A They have the same mass and the same volume but different weights.

B They have the same mass and the same weight but different volumes.

C They have the same mass, the same volume and the same weight.

D They have the same weight and the same volume but different masses.

A car travels at various speeds during a short journey.

The table shows the distances travelled and the times taken during each of four stages
 \( P, Q, R \) and \( S \).

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline stage & \( \mathrm{P} \) & \( \mathrm{Q} \) & \( \mathrm{R} \) & \( \mathrm{S} \) \\
\hline distance travelled/km & \( 1.8 \) & \( 3.6 \) & \( 2.7 \) & \( 2.7 \) \\
time taken/minutes & 2 & 2 & 4 & 3 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

During which two stages is the car travelling at the same average speed?

A \( P \) and \( Q \)

B \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{S} \)

C \( Q \) and \( R \)

D \( \mathrm{R} \) and \( \mathrm{S} \)

![diagram](./assets/b520c24c-39ef-4332-bbd6-647088b33183.png)

 overflow? Do not include the cube already in the cylinder.

A 1

How many neutrons and protons does the nucleus have after emitting the \( \beta \)-particle?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\hline A & 144 & 92 \\
B & 144 & 93 \\

body:
Which arrangement may be used to step up a voltage?

![diagram](./assets/171fa942-0588-477b-8263-b0683ec73d33.png)

![diagram](./assets/2633ccbb-913b-41a9-ab2f-efe0450cec70.png)

![diagram](./assets/b97af1c7-c010-43b9-acaa-1b0bc9599481.png)

![diagram](./assets/c0489e8a-36e0-4ba7-8dae-51b4e34c0ee7.png)

Why are the electric lamps in a house lighting circuit normally connected in parallel?

A The current in every circuit must be the same.

B The lamps are always switched on and off at the same time.

C The voltage across each lamp must be the mains voltage.

D When one of the lamps blows, all the others go out.

Which component can store energy for use in time delay circuits?

A capacitor

B potentiometer

C resistor

D thermistor

Two rods \( X \) and \( Y \) look the same.

![diagram](./assets/9a747710-6e0f-4980-b1ed-c72770e4d57c.png)

![diagram](./assets/d2da8234-1881-46d4-b501-ee75f93c88ad.png)

![diagram](./assets/11de352f-d39f-4fb2-aaf0-b6c75a5e776c.png)

The \( \mathrm{N} \) pole of a magnet is brought close, in turn, to each end of both rods. The results of these
 four actions are shown in the table.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline end tested & result \\
\hline P & attraction \\
Q & attraction \\
R & attraction \\
S & repulsion \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which of the rods is a permanent magnet?

A neither of the rods

B both of the rods

C \( \operatorname{rod} \mathrm{X} \) only

D rod \( Y \) only

When the horn on a ship is sounded, the passengers hear an echo from a cliff after \( 4.0 \mathrm{~s} \).

If the speed of sound is \( 340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), how far away is the cliff?

A \( 170 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 340 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 680 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 1360 \mathrm{~m} \)

In a ripple tank, water waves move towards a barrier with a narrow gap.

barrier

![diagram](./assets/66ccf4b4-78df-4b55-8706-4f81e8e7dbb1.png)

Which diagram best shows the waves beyond the barrier?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/2aefcf25-d947-4db2-81ef-40f9da3882a8.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/8daca146-d441-45b4-a9d8-3c15054fb263.png)

![diagram](./assets/5f88d0f7-49bc-428a-9beb-d0cdb1f61b46.png)

How does heat from the Sun reach the Earth?

A conduction only

B convection only

C radiation only

D conduction, convection and radiation

A suspension of pollen grains in water is observed under a microscope. The pollen grains are
 seen to be moving all the time.

Which diagram illustrates this motion?

![diagram](./assets/1eca178a-f3ef-4464-b3b1-db2123300caf.png)

![diagram](./assets/5568214c-fae4-4da7-9078-573439bc9100.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/7d3e7802-43bf-4784-b0ea-fe632e290229.png)

![diagram](./assets/e8710006-75a0-4d41-a2b7-e3922d6e36a8.png)

Four blocks, each weighing \( 10 \mathrm{~N} \), rest on a horizontal table.

Which block applies the greatest pressure on the table?

![diagram](./assets/9c1c453f-7ef0-407d-b601-e93c244b2244.png)

A man standing at the top of a cliff throws a stone.

![diagram](./assets/71f1aafc-5945-47ff-9937-eabbca49b892.png)

Which forms of energy does the stone have at \( X \) and at \( Y \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & energy at \( X \) & energy at \( Y \) \\
\hline A & gravitational only & kinetic only \\
B & kinetic only & gravitational only \\
C & gravitational only & gravitational and kinetic \\
D & gravitational and kinetic & gravitational and kinetic \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a mercury manometer used to measure the pressure of gas in a container.
 Atmospheric pressure is \( 76 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury.

![diagram](./assets/40c24b5f-a675-4dec-83dd-a2aa5152321d.png)

What is the pressure of the gas?

A \( 56 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

B \( 68 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

C \( 84 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

D \( 96 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

Which statement is explained by reference to pressure?

A Objects with greater mass have greater weight.

B One kilogram of water occupies more volume than one kilogram of lead.

C Spikes on running-shoes sink into the ground.

D Water cooled to a low enough temperature turns to ice.

The diagram shows a handle with three forces, each \( 100 \mathrm{~N} \), applied to it. The handle is free to
 move.

![diagram](./assets/bd34282f-0578-4880-b772-05d15b786c62.png)

What is the effect of the forces on the handle?

A The handle will move downwards.

B The handle will not move.

C The handle will turn anticlockwise (to the left).

D The handle will turn clockwise (to the right).

Passengers are not allowed to stand on the upper deck of double-decker buses.

![diagram](./assets/82151fe5-e2b3-4ea4-a1d2-36febd995c9e.png)

Why is this?

A They would cause the bus to become less stable.

B They would cause the bus to slow down.

C They would increase the kinetic energy of the bus.

D They would lower the centre of mass of the bus.

A geologist places a small rock on the left-hand pan of a balance. The two pans are level as
 shown when masses with a total weight of \( 23 \mathrm{~N} \) are placed on the right-hand pan.
 Take the weight of \( 1.0 \mathrm{~kg} \) to be \( 10 \mathrm{~N} \).

![diagram](./assets/5dc99ad7-e478-4d37-b3a1-3681b9763157.png)

![diagram](./assets/8e0ac1c4-7899-4f5e-80ea-2d42ef3b7bc1.png)

What is the mass of the small rock?

A \( \quad 0.023 \mathrm{~kg} \)

B \( \quad 2.3 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( 23 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D \( 230 \mathrm{~kg} \)

A car is moving downhill along a road at a constant speed.

Which graph is the speed/time graph for the car?

![diagram](./assets/c9afc93d-7437-4411-aa39-eed348713149.png)

![diagram](./assets/8c41ec3c-e851-45d5-8efa-fece2667f0e6.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/2fb4b977-53b9-411f-b150-11488eb813e0.png)

![diagram](./assets/acabafd2-d9f7-4863-82a3-354ae63578e8.png)

A cylindrical can is rolled along the ruler shown in the diagram.

starting position

final position

![diagram](./assets/dc37cf9a-786e-449a-ab28-0a55f215f7df.png)

The can rolls over twice.

What is the circumference (distance all round) of the can?

A \( 13 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 14 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 26 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 28 \mathrm{~cm} \)

Which statement about the nuclei of all atoms is correct?

A They are very small compared with the size of the atoms.

B They always contain the same number of protons as neutrons.

C They contain electrons, neutrons and protons.

D They have a total charge of zero.

A solenoid is connected to a very sensitive ammeter. A rod is inserted into one end of the
 solenoid. The ammeter shows that there is a small electric current in the circuit while the rod is
 moving.

solenoid

![diagram](./assets/161ff691-b712-4f2f-889d-16c8fe678420.png)

Which rod is being inserted?

A a heated copper rod

B a magnetised steel rod

C an uncharged nylon rod

D a radioactive uranium rod

Three vibrating objects \( \mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q} \) and \( \mathrm{R} \) produce waves in the air of different frequencies as shown.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline object & frequency/Hz \\
\hline\( P \) & 25 \\
\( Q \) & 1000 \\
\( R \) & 15000 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which of these waves can be heard by a human ear?

A P, Q and R

B \( P \) and \( Q \) only

C P and R only

D \( Q \) and \( R \) only

Waves travel more quickly on the surface of water when the water is deep.

A stone is dropped at point \( X \) into a pool of varying depth. The diagram shows the first wavefront
 on the surface of the pool.

The region between \( X \) and which labelled point is likely to be the deepest?

![diagram](./assets/bae12484-9837-4f1d-8c10-8cbc3d099b4e.png)

A heater is to be fitted in a room to warm the air throughout the room.

The diagram shows two possible positions to fit the heater, \( P \) and \( Q \).

![diagram](./assets/e6152bec-e5ee-4fb9-84eb-0950f570b007.png)

Which position is better and why?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & position & why? \\
\hline A & P & warmer air is less dense and rises \\
B & P & warmer air is more dense and rises \\
C & Q & warmer air is less dense and falls \\
D & Q & warmer air is more dense and falls \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A manometer is used to measure the pressure of the air in a container.

![diagram](./assets/30377452-c8cb-493e-b27f-12f62f8aad8a.png)

connection

to container

Which change would give a bigger value of height \( h \) ?

A using a less dense liquid

B using a more dense liquid

C using a narrower tube

D using a wider tube

When a bicycle lamp is switched on, what is the useful energy change within the battery?

A chemical energy to electrical energy

B electrical energy to chemical energy

C electrical energy to light energy

D light energy to chemical energy

The diagram shows a uniform, flat metal sheet hanging freely from a nail at point A. A weight also
 hangs freely on a string tied to \( \mathbf{A} \).

One of the labelled points is at the centre of mass of the metal sheet.

Which point is at the centre of mass?

![diagram](./assets/9623d64a-9af7-40fc-914a-504c84c68383.png)

Radioactive source \( S \) emits \( \alpha \)-particles, \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays. A detector is placed \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) away
 from S. A thin sheet of paper is placed as shown in the diagram.

![diagram](./assets/5035a4bc-03a7-42f4-9128-65c31859962d.png)

Which emissions from the source can be detected?

A \( \alpha \)-particles and \( \beta \)-particles only

B \( \alpha \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays only

C \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays only

D \( \alpha \)-particles, \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays

body:
The radioactive nucleus \( { }_{83}^{214} \mathrm{Bi} \) decays to another nucleus by the emission of a \( \beta \)-particle.

What is the proton number and what is the nucleon number of the nucleus formed by this decay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & proton number & nucleon number \\
\hline A & 81 & 210 \\
B & 81 & 212 \\
C & 84 & 213 \\
D & 84 & 214 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
What happens in the process of nuclear fission?

A electrons are added to a nucleus

B electrons are removed from a nucleus

C the nucleus of an atom splits

D two atomic nuclei join together

Two NAND gates are connected together as shown.

input 1

input 2

![diagram](./assets/569c6b4b-9816-458f-b816-3dc2028d10eb.png)

The arrangement acts like a single logic gate.

What is the name of this single logic gate?

A AND

B NOR

C NOT

D OR

In the circuit shown, the voltmeter reads \( 2.0 \mathrm{~V} \). A charge of \( 5.0 \mathrm{C} \) passes through the resistor in a
 certain time.

![diagram](./assets/1115c60c-6adf-4cf6-80e2-85d9142b806c.png)

How much energy is supplied to the resistor in this time?

A \( 0.40 \mathrm{~J} \)

B \( 2.5 \mathrm{~J} \)

C \( 10 \mathrm{~J} \)

D \( 20 \mathrm{~J} \)

A student suggests three methods for demagnetising a piece of steel.

1 placing it in an east-west direction and hammering it hard

2 placing it in an east-west direction and heating it until red hot

3 removing it slowly from a coil carrying alternating current

Which of the methods will demagnetise the piece of steel?

A 1 only

B 2 only

C 3 only

D 1,2 and 3

The diagrams show four spherical objects of the same colour and same type of surface. Two of
 the objects are small and two are large. Two of the objects are at the same high temperature and
 two are at the same low temperature.

Which object emits infra-red radiation at the greatest rate?

\( \mathbf{A} \)

B

\( \mathbf{C} \)

D

![diagram](./assets/3c2dfba7-9279-45f0-b86f-bee95c1a1536.png)

The equation used to find the pressure caused by a liquid can be written as

where \( p \) is the pressure and \( h \) is the depth of the liquid.

Which row gives the quantities \( Y \) and \( Z \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Y & Z \\
\hline A & cross-sectional area & gravitational field strength \\
B & cross-sectional area & volume \\
C & density & cross-sectional area \\
D & density & gravitational field strength \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which list contains only vector quantities?

A acceleration, energy, force, mass

B acceleration, force, momentum, velocity

C distance, energy, mass, speed

D distance, momentum, power, speed

Two electrical appliances are connected to the mains supply.

The cable connected to one appliance includes an earth wire.

The cable connected to the second appliance does not need an earth wire.

What is a reason for this difference?

A One appliance has a metal case, but the other appliance does not.

B One appliance is fitted with a fuse, but the other appliance is not.

C One appliance is fitted with a switch, but the other appliance is not.

D One appliance needs more current than the other appliance.

The diagram shows a circuit containing two identical lamps and three ammeters.

ammeter 1

![diagram](./assets/565ae6ea-51d8-4306-8d47-84d6f3fb630a.png)

The current in ammeter 1 is \( 0.30 \mathrm{~A} \).

Which row gives possible values for the currents in ammeters 2 and 3 ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { ammeter } 2 \\
/ A\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { ammeter } 3 \\
\text { /A }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & \( 0.15 \) & \( 0.00 \) \\
B & \( 0.15 \) & \( 0.30 \) \\
C & \( 0.30 \) & \( 0.00 \) \\
D & \( 0.30 \) & \( 0.30 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Below are four statements about the diffraction of a wave on the surface of water.

Which statement is correct?

A Diffraction involves a change in the speed of the wave.

B Diffraction involves a change in the wavelength of the wave.

C When a wave passes through a gap, its direction changes.

D When a wave passes through a gap, its frequency changes.

A piece of melting ice at \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and a beaker of boiling water are both in a laboratory. The
 laboratory is at \( 20^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \).

![diagram](./assets/3408863a-fc17-4286-b576-afec986ae86f.png)

![diagram](./assets/9a58abc3-0356-4ddd-9573-9a7f0f4c77a4.png)

Bunsen burner
 heating water

What is happening to the temperature of the melting ice and what is happening to the
 temperature of the boiling water?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { temperature of } \\
\text { melting ice }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { temperature of } \\
\text { boiling water }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & constant & constant \\
B & constant & increasing \\
C & increasing & constant \\
D & increasing & increasing \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Smoke particles in air are illuminated by a beam of light. The particles are viewed through a
 microscope. They are seen to move in a random zig-zag way.

What causes this movement?

A convection currents in the air

B impacts of fast-moving air molecules

C the energy of the beam of light

D vibrations of the atoms in the smoke particles
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
A student investigates a steel spring. He measures the length of the spring, then he hangs
 different weights from the spring. He measures the length of the spring for each different weight.

The table shows his results.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline weight/N & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { length of } \\
\text { spring /mm }\end{array} \) \\
\hline \( 0.0 \) & 108 \\
\( 2.0 \) & 116 \\
\( 4.0 \) & 124 \\
\( 6.0 \) & 132 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A weight of \( 3.0 \mathrm{~N} \) is hung from the spring.

What is the extension of the spring?

A \( 4 \mathrm{~mm} \)

B \( 12 \mathrm{~mm} \)

C \( 40 \mathrm{~mm} \)

D \( 120 \mathrm{~mm} \)

Which diagram shows a movement that will not produce the changing magnetic field needed to
 induce an e.m.f. in the coil?

![diagram](./assets/342e4953-3980-4c91-a8ba-71938b84b2fb.png)

moving a magnet and a coil towards each other
 at the same speed

![diagram](./assets/e9f8f0a5-ef2c-4ac9-af90-7bc72ee050ef.png)

moving a magnet and a coil in the same direction
 at the same speed

C

![diagram](./assets/2ab3c138-c790-49c6-8caf-6a3a35aacae9.png)
 moving a magnet away from a fixed coil

![diagram](./assets/0631c4a6-8716-4e26-9a91-8a1ecf6a60d2.png)
 moving a coil away from a fixed magnet

How can a permanent magnet be demagnetised?

A cool the magnet for a long time

B hit the magnet repeatedly with a hammer

C leave the magnet in a coil which is connected to a battery

D shine bright light onto the magnet

Which diagram shows how an image of an object is formed on a screen by a converging lens?

![diagram](./assets/c3d4ba73-1abb-4ad1-ad27-900c513f78d6.png)

B

![diagram](./assets/51a8d25e-a7d6-4d6a-b78d-7e6b6822cdea.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/d50ee6ad-8b99-423a-b729-471330d7b7d1.png)

![diagram](./assets/ed924950-ff99-47df-a022-232877e7ad8c.png)

The table gives common uses for three types of electromagnetic wave.

Which row correctly identifies the waves?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & satellite television & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { terrestrial television } \\
\text { (not satellite) }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { television remote } \\
\text { controllers }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & infra-red waves & microwaves & radio waves \\
B & microwaves & radio waves & infra-red waves \\
C & radio waves & infra-red waves & microwaves \\
D & radio waves & microwaves & infra-red waves \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A boy throws a small stone into a pond. Waves spread out from where the stone hits the water
 and travel to the side of the pond.

The boy notices that eight waves reach the side of the pond in a time of \( 5.0 \mathrm{~s} \).

What is the frequency of the waves?

A \( 0.20 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

B \( 0.63 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

C \( 1.6 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

D \( 40 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

A man goes into a cold room and switches on a heater. The man then stands one metre away
 from the heater. He feels warmer almost immediately.

![diagram](./assets/c237c57b-ec1e-4e14-9297-6c45a77ad959.png)

How is thermal energy transferred from the heater to the man so quickly?

A by conduction, convection and radiation

B by conduction only

C by convection only

D by radiation only

A block of ice cream is prevented from melting by wrapping it in newspaper soaked in water. The
 water evaporates from the newspaper.


Which molecules escape from the water and what happens to the average speed of the water
 molecules that remain in the newspaper?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & escaping molecules & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { average speed of the } \\
\text { remaining water molecules }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & the less energetic ones & decreases \\
B & the less energetic ones & increases \\
C & the more energetic ones & decreases \\
D & the more energetic ones & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A small steel ball is dropped from a low balcony.

Ignoring air resistance, which statement describes its motion?

A It falls with constant acceleration.

B It falls with constant speed.

C It falls with decreasing speed.

D It falls with increasing acceleration.

The nuclide notation for radium-226 is \( { }_{88}^{226} \mathrm{Ra} \).

How many electrons orbit the nucleus of a neutral atom of radium-226?

A 0

B 88

C 138

D 226

A student investigates how the radiation from a radioactive source changes with time.

The table shows the results from the detector used by the student.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \( \begin{array}{c}\text { time/ } \\
\text { minutes }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { count rate/ } \\
\text { counts per minute }\end{array} \) \\
\hline 0 & 340 \\
\( 2.0 \) & 180 \\
\( 4.0 \) & 100 \\
\( 6.0 \) & 60 \\
\( 8.0 \) & 40 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The experiment is repeated by many other students, who also measure the count rate every two
 minutes.

The half-life of the source is known to be exactly \( 2.0 \) minutes.

Why is the measured count rate always greater than half the previous value?

A Radioactive emissions occur randomly with time.

B The detector used is very close to the source.

C There is background radiation present.

D The radioactive source is decaying.

The diagram shows a potential divider circuit.

![diagram](./assets/e9ff960b-8e87-4b50-8eb7-ac50d2af6aee.png)

The resistance of the variable resistor is increased.

Which row shows what happens to the readings on voltmeter \( P \) and on voltmeter \( Q \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & reading on voltmeter \( P \) & reading on voltmeter \( \mathrm{Q} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The circuit shown contains a battery, a \( 6.0 \Omega \) resistor and two meters \( \mathrm{X} \) and \( \mathrm{Y} \).

One meter records current and one meter records potential difference.

![diagram](./assets/b7c98e61-2d89-409d-87c7-4df6532878f9.png)

Which row shows possible values for the readings on the meters?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & meter \( X \) & meter \( \mathrm{Y} \) \\
\hline A & \( 2.0 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) \\
B & \( 2.0 \mathrm{~V} \) & \( 12 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
C & \( 12 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 2.0 \mathrm{~V} \) \\
D & \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) & \( 2.0 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A metal wire of circular cross-section has diameter \( d \) and length \( l \).

![diagram](./assets/d3bbd63c-1c0e-4363-b5da-a49278969e05.png)

Which pair of changes, if both are carried out, must increase the resistance of the wire?

A decrease \( l \) and decrease \( d \)

B decrease \( l \) and increase \( d \)

C increase \( l \) and decrease \( d \)

D increase \( l \) and increase \( d \)

Which procedure may be used to demagnetise a steel bar?

A cooling it in a freezer for several hours

B earthing it with a copper wire for several seconds

C removing it slowly from a coil carrying an alternating current (a.c.)

D rubbing it in one direction with a woollen cloth

Which metal could be used for a permanent magnet and which metal could be used for the core
 of an electromagnet?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { permanent } \\
\text { magnet }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { core of } \\
\text { electromagnet }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & iron & copper \\
B & iron & steel \\
C & steel & copper \\
D & steel & iron \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A pulse of sound is produced at the bottom of a boat. The sound travels through the water and is
 reflected from the sea bed. The sound reaches the boat again after \( 1.2 \mathrm{~s} \). The speed of sound in
 the water is \( 1500 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

![diagram](./assets/ae8ac102-4db3-4d0e-81e9-a57bfc7dd5f0.png)

![diagram](./assets/807d5d76-e7f8-4f88-b2a4-85ace24f3c5d.png)

How far below the bottom of the boat is the sea bed?

A \( 450 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 900 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 1800 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 3600 \mathrm{~m} \)

A student wishes to check the upper and the lower fixed points on a Celsius scale thermometer.
undefined

She has four beakers \( P, Q, R \) and \( S \).

Beaker \( Q \) contains a mixture of ice and water.

Beaker R contains boiling salt solution.

Beaker S contains boiling water.

A \( P \) and \( R \)

B \( P \) and \( S \)

C \( Q \) and \( R \)

 containing water.

 reading on the voltmeter?

B & decreases & increases \\

body:

body:
Which particle is absorbed by a nucleus to cause nuclear fission?

A a neutron

B a proton

An electric current can produce a heating effect and a magnetic effect.

\hline & effect used by a relay & one application of a relay \\
\hline A & heating effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
B & heating effect & changing the voltage of an a.c. supply \\
C & magnetic effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
D & magnetic effect & changing the voltage of an a.c. supply \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

D moving the lamp to point \( P \) in the circuit

A student holds a rod in his hand.

\hline
\end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

On a building site, metal scaffolding is firmly embedded in the damp ground. A builder holds a
 mains-operated electric drill in one hand. With his other hand he holds on to the scaffolding.

A A current could pass through the builder and electrocute him.

B A current in the scaffolding could heat it up and burn him.

C The large current could blow the fuse and damage the drill.

D The large current could make the motor spin too quickly.

A certain electrical appliance is powered from a mains supply. The appliance normally uses a

The fuses available to protect the cable are rated at \( 1 \mathrm{~A}, 3 \mathrm{~A}, 5 \mathrm{~A} \) and \( 13 \mathrm{~A} \).

Which fuse should be used?

A \( 1 \mathrm{~A} \)

B \( 3 A \)

B \( \quad 0.50 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( \quad 0.65 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D \( 0.80 \mathrm{~kg} \)

A train travels along a track from Aytown to Beetown. The map shows the route.

![diagram](./assets/6a600a7a-30d8-4f9d-9194-af46617a1d09.png)

The distance travelled by the train between the towns is \( 210 \mathrm{~km} \). It moves at an average speed of
 \( 70 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \).

How long does the journey take?

A less than \( \frac{70}{210} \) hours, because the journey is not in a straight line

B exactly \( \frac{70}{210} \) hours

C exactly \( \frac{210}{70} \) hours

D more than \( \frac{210}{70} \) hours, because the journey is not in a straight line

The diagram represents a carbon atom.

![diagram](./assets/fa745d4a-770c-46e6-be8e-3a3bfc2ca8f9.png)

key

neutron

\(  \) proton

electron

What is the nucleon number (mass number) for this atom?

A 6

B 8

C 14

D 20

The reading on the ammeter in the circuit is \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \).

A second ammeter is connected in the circuit. It also reads \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \).

At which labelled point is it connected?

![diagram](./assets/d9dd3ede-f2c4-4fb0-b5a6-fa7b022a9e2c.png)

Which copper wire would have the smallest resistance?

A a long, thick wire

B a long, thin wire

C a short, thick wire

D a short, thin wire

Two soft-iron rods are placed end to end inside a coil which is connected to a battery.

![diagram](./assets/9fc98345-b0d0-45c7-a8ae-02668126ca1d.png)

soft-iron rod soft-iron rod

The connections from the battery to the coil are now reversed.

What happens to the soft-iron rods in each case?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { battery connections } \\
\text { as shown }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { battery connections } \\
\text { reversed }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & rods attract & rods attract \\
B & rods attract & rods repel \\
C & rods repel & rods attract \\
D & rods repel & rods repel \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which diagram shows how a ray of light could pass through a glass block in air?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/aeb0c08e-1549-4f28-a236-26834e0416ce.png)

![diagram](./assets/7d71c393-a0e1-49ce-ac71-d8fbda23cc40.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/8ab49d51-cbd6-443a-9da2-3fe0dd411c09.png)

![diagram](./assets/b8deab87-db73-49be-9de0-0b3be123726e.png)

Different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum are used for different purposes. Below are four
 statements about parts of the spectrum.

statement 1: Infra-red waves are used in television remote controllers.

statement 2: Radio waves are used to transmit television pictures from satellites to Earth.

statement 3: Ultra-violet waves are used for intruder alarms.

statement 4: X-rays are used for security checks.

Which statements are correct?

A 1 and 2

B 1 and 4

C 2 and 3

D 3 and 4

The diagram shows a refrigerator.

The cooling unit is placed at the top. The cooling unit cools the air near it.

![diagram](./assets/84d3a410-0d20-4d81-8743-ab410cc59a98.png)

What happens to the density of the air as it cools, and how does it move?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & density of the air & movement of the air \\
\hline A & decreases & moves down \\
B & decreases & stays at the top \\
C & increases & moves down \\
D & increases & stays at the top \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A gas storage tank has a fixed volume. The graph shows how the temperature of the gas in the
 tank varies with time.

![diagram](./assets/b78dc427-5670-4304-9bbe-06c573e035da.png)

At time \( Y \), the gas molecules are

A closer together than at time \( X \).

B hitting the sides of the tank harder than at time \( X \).

C larger in size than at time \( X \).

D moving more slowly than at time \( \mathrm{X} \).

The diagram shows a simple mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/a0b07870-2c21-4b17-93d2-323dc10a0a96.png)

Which length is used to find the value of atmospheric pressure?

A \( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 74 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 86 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 100 \mathrm{~cm} \)

A measuring cylinder has a mass of \( 120 \mathrm{~g} \) when empty.

When it contains \( 50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \) of a liquid, the total mass of the measuring cylinder and the liquid is
 \( 160 \mathrm{~g} \).

What is the density of the liquid?

\( \frac{40}{50} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

\( \frac{50}{40} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

C \( \frac{120}{50} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

D \( \frac{160}{50} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

How many of the following methods could be used to demagnetise a piece of steel?

heating it until it is red hot

pulling it from a coil that is carrying an alternating current

placing it in an east-west direction and hammering it

putting it in a coil which is carrying a direct current

A 1

B 2

C 3

D 4

Rays of light enter and leave a box.

![diagram](./assets/188e6c43-c7fd-47be-b03e-07d0bcc43fab.png)

What could be inside the box to make the rays behave as shown?

A a converging lens

B a parallel-sided glass block

C a plane mirror

D a triangular prism

A knife is being sharpened on a rotating sharpening-stone. A spark flies off and lands on the
 operator's hand. The spark is a very hot, very small piece of metal. The operator feels nothing.

What does this show about the piece of metal?

A It has a high thermal capacity.

B It has a low thermal capacity.

C It is a good conductor of heat.

D It is a poor conductor of heat.

The diagram shows a mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/0e9a7dab-dabc-4e8e-a319-80c07428d16d.png)

Which distance is used to calculate the pressure of the atmosphere?

A \( 25 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 75 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 80 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 100 \mathrm{~cm} \)

Which type of power station does not use steam from boiling water to generate electricity?

A geothermal

B hydroelectric

C nuclear

D oil-fired

The diagram shows a flat metal plate that may be hung from a nail so that it can rotate about any
 of four holes.

![diagram](./assets/2aaa134e-edad-46e0-97ea-18e009fb4f1b.png)


What is the smallest number of holes from which the flat metal plate should be hung in order to
 find its centre of gravity?

A 1

B 2

C 3

D 4

The same mass of four different liquids is placed in some measuring cylinders.

Which measuring cylinder contains the liquid with the greatest density?

![diagram](./assets/ffa5f907-9460-4c3a-83c5-1e802c1b14be.png)

A village has to be supplied with electricity from a power station that is a long way from the
 village.

Which type of current should be used, and at which voltage?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & type of current & voltage \\
\hline A & alternating current & high voltage \\
B & alternating current & low voltage \\
C & direct current & high voltage \\
D & direct current & low voltage \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A chain of steel nails and a chain of iron nails hang from a strong magnet. The chains are then
 carefully removed from the magnet.

![diagram](./assets/adc9a2a6-334d-482c-9a1f-10a8320c4adb.png)
 iron

What happens to the chains?

A Both chains fall apart.

B Both chains stay together.

C Only the chain of iron nails falls apart.

D Only the chain of steel nails falls apart.

Which statement about a magnet is not correct?

A It can attract another magnet.

B It can attract an unmagnetised piece of iron.

C It can repel another magnet.

D It can repel an unmagnetised piece of iron.

A potential difference (p.d.) across a resistor causes a current in it.

![diagram](./assets/3ebd5188-4186-4776-a184-4908532ebf96.png)

The p.d. and the resistance of the resistor can both be changed.

Which row shows two changes that will both increase the current in the resistor?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & change & change \\
\hline A & decrease p.d. & decrease resistance \\
B & decrease p.d. & increase resistance \\
C & increase p.d. & decrease resistance \\
D & increase p.d. & increase resistance \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagrams represent two different sound waves.

wave \( P \)

wave \( Q \)

![diagram](./assets/24acc5fa-486a-450c-af74-22cb4d8c6e8c.png)

How do the frequency and pitch of \( P \) compare with the frequency and pitch of \( Q \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & frequency of \( P \) & pitch of \( P \) \\
\hline A & greater than \( Q \) & higher than \( Q \) \\
B & greater than \( Q \) & same as \( Q \) \\
C & same as \( Q \) & higher than \( Q \) \\
D & same as \( Q \) & same as \( Q \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A girl writes the word LEFT on a piece of card.

![diagram](./assets/ed25c854-5b13-4388-9248-5bbdccf35df0.png)

She looks at the image of this card, made by reflection by a plane mirror.
 What does she see?
undefined

The extension/load graph for a spring is shown. The unloaded length of the spring is \( 15.0 \mathrm{~cm} \).

![diagram](./assets/3353aec6-88be-4899-944a-abdc48095405.png)

When an object of unknown weight is hung on the spring, the length of the spring is \( 16.4 \mathrm{~cm} \).

What is the weight of the object?

A \( 0.55 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( \quad 0.67 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 3.5 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 4.1 \mathrm{~N} \)

A force acts on a moving rubber ball.

Which of these changes could not happen to the ball because of the force?

A a change in direction

B a change in mass

C a change in shape

D a change in speed

Which list contains the name of a force?

A acceleration, charge, temperature

B density, resistance, speed

C distance, frequency, mass

D energy, power, weight

The diagram shows an electric circuit.

![diagram](./assets/a5d5753c-f71f-415a-b085-b91a4ca33d00.png)

When the switch is open, which lamp or lamps are not lit?

A R only

B S only

C R, S and \( \mathrm{T} \)

D S and \( T \) only

A student draws four diagrams to represent light passing from air through a glass block and then
 back into the air.

The critical angle for the glass is \( 42^{\circ} \).

In which diagram is the path of the light through the glass block not correct?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/7a039b81-7f5d-42c5-8cfe-406762986589.png)

![diagram](./assets/d4528273-3947-4b86-8115-631dceed81e8.png)

![diagram](./assets/ae7c1845-48d2-4e58-b62f-2f4b1305fa2f.png)

D

![diagram](./assets/962d1339-7d1f-4f84-815d-813f16649a27.png)

The box contains a list of four types of wave.

\( \gamma \)-rays sound ultraviolet \( \mathrm{X} \)-rays

How many waves in the list are transverse waves?

A 1

B 2

C 3

D 4

Water can exist in three states: solid (ice), liquid and gas (steam).

In which state, or states, is the motion of the molecules only vibrational?

A ice only

B steam only

C liquid water only

D liquid water and ice only

body:
The diagrams show the actual sizes of the heels of four different shoes, as seen from underneath
 the shoe.

Which heel is most likely to cause damage to wooden floors?

\( \mathbf{A} \)

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/3358defc-d05e-4a08-994d-70d34e3c8c22.png)

![diagram](./assets/698555b1-94c1-48fa-ae18-6c5320872267.png)

A force is applied to a long crowbar so as to move a large rock.

Which labelled arrow represents the smallest force needed to move the rock?

![diagram](./assets/0ec37485-18dc-429f-a524-469c5a63bbee.png)

A student uses a measuring cylinder and a balance to find the density of oil. The diagram shows
 the arrangement used.

![diagram](./assets/8e1ca2e7-da27-43b4-a7c8-ba85a9e18d86.png)

Which calculation gives the density of the oil?

A \( \quad \frac{V}{m_{2}} \)

B \( \frac{V}{\left(m_{2}-m_{1}\right)} \)

C \( \frac{m_{2}}{\mathrm{~V}} \)

D \( \frac{\left(m_{2}-m_{1}\right)}{V} \)

A student writes about mass and weight.

Which statement is correct?

A A ship which is floating has mass but no weight.

B Mass is a scientific word that means the same as weight.

C Mass is measured in newtons.

D The mass of an astronaut is the same on the Moon as on the Earth.

Radioactive source \( S \) emits \( \alpha \)-particles, \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays. A detector is placed \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) away
 from S. A thin sheet of paper is placed as shown in the diagram.

![diagram](./assets/eca25695-3e1d-4760-abbc-1e8b8a7b4f0c.png)

Which emissions from the source can be detected?

A \( \alpha \)-particles and \( \beta \)-particles only

B \( \alpha \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays only

C \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays only

D \( \quad \alpha \)-particles, \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays

body:
The circuit shows a \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) battery connected to a lamp of resistance \( 3.0 \Omega \).

![diagram](./assets/7d9b1416-6681-4ad2-b609-1add4131e453.png)

How much energy is transferred to the surroundings by the lamp in \( 2.0 \) minutes?

A 48 48

B \( 96 \mathrm{~J} \)

C \( 2880 \mathrm{~J} \)

D \( 5760 \mathrm{~J} \)

Light travelling at a speed of \( 3.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) strikes the surface of a glass block and undergoes
 refraction as it enters the block.

The diagram shows a ray of this light before and after it enters the block.

![diagram](./assets/becdef54-9cd9-4ef9-a3ae-7786cff375f2.png)

What is the speed of light in the glass?

A \( 1.8 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

B \( 2.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

C \( 4.5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

D \( \quad 5.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

A lamp has a power input of \( 5.0 \mathrm{~W} \). It wastes \( 1.0 \mathrm{~W} \) of power heating the surroundings.

What is the efficiency of the lamp?

A \( 20 \% \)

B \( 50 \% \)

C \( 80 \% \)

D \( 120 \% \)

An object travels in a circular path at constant speed.

Which statement about the object is correct?

A It has changing kinetic energy.

B It has changing momentum.

C It has constant velocity.

D It is not accelerating.

A nucleus \( X \) has 17 protons and 18 neutrons.

Which notation is correct for this nucleus?

A \( \quad \begin{array}{l}17 \\ 18\end{array} \)

B \( \quad 17 x \)

C \( { }_{17}^{18} \mathrm{X} \)

D \( { }_{17}^{35} x \)

 ner will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity.

idge International Examinations is part of the Cambridge Assessment Group. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of University of Cambridge Local

Which diagram shows a movement that will not produce the changing magnetic field needed to
 induce an e.m.f. in the coil?

![diagram](./assets/9b16d373-eb23-4928-8caf-69c4d8ee2c14.png)

moving a magnet and a coil towards each other
 at the same speed

B

![diagram](./assets/e45606b0-ee34-4645-bd3a-62aee90b38ec.png)

moving a magnet and a coil in the same direction
 at the same speed

C

![diagram](./assets/cd6414e9-9bb9-49c5-87d8-976c2b9c0d5b.png)
 moving a magnet away from a fixed coil

![diagram](./assets/65c053f4-db66-404e-8909-f931b0f19d1f.png)

![diagram](./assets/6688b516-4ac2-4ce3-a26c-0eacefceaa0b.png)
 moving a coil away from a fixed magnet

The circuit shown contains a relay.

Both lamps are initially off.

![diagram](./assets/d8cb5bb7-b403-4765-be4c-8db48f204173.png)

lamp 1

When switch \( \mathrm{S} \) is closed, the relay operates. What is the state of the lamps?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & lamp 1 & lamp 2 \\
\hline A & on & on \\
B & on & off \\
C & off & on \\
D & off & off \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A boy throws a small stone into a pond. Waves spread out from where the stone hits the water
 and travel to the side of the pond.

The boy notices that eight waves reach the side of the pond in a time of \( 5.0 \mathrm{~s} \).

What is the frequency of the waves?

A \( 0.20 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

B \( 0.63 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

C \( 1.6 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

D \( 40 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

A man goes into a cold room and switches on a heater. The man then stands one metre away
 from the heater. He feels warmer almost immediately.

![diagram](./assets/17e98c75-7291-4ef2-a349-0bbef815bc8f.png)

How is thermal energy transferred from the heater to the man so quickly?

A by conduction, convection and radiation

B by conduction only

C by convection only

D by radiation only

The diagram shows a sealed jar containing a gas.

![diagram](./assets/432e8c6a-e18f-4783-bf8c-46438c7771b0.png)

Which statement about the gas in the jar is correct?

A The gas molecules collide with the inside of the jar more often as the temperature increases.

B The gas molecules move more slowly as the temperature increases.

C The pressure of the gas decreases as the temperature increases.

D The pressure of the gas is higher at the top of the jar than at the bottom of the jar.

The diagrams show four divers at the bottom of four different swimming pools.

Two swimming pools contain fresh water and two contain salt water. Fresh water is less dense
 than salt water.

Which diver feels the least pressure from the water?
undefined

C

D

\begin{tabular}{|c|}
\hline salt \\
water \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|}
\hline salt \\
water \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A drawing pin (thumb tack) has a sharp point and a flat end.

![diagram](./assets/9f97ba07-935c-4658-b34b-7f0bf5134b68.png)

The pin is pushed into a wooden board.

How do the pressure and the force at the sharp point compare with the pressure and the force at
 the flat end?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & force at the sharp point & pressure at the sharp point \\
\hline A & greater than at the flat end & greater than at the flat end \\
B & greater than at the flat end & less than at the flat end \\
C & the same as at the flat end & greater than at the flat end \\
D & the same as at the flat end & less than at the flat end \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Some energy sources are reliably available at all times, and some are not.

Which row shows three sources all in their correct columns?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & available at all times & not available at all times \\
\hline A & geothermal & nuclear fission, solar \\
B & geothermal, nuclear fission & solar \\
C & solar, nuclear fission & geothermal \\
D & solar & nuclear fission, geothermal \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A force acting on an object causes some properties of the object to change.

Which list contains only properties that can be changed by the action of the force?

A mass, motion and shape

B mass, motion and size

C mass, shape and size

D motion, shape and size

A cup contains hot liquid.

Some of the liquid evaporates.

What happens to the mass and to the weight of the liquid in the cup?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & mass & weight \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & stays the same \\
C & stays the same & decreases \\
D & stays the same & stays the same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which is the unit for force and which is the unit for weight?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & force & weight \\
\hline A & \( \mathrm{kg} \) & \( \mathrm{kg} \) \\
B & \( \mathrm{kg} \) & \( \mathrm{N} \) \\
C & \( \mathrm{N} \) & \( \mathrm{kg} \) \\
D & \( \mathrm{N} \) & \( \mathrm{N} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a \( 10 \Omega \) resistor and a \( 20 \Omega \) resistor connected in a potential divider circuit.

![diagram](./assets/1aa91fcd-c4ff-4b46-aaa3-2bd1d461a96c.png)

What is the reading on the voltmeter?

A \( 4.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

B \( 6.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

C \( 8.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

D \( 12.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

Which component is represented by this circuit symbol?

![diagram](./assets/2eb79bf3-dabe-4455-933d-10820d9766b3.png)

A a bell

B a fuse

C a relay

D a transformer

The diagram shows a circuit which includes an uncharged capacitor and a switch.

![diagram](./assets/8e645eb4-1ea7-4fcb-bb9d-282c88c298b4.png)

The switch can be moved between position \( \mathrm{X} \) and position \( \mathrm{Y} \).

What happens to the capacitor when the switch is moved to position \( \mathrm{X} \), and what happens when
 the switch is then moved to position Y?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & switch at \( X \) & switch at \( Y \) \\
\hline A & capacitor charges & capacitor charges \\
B & capacitor charges & capacitor discharges \\
C & capacitor discharges & capacitor charges \\
D & capacitor discharges & capacitor discharges \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What is the unit of electromotive force (e.m.f.)?

A ampere

B newton

C ohm

D volt

A man holding a starting pistol stands \( 640 \mathrm{~m} \) away from a spectator.

![diagram](./assets/06f9b285-45ca-4ce5-8e1d-87c623b51af8.png)

The spectator hears the sound of the starting pistol \( 2.0 \mathrm{~s} \) after seeing the flash from the pistol.

Using this information, what is the speed of sound in air?

A \( 160 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

B \( 320 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

C \( 640 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

D \( \quad 1280 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

A scientist tries to direct a ray of light in a glass block so that no light escapes from the top of the
 block.

However, some light does escape.

![diagram](./assets/6f6a63c7-c2e3-4c38-8b41-1fc81b7eb03b.png)

The scientist changes angle \( X \) and stops the light escaping from the top.

Which row in the table describes the change to angle \( X \) and the name of the effect produced?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & change to angle \( X \) & name of effect produced \\
\hline A & decrease & total internal reflection \\
B & decrease & total internal refraction \\
C & increase & total internal reflection \\
D & increase & total internal refraction \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Radiation from the Sun is dispersed by a prism. The prism does not absorb any of the radiation.
 Four identical thermometers are placed, one at each of the labelled positions.

In which position does the thermometer show the greatest rise in temperature?

![diagram](./assets/63e50f7d-6665-4a6a-b81e-44d083c358e0.png)

A cupboard is placed in front of a heater. Air can move through a gap under the cupboard.

![diagram](./assets/035a726b-5d8e-44ac-802f-5004abf2a606.png)

floor

Which row describes the temperature, and the direction of movement, of the air in the gap?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & air temperature & air direction \\
\hline A & cool & away from the heater \\
B & cool & towards the heater \\
C & warm & away from the heater \\
D & warm & towards the heater \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

One method of heat transfer involves the energy travelling at a much greater speed than in other
 methods.

What is the name of this method?

A conduction

B convection

C evaporation

D radiation
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
A solid is heated from room temperature. The graph shows how its temperature changes with
 time as it is heated constantly.

![diagram](./assets/c3a01151-5b94-48bf-aa77-48ad90ca8555.png)

Between which labelled points on the graph is the substance partly solid and partly liquid?

A between \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \)

B between \( Q \) and \( \mathrm{R} \)

C between \( \mathrm{R} \) and \( \mathrm{S} \)

D between \( \mathrm{S} \) and \( \mathrm{T} \)

The diagram shows a solid block resting on a bench. The dimensions of the block are shown.

![diagram](./assets/bbe09852-fa72-4d16-9269-f01f69e72ed9.png)

A student measures the length of a spring. She then hangs different weights from the spring. She
 measures the length of the spring for each different weight.

\( 1.0 \) & 524 \\
\( 2.0 \) & 528 \\
\( 3.0 \) & 533 \\
\( 4.0 \) & 537 \\
\( 5.0 \) & 540 \\

D \( 13 \mathrm{~mm} \)

B P is louder and lower in pitch than \( Q \).

A The bench is heated by convection from the bottom of the outer cup.

A neither the ruler nor the measuring cylinder

D the ruler only

Which particle is emitted in this process?

A an \( \alpha \)-particle

B a \( \beta \)-particle

C a neutron

D a proton

The pressure \( p \) and the volume \( V \) of the gas are found to be related by the equation:

Which quantities are kept constant and which quantities change?

body:
Which list contains only energy resources that derive their energy from the Sun?

A geothermal, nuclear, tidal

B hydroelectric, water waves, wind

C geothermal, hydroelectric, solar

D nuclear, solar, water waves

A ball is dropped onto a floor.

Its speed just before hitting the floor is \( 3.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

Which change would result in a speed of \( 6.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) just before hitting the floor?

Ignore any effects due to air resistance.

A Drop the ball from double the height above the floor.

B Drop the ball from four times the height above the floor.

C Use a ball with double the mass.

D Use a ball with four times the mass.

A vehicle of mass \( 900 \mathrm{~kg} \) is travelling with a velocity of \( 20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What is the momentum of the vehicle?

A \( 45 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) B \( 450 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) C \( 18000 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) D \( 180000 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

The graph shows the activity of a radioactive source over a period of time.

![diagram](./assets/7458e062-e19d-4017-8704-374fc0f51550.png)

time/hour

What is the half-life of the source?

A \( \frac{1}{2} \) hour

B 1 hour

C \( 1 \frac{1}{2} \) hours

D 3 hours

A scientist needs to use a source of \( \gamma \)-rays as safely as possible.

Which action will not reduce the amount of radiation that reaches the scientist?

A keeping the distance between the source and the scientist as large as possible

B keeping the temperature of the source as low as possible

C keeping the time for which the scientist uses the source as small as possible

D placing a lead screen between the scientist and the source

Cathode rays are emitted in a vacuum tube. They consist of particles that are found in atoms.

What is the name of the particles and how are the cathode rays produced?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & name of particles & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { how the cathode rays } \\
\text { are produced }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & electrons & electromagnetic induction \\
B & electrons & thermionic emission \\
C & protons & electromagnetic induction \\
D & protons & thermionic emission \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\end{tabular}

The diagram shows water waves passing through a gap in a harbour wall. The waves curve

\hline
\end{tabular}

A activity of a radioactive source, volume of a gas

B mass of a liquid, volume of a liquid

Brownian motion is observed when looking at smoke particles in air using a microscope.

What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

A Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

B Smoke particles are moved by convection currents in the air.

C Smoke particles have different weights and fall at different speeds.

D Smoke particles hit the walls of the container.

Which quantity is measured in newtons?

A density

B energy

C pressure

D weight

A 250

B 4000

C 6000

D 16000

The specific heat capacity of copper is \( 385 \mathrm{~J} /\left(\mathrm{kg}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \) and the specific heat capacity of water

A puddle of water is formed after a rain shower on a windy day.

Which statement explains the effect of the wind on the rate of evaporation of the water in the

B The wind removes evaporated water from near the surface and so decreases the rate of

 evaporation.


D The wind takes energy from molecules near the surface and so decreases the rate of

What happens to the gas molecules during this pressure increase?

A The average kinetic energy of the molecules increases.

B The average separation of the molecules decreases.

C The average separation of the molecules increases.

D The volume of each molecule increases.

The diagram shows a simple mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/c568d6fc-2a7b-483e-9b7e-3e42d7d9a4ca.png)

The atmospheric pressure increases.

Which distance increases?

A VW

B WY

C \( X Y \)

D \( X Z \)

The diagram shows three vases each with the same base area. Each vase contains water of the
 same depth.

![diagram](./assets/342da7fe-7bce-4e54-a284-0e70eef8778b.png)

Which statement about the water pressures at points \( P, Q \) and \( R \) is correct?

A The pressure at point \( P \) is the greatest.

B The pressure at point \( Q \) is the least.

C The pressure at point \( R \) is the greatest.

D The pressures at points \( P, Q \) and \( R \) are the same.

A skier walks from the bottom of a ski slope to the top and gains \( 10000 \mathrm{~J} \) of gravitational potential
 energy.

She skis down the slope. At the bottom of the slope, her kinetic energy is \( 2000 \mathrm{~J} \).

![diagram](./assets/2431b467-34dc-480e-9368-73ade104f975.png)

How much energy is dissipated in overcoming friction and air resistance as the skier moves down
 the slope?

A \( 2000 \mathrm{~J} \)

B \( 8000 \mathrm{~J} \)

C \( 10000 \mathrm{~J} \)

D \( 12000 \mathrm{~J} \)

The diagram shows an object of weight \( W \) and an object of weight \( Z \) balanced on a uniform metre
 rule.

![diagram](./assets/561dc88d-861b-48ad-b761-9f92934790dd.png)

Which equation relating to \( W, Z, a \) and \( b \) is correct?

A \( \frac{W}{a}=\frac{Z}{b} \)

B \( W \times Z=a \times b \)

C \( W \times a=Z \times b \)

D \( W \times(a+b)=Z \)

An object has a mass of \( 50 \mathrm{~kg} \).

The gravitational field strength on Earth is \( 10.0 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{kg} \).

The gravitational field strength on a distant planet is \( 4.0 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{kg} \).

What is the weight of the object on Earth, and what is its weight on the distant planet?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & on Earth & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { on the distant } \\
\text { planet }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & \( 5.0 \mathrm{~kg} \) & \( 12.5 \mathrm{~kg} \) \\
B & \( 5.0 \mathrm{~N} \) & \( 12.5 \mathrm{~N} \) \\
C & \( 500 \mathrm{~kg} \) & \( 200 \mathrm{~kg} \) \\
D & \( 500 \mathrm{~N} \) & \( 200 \mathrm{~N} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Two runners take part in a race.

The graph shows how the speed of each runner changes with time.

![diagram](./assets/df5dc4fb-e804-4609-818e-a3b337a9da1f.png)

What does the graph show about the runners at time \( t \) ?

A Both runners are moving at the same speed.

B Runner 1 has zero acceleration.

C Runner 1 is overtaking runner 2.

D Runner 2 is slowing down.

The diagram shows an enlarged drawing of the end of a metre rule. It is being used to measure
 the length of a small feather.

![diagram](./assets/392f05db-1a7a-44e3-bf7e-65e5e447964e.png)

![diagram](./assets/85292c7f-9df7-4b46-9ae9-a5371704f7d3.png)

What is the length of the feather?

A \( 19 \mathrm{~mm} \)

B \( 29 \mathrm{~mm} \)

C \( 19 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 29 \mathrm{~cm} \)

A beam of cathode rays passes between two parallel metal plates connected to a high-voltage
 d.c. power supply.

Which path does the beam follow?

![diagram](./assets/3bb8d3fb-edda-4383-ab63-937e5ead5953.png)

A magnet is suspended from a spring so that it can move freely inside a coil. The coil is
 connected to a sensitive centre-zero ammeter.

![diagram](./assets/22658d4b-90e1-4600-8832-b7c996092bdc.png)

What does the ammeter show when the magnet repeatedly moves slowly up and down?

A a reading constantly changing from left to right and right to left

B a steady reading to the left

C a steady reading to the right

D a steady reading of zero

Which graph shows how the output voltage varies with time for a simple a.c. generator?

![diagram](./assets/47210b1c-d850-4600-b742-f6cc1aae25bb.png)

B

![diagram](./assets/43d11f40-c1f8-4b1b-ac02-f606dbb5effa.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/ed45d5a2-7e67-40b3-8637-cd2a9303071c.png)

![diagram](./assets/a5768eb3-004b-4f40-99af-eae44a6e329d.png)

In this circuit, a component at \( X \) automatically protects the wiring from overheating if there is a
 fault.

electrical supply

![diagram](./assets/c475e398-1f95-4da3-a9ee-522353fba670.png)

Which components are suitable to use at \( \mathrm{X} \) ?

A a circuit-breaker, a fuse or a switch

B only a circuit-breaker or a fuse

C only a circuit-breaker or a switch

D only a fuse

Which circuit includes a capacitor and what does the capacitor do in this circuit?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & circuit & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { what the } \\
\text { capacitor does }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & potential divider & stores current \\
B & potential divider & stores energy \\
C & time delay & stores current \\
D & time delay & stores energy \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which test could be used to find which end of a magnet is the north pole?

A putting it near a compass needle

B putting it near a ferrous metal

C putting it near a non-ferrous metal

D putting it near a steel spoon

A student listens to a machine that makes sounds of different frequencies. He can only hear one
 of the sounds.

Which frequency of sound is the student able to hear?

A \( 2 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

B \( 10 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

C \( 2 \mathrm{kHz} \)

D \( 30 \mathrm{kHz} \)

An ice cube at a temperature of \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is put into a drink at a temperature of \( 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \).

After a short time, some of the ice has melted and the drink has cooled to a temperature of \( 8^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \).

What is the temperature of the remaining ice?

A \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

B \( \quad 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

C \( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

D \( 8^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

The diagram shows two mercury barometers.

Barometer 1 is measuring atmospheric pressure on day 1.

Barometer 2 is measuring atmospheric pressure on day 2.

![diagram](./assets/2c7e7779-c6f1-4852-b0a4-900acd7b4b09.png)

Which statement is true?

A The atmospheric pressure on day 1 is less than the atmospheric pressure on day 2.

B The atmospheric pressure on day 1 is the same as the atmospheric pressure on day 2.

C The pressure at point \( X \) is less than the pressure at point \( Y \).

D The pressure at point \( \mathrm{X} \) is the same as the pressure at point \( Y \).

A brick with flat, rectangular sides rests on a table.

![diagram](./assets/d476e02c-e9a3-4132-90ca-a89d879d15d8.png)

The brick is now turned so that it rests on the table on its smallest face.

![diagram](./assets/8b408956-c035-4aeb-a4a9-62f0d50e683c.png)

How has this affected the force and the pressure exerted by the brick on the table?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & force & pressure \\
\hline A & increased & increased \\
B & increased & unchanged \\
C & unchanged & increased \\
D & unchanged & unchanged \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Objects with different masses are hung on a spring. The diagram shows how much the spring
 stretches.

![diagram](./assets/5378946c-9873-4e7a-bd09-d1d7bd473cfd.png)

The extension of the spring is directly proportional to the mass hung on it.

What is the mass of object M?

A \( 110 \mathrm{~g} \)

B \( \quad 150 \mathrm{~g} \)

C \( 200 \mathrm{~g} \)

D \( 300 \mathrm{~g} \)

A cube of side \( 2.0 \mathrm{~cm} \) is placed on a balance.

![diagram](./assets/5181a719-dcae-4b24-bbcc-6727e49b325d.png)

What is the density of the cube?

A \( \quad 0.90 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

B \( \quad 1.2 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

C \( 1.8 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

D \( \quad 3.6 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

The diagram shows a balance being used to find the weight of a baby. The weight of the basket
 can be ignored.

At equilibrium, the pivot is nearer to the weight \( W \) than to the baby.

![diagram](./assets/168e924a-d68b-43dc-bad0-34ab41d9b10a.png)

What is the weight of the baby?

A less than \( W \)

B more than \( W \)

C \( W \)

D impossible to tell

How many neutrons and how many protons are contained in a nucleus of \( { }_{92}^{238} \mathrm{U} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & neutrons & protons \\
\hline A & 92 & 146 \\
B & 146 & 92 \\
C & 146 & 238 \\
D & 238 & 92 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What are suitable numbers of turns for the primary coil and for the secondary coil?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\hline A & 100 & 1000 \\
B & 200 & 110 \\
C & 400 & 490 \\

A pupil measures the potential difference across a device and the current in it.

Which calculation gives the resistance of the device?

A current \( + \) potential difference

B current \( \div \) potential difference

C potential difference \( \div \) current

D potential difference \( \times \) current

An object \( O \) is placed in front of a converging lens of focal length \( f \).

At which point will the top of the image be seen?

A

![diagram](./assets/e65f73b9-921d-4bd8-b07a-301e9b0e7ec5.png)

A ray of light in glass is incident on a boundary with air.

Which path does the ray of light take when the angle of incidence \( i \) is less than the critical angle?

![diagram](./assets/b8b0d284-f388-46a7-b5a0-e66c1c8163fd.png)

The drawing shows a wave.

Which labelled distance is the wavelength?

![diagram](./assets/67d342aa-64cd-421e-8cac-bfb744989444.png)

![diagram](./assets/6dee1d0e-4288-41ee-9e4f-291ca581558b.png)

How could a convection current be set up in the water?

A cool the water at \( X \)

B cool the water at \( Y \)

C stir the water at \( \mathrm{X} \)

D stir the water at \( Y \)

The table gives the melting points and boiling points of glycerine and benzene.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & melting point & boiling point \\
\hline glycerine & \( 18^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) & \( 290^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) \\
benzene & \( 5.4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) & \( 80^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

At which temperature will both glycerine and benzene be liquid?

A \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

B \( 50^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

C \( 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

body:
To mark a temperature scale on a thermometer, standard temperatures known as fixed points are
 needed.

Which of these is a fixed point?

A room temperature

B the temperature inside a freezer

C the temperature of pure melting ice

D the temperature of pure warm water

Brownian motion is observed by looking at smoke particles through a microscope.

How do the smoke particles move in Brownian motion?

A all in the same direction

B at random

C in circles

D vibrating about fixed points

The diagram shows a microphone being used in an interview.

![diagram](./assets/d6d3d05d-d88d-450d-bff8-5cc106f6a400.png)

microphone

![diagram](./assets/dc282a40-daa0-47da-bc66-64594d5434dc.png)

Which energy change takes place in the microphone?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & input energy & output energy \\
\hline A & chemical & electrical \\
B & electrical & chemical \\
C & electrical & sound \\
D & sound & electrical \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A car accelerates from traffic lights. The graph shows the car's speed plotted against time.

![diagram](./assets/70865abd-b96d-436d-872d-a79a648c820d.png)

How far does the car travel before it reaches a constant speed?

A \( 10 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 20 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 100 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 200 \mathrm{~m} \)

The nucleus of a neutral atom of lithium is represented by \( { }_{3}^{7} \mathrm{Li} \).

How many protons, electrons and neutrons does the atom contain?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & protons & electrons & neutrons \\
\hline A & 7 & 7 & 3 \\
B & 3 & 7 & 3 \\
C & 3 & 4 & 4 \\
D & 3 & 3 & 4 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

![diagram](./assets/421a04fd-b18e-44e4-8ed0-15401fb62e6e.png)

What are suitable numbers of turns for coil \( X \) and for coil \( Y \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\text { on coil } X\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { number of turns } \\

When a plastic comb is placed next to a small piece of aluminium foil hanging from a nylon
 thread, the foil is repelled by the comb.

Why is this?

A The comb is charged and the foil is uncharged.

B The comb is uncharged and the foil is charged.

C The comb and the foil have charge of opposite signs.

D The comb and the foil have charge of the same sign.

A student investigates which end of a magnetic compass needle is attracted to a bar magnet.

What does the investigation show?

A Both ends of the compass needle are attracted by the north pole of the magnet.

B Both ends of the compass needle are attracted by the south pole of the magnet.

C One end of the compass needle is attracted by the north pole and the other end by the south
 pole.

D The compass needle is not attracted by either end of the magnet.

The diagram shows a man standing at \( X \) who shouts to a man standing at \( Y \).

![diagram](./assets/440e9937-b5fd-4294-ab88-8ff1eafc68f7.png)

The man's voice will be heard sooner and more clearly if the wind is blowing towards the

A north.

B south.

C east.

D west.

Water waves travel more slowly in shallow water than in deep water.

Which diagram shows what will happen to plane waves in deep water when they enter shallow
 water?

![diagram](./assets/aedc2462-61b2-4f97-bd44-435062316cbe.png)

![diagram](./assets/651d0fb9-83ca-4f82-ba23-fff34ea15a04.png)

\( \mathrm{C} \)

D

A beaker contains water at room temperature.

![diagram](./assets/c2446878-7611-45a5-bda2-60a1d1a3a754.png)

How could a convection current be set up in the water?

A cool the water at \( \mathrm{X} \)

B cool the water at \( Y \)

C stir the water at \( \mathrm{X} \)

D stir the water at \( Y \)

A long thin bar of copper is heated evenly along its length.

![diagram](./assets/6b72a572-6650-4262-b860-1cc7a8f01dbc.png)

copper bar

What happens to the bar?

A It becomes lighter.

B It becomes longer.

C It becomes shorter.

D It bends at the ends.

A manometer is being used to measure the pressure of the gas inside a tank. \( \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C} \) and \( \mathbf{D} \)
 show the manometer at different times.

At which time is the gas pressure inside the tank greatest?

gas

![diagram](./assets/fb3c84ae-2c60-417e-a397-e700ec6b3f31.png)

A particular nuclide of chlorine can be represented by the symbol shown.

How many electrons are there in a neutral atom of this nuclide?

A 17

B 20

C 37

D 54

A beam of cathode rays passes between two parallel metal plates connected to a high-voltage
 d.c. power supply.

Which path does the beam follow?

![diagram](./assets/646c358a-c7a3-4008-a121-76c73f6d059d.png)

A transformer has 100 turns on its primary coil and 25 turns on its secondary coil. The primary
 coil is connected to a \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) a.c. supply.

![diagram](./assets/a4dbd117-7d57-43da-b962-38a9e5a96b37.png)

What is the voltage induced across the secondary coil?

A \( 3.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

B \( 4.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

C \( 48 \mathrm{~V} \)

D \( 300 \mathrm{~V} \)

The diagram shows a lamp and a resistor connected in a circuit. The lamp is too bright.

![diagram](./assets/92b3020a-fc2c-4f16-a25f-9a698f9da6b6.png)

Which change to the circuit will decrease the current in the lamp and make it less bright?

A connecting another resistor in parallel with the one in the circuit

B connecting another resistor in series with the one in the circuit

C exchanging the positions of the lamp and the resistor in the circuit

D increasing the e.m.f. of the battery in the circuit

Which quantities is a voltmeter used to measure?

A current and e.m.f. only

B current and p.d. only

C e.m.f. and p.d. only

D e.m.f., current and p.d

Two balloons, \( X \) and \( Y \), are suspended by insulating threads. They are each held near a
 negatively charged balloon. The balloons hang as shown.

![diagram](./assets/0700910e-c0ba-4c43-8f87-125cc22aa54a.png)

What is the charge on balloon \( X \) and what is the charge on balloon \( Y \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & balloon \( X \) & balloon \( Y \) \\
\hline A & negative & negative \\
B & negative & positive \\
C & positive & negative \\
D & positive & positive \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagrams show the wave patterns of four sounds shown on a cathode-ray oscilloscope
 (c.r.o.). The oscilloscope controls are set the same for each sound.

Which sound has the highest pitch?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/19477c47-c143-4791-b716-80cfd519c6c4.png)

C

A boy wears a shirt with a letter \( F \) on the front. He stands in front of a plane mirror.

![diagram](./assets/788a9aa4-b7c2-4bed-91fb-f0d4634f2f91.png)

What does he see in the mirror?

A

B

C

D

\( \square \) \( \square \)

![diagram](./assets/e9648248-a704-4b6a-bed1-ca91110c1e48.png)

Which statement about thermal radiation is correct?

A It can only occur in a vacuum.

B It involves movement of electrons through a material.

C It involves movement of atoms.

D It is infra-red radiation.

Which equation can be used to calculate the resistance \( R \) of a resistor?

A \( \quad V=I \div R \)

B \( I=V \times R \)

C \( R=V \times I \)

D \( V=I \times R \)

When the volcano Krakatoa erupted in 1883 , it was heard \( 5000 \mathrm{~km} \) away.

Which statement about the sound from the volcano is not correct?

A If such a loud sound were to be made today, an astronaut orbiting in space (a vacuum) at a
 height of \( 400 \mathrm{~km} \) could hear it.

B People further from the volcano heard the sound later than people nearer to the volcano.

C The amplitude of the sound waves would have been smaller further from the volcano.

D The sound was very loud because a lot of energy was transferred to vibrations of the air.

The diagram shows a ray of light passing through a semicircular glass block into air.

![diagram](./assets/0bd73a95-6628-4780-91d5-5680d4ced76d.png)

Which row gives the correct name for angle \( \mathrm{P} \) and states how angle \( \mathrm{P} \) compares with the critical
 angle?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & name of angle \( P \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { angle } P \text { compared with } \\
\text { the critical angle }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & angle of incidence & larger than the critical angle \\
B & angle of incidence & smaller than the critical angle \\
C & angle of refraction & larger than the critical angle \\
D & angle of refraction & smaller than the critical angle \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which row shows an example of a transverse wave and an example of a longitudinal wave?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & transverse & longitudinal \\
\hline A & light & radio \\
B & radio & sound \\
C & sound & water \\
D & water & light \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A rod is made half of glass and half of copper. Four pins, \( \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C} \) and \( \mathbf{D} \) are attached to the rod
 by wax. The rod is heated in the centre as shown.

Which pin falls off first?

![diagram](./assets/72b5e197-02c5-45e5-9282-e2c2729e18af.png)

The nucleus of an americium atom contains 146 neutrons and 95 protons. It decays by emitting
 an \( \alpha \)-particle.


How many neutrons and how many protons remain in the nucleus when this form of americium
 decays?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { number of neutrons } \\
\text { remaining }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { number of protons } \\
\text { remaining }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & 142 & 93 \\
B & 142 & 95 \\
C & 144 & 93 \\
D & 144 & 95 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a cathode-ray tube.

![diagram](./assets/cdbb8d45-2336-4ab1-b343-5520a17e5f77.png)

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & heated electrode & positive electrode \\
\hline A & anode & anode \\
B & anode & cathode \\
C & cathode & anode \\
D & cathode & cathode \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

In the circuit shown, only one of the fuses has blown, but none of the lamps is lit.

Which fuse has blown?

![diagram](./assets/18f65ab0-6046-4f46-a67f-916a5779a211.png)

Which action will demagnetise a magnetised piece of steel?

A Cool it in a freezer for several hours.

B Hit it repeatedly with a hammer.

C Put it in a coil carrying a direct current (d.c.).

D Put it near an unmagnetised piece of iron.

Which diagram shows how the light from a candle is reflected by a mirror, and shows the position
 of the image formed?

![diagram](./assets/6ff187a0-8124-44e6-9ca7-724705767c69.png)

The diagrams represent water waves in a tank.

Which diagram represents a wave that changes speed?

![diagram](./assets/f505ee93-be25-4cf4-9dd7-c14fe034058d.png)

![diagram](./assets/839b50d7-fe3e-44ae-94e2-c727f59b2901.png)

D

![diagram](./assets/ddd94bab-e752-45a5-8727-33267d3a3ba3.png)

The extension-load graph for a spring is shown. The unstretched length of the spring is \( 17.0 \mathrm{~cm} \).

![diagram](./assets/7121d413-0a4a-4641-9e5d-2bc038a67c10.png)

When an object is hung from the spring, the length of the spring is \( 19.2 \mathrm{~cm} \).

What is the weight of the object?

A \( 1.4 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( \quad 1.6 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 2.6 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 3.0 \mathrm{~N} \)

The diagram shows the paths of three different types of radiation, \( X, Y \) and \( Z \).

![diagram](./assets/cf7dbae2-1f5f-4ff6-bbfc-ff35b4e8bf20.png)

Which row in the table correctly identifies \( \mathrm{X}, \mathrm{Y} \) and \( \mathrm{Z} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \mathbf{X} \) & \( \mathbf{Y} \) & \( \mathbf{Z} \) \\
\hline A & \( \alpha \)-particles & \( \beta \)-particles & \( \gamma \)-rays \\
B & \( \beta \)-particles & \( \alpha \)-particles & \( \gamma \)-rays \\
