body:
The diagram shows a coil connected to a battery and a switch. Two unmagnetised iron bars hang
 freely near opposite ends of the coil.

![diagram](./assets/8cf30baa-ef6e-42cb-b18e-ddc115a66a58.png)

![diagram](./assets/ef781da1-d185-4c7a-a7b9-ffaa653c3bf9.png)

What happens to the iron bars when the switch is closed?

A Both \( X \) and \( Y \) move away from the coil.

B Both \( X \) and \( Y \) move towards the coil.

C \( X \) moves towards the coil, \( Y \) moves away from the coil.

D \( Y \) moves towards the coil, \( X \) moves away from the coil.

The circuit shown in the diagram contains an unknown component \( X \), hidden in a box.

The voltage-current graph for \( X \) is as shown.

variable voltage supply

![diagram](./assets/376d776a-3958-465e-bb24-e31c2580c637.png)

![diagram](./assets/b486038a-36ff-4874-92d6-bd35e6bac443.png)

What is the component \( X \) ?

A a capacitor

B a closed switch

C an open switch

D a resistor of constant resistance

A girl stands at a distance from a large building. She claps her hands and a short time later hears
 an echo.

Why is an echo produced when the sound waves hit the building?

A The sound waves are absorbed.

B The sound waves are diffracted.

C The sound waves are reflected.

D The sound waves are refracted.

An object on a thread is swinging between \( X \) and \( Z \), as shown in the diagram. It is momentarily at
 rest at \( \mathrm{X} \) and at \( \mathrm{Z} \).

![diagram](./assets/6002182d-1a3d-4a97-9fe4-57af5d6e803b.png)

An incomplete word equation about the energy of the object is shown below.

gravitational potential energy \( = \) kinetic energy \( +\ldots \ldots \). energy \( + \) energy losses
 at \( X \quad \) at \( Y \quad \) at \( Y \)

Which form of energy is needed to complete the word equation?

A chemical

B gravitational potential

C internal

D strain

In which pair of energy sources are both sources renewable?

A oil and coal

B oil and tidal

C tidal and geothermal

D tidal and nuclear fission

A stone has a volume of \( 0.50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \) and a mass of \( 2.0 \mathrm{~g} \).

What is the density of the stone?

A \( \quad 0.25 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

B \( 1.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

C \( 2.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

D \( 4.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

In a race, a car travels 60 times around a \( 3.6 \mathrm{~km} \) track. This takes \( 2.4 \) hours.

What is the average speed of the car?

A \( 1.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

B \( 90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

C \( 144 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

D \( 216 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

In a cathode-ray tube, a hot tungsten cathode releases particles by thermionic emission.

What are these particles?

A \( \alpha \)-particles

B electrons

C protons

D tungsten atoms
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
Two methods by which thermal energy can be transferred are conduction and radiation.

Which statement is correct?

A Conduction involves density changes in fluids.

B Conduction only occurs in solids.

C Radiation cannot occur in a vacuum.

D Radiation involves electromagnetic waves.

The weight of an object is found using the balance shown in the diagram. The object is put in the
 left-hand pan and various weights are put in the right-hand pan.

![diagram](./assets/d7665e07-393f-49f9-8b8d-1e9e95aaefd5.png)

These are the results.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline weights in the right-hand pan & effect \\
\hline \( 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.05 \mathrm{~N}, 0.02 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the left-hand side \\
\hline \( 0.2 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.01 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the right-hand side \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What is the best estimate of the weight of the object?

A \( 0.27 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( 0.29 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 0.31 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 0.58 \mathrm{~N} \)

An electric current can produce a heating effect and a magnetic effect.

Which row shows the effect that a relay uses and one application of a relay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & effect used by a relay & one application of a relay \\
\hline A & heating effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
B & heating effect & changing the voltage of an a.c. supply \\
C & magnetic effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
D & magnetic effect & changing the voltage of an a.c. supply \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which property of a sound wave affects the loudness of the sound?

A amplitude

B frequency

C speed

D wavelength

A girl notices that, when she shouts into a cave, she hears an echo.

Which wave property causes the echo?

A diffraction

B dispersion

C reflection

D refraction

Which part of the electromagnetic spectrum is used to send television signals from a satellite to
 Earth?

A infra-red

B microwaves

C ultraviolet

D visible light

The diagram shows light passing from air into glass. Two angles \( p \) and \( q \) are marked.

![diagram](./assets/88623596-ecdb-4086-b361-4db95210c180.png)

Which pair of equations can both be used to calculate the refractive index \( n \) of the glass?

A \( \mathrm{n}=\frac{\text { speed of light in air }}{\text { speed of light in glass }}, \quad n=\frac{\sin p}{\sin \mathrm{q}} \)

B \( \mathrm{n}=\frac{\text { speed of light in glass }}{\text { speed of light in air }}, \quad \mathrm{n}=\frac{\sin \mathrm{p}}{\sin \mathrm{q}} \)

C \( \mathrm{n}=\frac{\text { speed of light in air }}{\text { speed of light in glass }}, \quad \mathrm{n}=\frac{\sin \mathrm{q}}{\sin \mathrm{p}} \)

D \( \mathrm{n}=\frac{\text { speed of light in glass }}{\text { speed of light in air }}, \quad \mathrm{n}=\frac{\sin \mathrm{q}}{\sin \mathrm{p}} \)

The diagrams show a spring and a graph of the length of the spring against the load applied to it.

![diagram](./assets/d588c246-40a7-441a-8899-fdcc237cfa23.png)

What is the extension of the spring when a load of \( 40 \mathrm{~N} \) is applied to it?

A \( 1.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 2.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 4.0 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 6.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)

An object travels in a circular path at constant speed.

Which statement about the object is correct?

A It has changing kinetic energy.

B It has changing momentum.

C It has constant velocity.

D It is not accelerating.

Which statement is correct?

A The acceleration in the first \( 5 \mathrm{~s} \) is given by area \( P \).

B The acceleration increases between \( \mathrm{W} \) and \( X \).

C The acceleration is negative between \( Y \) and \( Z \).

D The deceleration between \( Y \) and \( Z \) is \( (20 \div 25) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \).

![diagram](./assets/e7404608-d01a-49e1-9c60-19dec1386ac1.png)

Which row describes the speed of the vehicle in each section of the graph?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & P to \( Q \) & Q to \( R \) & \( R \) to \( S \) \\
\hline A & constant & zero & constant \\
B & constant & zero & decreasing \\
C & increasing & constant & decreasing \\
D & increasing & zero & constant \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The half-life of a radioactive nuclide is \( 2.0 \) hours.

The decay rate of a sample of this nuclide is measured at \( 1.0 \) hour intervals. The table shows the
 measurements, with one value shown as \( X \).

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \( \begin{array}{c}\text { time } / \\
\text { hours }\end{array} \) & \( \frac{\text { decay rate }}{\text { decays } / \mathrm{s}} \) \\
\hline 0 & 240 \\
\( 1.0 \) & 170 \\
\( 2.0 \) & 120 \\
\( 3.0 \) & 85 \\
\( 4.0 \) & \( \mathrm{X} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A 15

D 60

empty box

\end{tabular}

C & the same as at the flat end & greater than at the flat end \\
D & the same as at the flat end & less than at the flat end \\

\end{tabular}

![diagram](./assets/9b038fd6-e605-4a4c-ae0c-d64c69d6cb9b.png)

A cup contains hot liquid.

Some of the liquid evaporates.

What happens to the mass and to the weight of the liquid in the cup?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & mass & weight \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & stays the same \\
C & stays the same & decreases \\
D & stays the same & stays the same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

For which part of the graph is the train's speed changing at the greatest rate?

How can the turning effect be increased?

A Increase the number of turns on the coil.

 supply of \( 25 \mathrm{~V} \).

![diagram](./assets/47befef4-458e-4cc9-9cbc-0933f61d1753.png)

A 25

A moving the coil to the right

B moving both the magnet and the coil to the left at the same speed

A plastic rod is rubbed with a cotton cloth. This process causes the rod and the cloth to become
 charged. These charges cause a force between the rod and the cloth.

\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { charges on rod } \\
\text { and cloth }\end{array} \) & effect \\

C & the same & they attract \\
D & the same & they repel \\

\end{tabular}

 substance Q. Total internal reflection occurs at the boundary.

\hline
\end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

100 & \( 26.0 \) \\

B \( 13.0 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 14.0 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 16.0 \mathrm{~cm} \)

Which quantity decreases?

A its density

B its diameter

C its thickness

D its volume

The density of the water decreases when its temperature increases.

Which combination of depth and temperature produces the greatest water pressure?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & depth \( / \mathrm{m} \) & temperature \( /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) \\
\hline A & 10 & 5 \\
B & 10 & 15 \\

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & battery & solar cell \\
\hline A & chemical to electrical & electrical to light \\

\end{tabular}

What is the weight of an object?

A the force of gravity on the object

B the gravitational potential energy of the object

What are the products of these two types of radioactive emission?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\hline A & a nucleus of a different element & a nucleus of a different element \\

C & a nucleus of the same element & a nucleus of a different element \\
D & a nucleus of the same element & a nucleus of the same element \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

body:
A certain element has several isotopes.

Which statement about these isotopes is correct?

A They must have different numbers of electrons orbiting their nuclei.

B They must have the same number of neutrons in their nuclei.

C They must have the same number of nucleons in their nuclei.

D They must have the same number of protons in their nuclei.

 circuit.

\hline & position & operation \\
\hline A & live wire & disconnects the circuit \\

C & neutral wire & disconnects the circuit \\
D & neutral wire & reduces the current to \( 30 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

![diagram](./assets/33879e38-06f6-409d-af16-9d51f7efa0bc.png)

In the evening it gets dark.

 potential difference (p.d.) across it?

\hline & resistance of LDR & p.d. across LDR \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\

\end{tabular}

 liquid is recorded every half minute. The table shows the results.

\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline /minutes & \( 0.0 \) & \( 0.5 \) & \( 1.0 \) & \( 1.5 \) & \( 2.0 \) & \( 2.5 \) & \( 3.0 \) & \( 3.5 \) & \( 4.0 \) & \( 4.5 \) & \( 5.0 \) & \( 5.5 \) & \( 6.0 \) & \( 6.5 \) & \( 7.0 \) & \( 7.5 \) \\
\hline perature \( /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) & 73 & 65 & 59 & 55 & 55 & 55 & 51 & 48 & 45 & 42 & 40 & 38 & 36 & 35 & 34 & 33 \\

What is the melting point of the substance?

A \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

body:

C \( 72 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 90 \mathrm{~cm} \)

Radio waves are received at a house at the bottom of a hill.

![diagram](./assets/a98a006d-7a80-43f3-b75c-dac64204cc64.png)

The waves reach the house because the hill has caused them to be

A diffracted.

B radiated.

C reflected.

D refracted.

The same quantity of thermal energy is supplied to two solid objects \( X \) and \( Y \). The temperature
 increase of object \( X \) is greater than the temperature increase of object \( Y \).

Which statement explains this?

A \( \mathrm{X} \) has a lower melting point than \( \mathrm{Y} \).

B \( X \) has a lower density than \( Y \).

C \( X \) has a lower thermal capacity than \( \mathrm{Y} \).

D \( \mathrm{X} \) is a better thermal conductor than \( \mathrm{Y} \).

A cup contains hot liquid.

Some of the liquid evaporates.

What happens to the mass and what happens to the weight of the liquid in the cup?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & mass & weight \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & stays the same \\
C & stays the same & decreases \\
D & stays the same & stays the same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A student sets up the circuit shown. The switch is open (off).

![diagram](./assets/c382a64a-6ed5-481c-9abe-e3d79bc4f983.png)

Which lamps are on and which lamps are off?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & lamp X & lamp \( Y \) & lamp \( Z \) \\
\hline A & off & off & off \\
B & on & off & off \\
C & on & off & on \\
D & on & on & on \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A polythene rod repels an inflated balloon hanging from a nylon thread.

What charges must the rod and the balloon carry?

A The rod and the balloon carry opposite charges.

B The rod and the balloon carry like charges.

C The rod is charged but the balloon is not.

D The balloon is charged but the rod is not.

A thin converging lens is used to produce, on a screen, a focused image of a candle.

![diagram](./assets/a8fc6ffb-a67b-4180-bc77-574d3a93fb26.png)

Various focused images are produced on the screen by moving the lens and the screen
 backwards and forwards.

Which statement is always correct?

A The image is at the principal focus (focal point) of the lens.

B The image is bigger than the object.

C The image is closer to the lens than the object is.

D The image is inverted.

Water waves can be used to show reflection, refraction and diffraction.

For each of these, which row shows whether or not the speed of the water waves changes?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & reflection & refraction & diffraction \\
\hline A & no & no & yes \\
B & no & yes & no \\
C & yes & no & no \\
D & yes & yes & yes \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a thermometer calibrated in degrees Celsius.

![diagram](./assets/062812b3-ff47-4256-bbef-1ae1ef145ed6.png)

What are the values of the lower fixed point and of the upper fixed point on the Celsius scale?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { lower fixed } \\
\text { point } /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { upper fixed } \\
\text { point } /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & \( -10 \) & 110 \\
B & 0 & 20 \\
C & 0 & 100 \\
D & 20 & 100 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A sealed gas cylinder is left outside on a hot, sunny day.

What happens to the average speed of the molecules and to the pressure of the gas in the
 cylinder as the temperature rises?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { average speed of } \\
\text { the gas molecules }\end{array} \) & gas pressure \\
\hline A & falls & falls \\
B & falls & rises \\
C & rises & falls \\
D & rises & rises \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which energy resource is used to generate electricity by first boiling water?

A hydroelectric

B nuclear fission

C tides

D waves

The diagram shows the paths of three different types of radiation, \( X, Y \) and \( Z \).

![diagram](./assets/a5168d5c-7967-4760-98e7-3a73d222ac23.png)

Which row in the table correctly identifies \( \mathrm{X}, \mathrm{Y} \) and \( \mathrm{Z} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \mathbf{X} \) & \( \mathbf{Y} \) & \( \mathbf{Z} \) \\
\hline A & \( \alpha \)-particles & \( \beta \)-particles & \( \gamma \)-rays \\
B & \( \beta \)-particles & \( \alpha \)-particles & \( \gamma \)-rays \\
C & \( \beta \)-particles & \( \gamma \)-rays & \( \alpha \)-particles \\
D & \( \gamma \)-rays & \( \alpha \)-particles & \( \beta \)-particles \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Question 40 is on the next page.
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
Which statement explains the meaning of the half-life of a radioactive substance?

A half the time taken for half the substance to decay

B half the time taken for the substance to decay completely

C the time taken for half the substance to decay

D the time taken for the substance to decay completely

To create cathode rays in a vacuum, what might be a suitable potential difference to connect
 between the cathode and anode?

A \( 6 \mathrm{~V} \) a.c.

B \( 6 \vee \) d.c.

C \( 600 \mathrm{~V} \) a.c.

D \( 600 \mathrm{~V} \) d.c.

Which device is designed to allow a small direct current (d.c.) to control a large direct current
 (d.c.)?

A a generator

B a motor

C a relay

D a transformer

The diagram shows a battery connected to two identical resistors. Three ammeters \( M_{1}, M_{2} \) and
 \( \mathrm{M}_{3} \) are connected in the circuit.

![diagram](./assets/22d5b15f-1b17-4396-89de-0a598374592e.png)

Meter \( M_{1} \) reads \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \).

What are the readings on \( M_{2} \) and on \( M_{3} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & reading on \( \mathrm{M}_{2} \) /A & reading on \( \mathrm{M}_{3} / \mathrm{A} \) \\
\hline A & \( 0.5 \) & \( 0.0 \) \\
B & \( 0.5 \) & \( 0.5 \) \\
C & \( 0.5 \) & \( 1.0 \) \\
D & \( 1.0 \) & \( 1.0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Four plotting compasses are placed in the magnetic field of two identical bar magnets as shown
 in the diagram.

Which compass is shown pointing in the wrong direction?

![diagram](./assets/299ab918-f3a7-4cf4-8c45-43fd9f23a901.png)

![diagram](./assets/c9be88f1-bd0c-4258-935d-b9fcaa3bcfed.png)

![diagram](./assets/92370d99-ab16-42a5-95d6-24bc1153af3b.png)

![diagram](./assets/e5a54402-3a13-444b-ab48-7c02fd8ebcb3.png)

![diagram](./assets/b6a7bf79-b924-47eb-b25c-f4ec9a2bc0f4.png)

A permanent magnet is brought near to a piece of copper. The copper is not attracted by the
 magnet.

Why is there no attraction?

A Copper is ferrous but is only attracted by an electromagnet.

B Copper is ferrous but is not attracted by any type of magnet.

C Copper is not ferrous and is only attracted by an electromagnet.

D Copper is not ferrous and is not attracted by any type of magnet.

Astronaut 1 uses a hammer to mend a satellite in space. Astronaut 2 is nearby. There is no air in
 space.

![diagram](./assets/a159860e-aac7-4e5f-b5b5-d7766119117a.png)

Compared with the sound heard if they were working on Earth, what does astronaut 2 hear?

A a louder sound

B a quieter sound

C a sound of the same loudness

D no sound at all

Sound waves travel from a point \( X \) to another point \( Y \).

![diagram](./assets/98095e63-458d-44c7-86b9-e9c7bf598cc1.png)

Which diagram represents the movement of the air molecules, caused by the sound waves, in the
 region between \( \mathrm{X} \) and \( \mathrm{Y} \).

![diagram](./assets/080652a8-b8c6-4a1c-81ab-097aea575e99.png)

![diagram](./assets/ccbbef3f-9c57-4818-b8e3-c7f4390153a5.png)

\( \mathrm{D} \)

![diagram](./assets/fd69bc23-e56b-4d71-8c3d-e2fffd13ce8d.png)

A student warms her hands near a fire.

![diagram](./assets/94a77d2b-8b8c-4766-b7bb-e4decfc17d12.png)

![diagram](./assets/f4fcfaa6-5813-4dd1-ac86-759f0ba99e50.png)

Which waves carry most heat to her hands and are these waves electromagnetic?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & waves & electromagnetic \\
\hline A & infra-red & no \\
B & infra-red & yes \\
C & visible light & no \\
D & visible light & yes \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which property of a body can be measured in newtons?

A density

B mass

C volume

D weight

A ball is thrown upwards.

What effect does the force of gravity have on the ball?

A It produces a constant acceleration downwards.

B It produces a constant acceleration upwards.

C It produces a decreasing acceleration upwards.

D It produces an increasing acceleration downwards.

A stopwatch is used to time an athlete running \( 100 \mathrm{~m} \). The timekeeper forgets to reset the watch
 to zero before using it to time another athlete running \( 100 \mathrm{~m} \).

![diagram](./assets/eb5ac38f-0e1f-4288-955c-5d507584acd0.png)

![diagram](./assets/72351633-2e08-43b6-95fc-26d64b0f1a32.png)

stopwatch at

stopwatch at
 end of first
 end of second
 athlete's run
 athlete's run

How long does the second athlete take to run \( 100 \mathrm{~m} \) ?

A \( 11.2 \mathrm{~s} \)

B \( 11.4 \mathrm{~s} \)

C \( 12.4 \mathrm{~s} \)

D \( 23.8 \mathrm{~s} \)

A Geiger counter detects radiation from radioactive sources.

A radioactive source is inside a thick aluminium container as shown.

radioactive source

Geiger counter

thick aluminium container

A \( \alpha \)-particles

B \( \beta \)-particles

D radio waves

![diagram](./assets/9cf1aa6a-fbde-4cda-8724-d9c761851a71.png)

2nd particle

A atom 2

body:
An electric power tool is being used outdoors in a shower of rain.

What is the greatest hazard to the user?

A The cable gets hot and causes burns.

B The circuit-breaker cuts off the current.

C The current passes through water and causes a shock.

D The tool rusts.

Four resistors and an ammeter are connected to a battery as shown.

The ammeter reads \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \).

Which of the four labelled points in the circuit is the only one where the current is less than \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \) ?

![diagram](./assets/826478f1-dcfe-45c6-af3f-f8455876bbcc.png)

From which materials are the coil and the core of an electromagnet made?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & coil & core \\
\hline A & copper & copper \\
B & copper & iron \\
C & iron & copper \\
D & iron & iron \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Sounds are made by vibrating objects. A certain object vibrates but a person nearby cannot hear
 any sound.

Which statement might explain why nothing is heard?

A The amplitude of the sound waves is too large.

B The frequency of the vibration is too high.

C The sound waves are transverse.

D The speed of the sound waves is too high.

The diagram shows the image of a clock in a plane mirror.

![diagram](./assets/d72e83f5-fcc0-48a2-b55e-bd1ca2a5c343.png)

What time is shown?

A \( 02: 25 \)

B \( 02: 35 \)

C 09:25

D \( 09: 35 \)

Which is the best description of the speed of a water wave?

A the distance between one wave crest and the next

B the distance between the crest of a wave and a trough

C the distance that a particle of water moves up and down in one second

D the distance that a wavefront moves along the surface in one second

body:
Driving a car raises the temperature of the tyres.

This causes the pressure of the air in the tyres to increase.

Why is this?

A Air molecules break up to form separate atoms.

B Air molecules expand with the rise in temperature.

C The force between the air molecules increases.

D The speed of the air molecules increases.

Which form of energy do we receive directly from the Sun?

A chemical

B light

C nuclear

D sound

A measuring cylinder contains some water. When a stone is put in the water, the level rises.

![diagram](./assets/cfc3eb05-8ae4-4da2-9294-982ca5b3dc20.png)

![diagram](./assets/91638dc2-abc4-447e-a789-108455a25d36.png)

What is the volume of the stone?

A \( 50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

B \( 70 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

C \( 75 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

D \( 125 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

The diagram shows a box used for storing radioactive sources.

![diagram](./assets/5249ee43-5c82-46cf-9a43-1693b87ccfa8.png)

Which material is best for lining the box to prevent the escape of most radioactive emissions?

A aluminium

B copper

C lead

D steel

A steel magnet is placed inside a coil of wire. There is a large alternating current in the coil. The
 magnet is slowly moved out of the coil to position \( P \).

![diagram](./assets/3c239abe-8cb4-4249-b82b-f5ecd0cc7118.png)

steel magnet moved

out of coil

How has the steel changed, if at all, when it reaches position \( \mathrm{P} \) ?

A It has become a stronger magnet.

B It has become demagnetised.

C The poles have changed ends.

D There has been no change.

Rays of light enter and leave a box.

![diagram](./assets/0699862f-2f4c-459f-b4e8-839d36b3dde3.png)

What could be inside the box to make the rays behave as shown?

A a converging lens

B a parallel-sided glass block

C a plane mirror

D a triangular prism

A small boat in a harbour is protected from waves on the sea by harbour walls.

![diagram](./assets/e43b5359-c3ce-4208-846e-c51f7c3a8167.png)

Some waves can curve round the harbour walls and reach the boat.

What is the name of this effect?

A diffraction

B dispersion

C reflection

D refraction

Scout P signals to scout \( Q \) on the other side of a valley by using a mirror to reflect the Sun's rays.

![diagram](./assets/a70511d8-631c-464a-9085-b670c9e8d227.png)

Which mirror position would allow the Sun's rays to be reflected to scout Q?

![diagram](./assets/f9f36d78-8477-4bd0-a54d-1358af7ccc94.png)

The diagram shows a simple mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/61762070-d4a1-4ca3-898e-61fa24c89c97.png)

Atmospheric pressure decreases.

What happens to the level of the mercury at \( P \) and what happens to the level of the mercury at
 Q?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & P & Q \\
\hline A & falls & falls \\
B & falls & rises \\
C & rises & falls \\
D & rises & rises \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which object has the greatest density?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & mass \( / \mathrm{g} \) & volume \( / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \) \\
\hline A & \( 5.4 \) & \( 2.0 \) \\
B & 13 & \( 3.0 \) \\
C & 15 & \( 6.0 \) \\
D & 18 & \( 5.0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A car takes 15 minutes to travel along a road that is \( 20 \mathrm{~km} \) long.

What is the average speed of the car?

A \( \quad 0.75 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

B \( 5.0 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

C \( 80 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

D \( 300 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

Which distance/time graph represents the motion of an object moving at constant speed?

C

D

Two very light, charged balls \( P \) and \( Q \) are hung, one above the other, from nylon threads. When a
 negatively charged plastic sheet is placed alongside them, \( P \) is repelled and \( Q \) is attracted.

![diagram](./assets/892d9ade-9738-445a-afe6-5f61b59c19cf.png)

What are the original charges on \( \mathrm{P} \) and on \( \mathrm{Q} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\hline A & negative & negative \\
B & negative & positive \\
C & positive & negative \\
D & positive & positive \\

\end{tabular}

Waves travel more slowly on the surface of water when the water is shallow.

A person drops a stone into a pool at \( \mathbf{X} \). The diagram shows the first wavefront on the surface of
 the pool.

![diagram](./assets/43908f38-94e6-40df-8021-d935c9320d06.png)

The diagrams show four identical pieces of ice that are heated in test-tubes of water.

In which test-tube will the ice take the longest time to melt?

![diagram](./assets/693dac9e-8562-424c-b241-02c9206fa3d9.png)

![diagram](./assets/a17e423d-0f7f-4b11-88f4-7ec44782a4ab.png)

![diagram](./assets/1239cb5f-311f-4fe5-8925-2aa3ac4db0b9.png)

![diagram](./assets/ef0162d0-872f-4ed3-9b3f-2f01d6158666.png)

A gas to liquid

B liquid to gas

C liquid to solid

D solid to liquid

body:
Driving a car raises the temperature of the tyres.

This causes the pressure of the air in the tyres to increase.

Why is this?

A Air molecules break up to form separate atoms.

B Air molecules expand with the rise in temperature.

C The force between the air molecules increases.

D The speed of the air molecules increases.

A manometer is being used to measure the pressure of the gas inside a tank. \( \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C} \) and \( \mathbf{D} \)
 show the manometer at different times.

At which time is the gas pressure inside the tank greatest?

![diagram](./assets/aec41629-9b11-42fe-afa3-4cc15b4264bd.png)

![diagram](./assets/c477caa2-2e89-4fe9-bb5c-fd77c7995c66.png)

A large electric motor is used to lift a container off a ship.

Which of the following values are enough to allow the power of the motor to be calculated?

A the mass of the container and the distance moved

B the force used and the distance moved

C the current used and the work done

D the work done and the time taken

A student tries to find the density of a metal block. First he measures the weight with a
 forcemeter (spring balance). Next he measures the sides of the block using a rule, in order to
 calculate the volume of the block. Finally he divides the weight by the volume to find the density.

The student has made a mistake.

Why does his method not give the density?

A Density is volume divided by weight.

B He should have measured the surface area, not the volume.

C He should have used the mass in his calculation, not the weight.

D Weight is not measured with a forcemeter (spring balance).

Five telegraph poles are positioned at equal distances along the side of a road.

![diagram](./assets/523ae935-6e0f-4acc-bdef-acc49db94645.png)

A car accelerates until it is level with pole 4. The car then continues along the road at a steady
 speed. The times taken to travel between one pole and the next are measured.

Which time is the greatest?

The time between

A pole 1 and pole 2.

B pole 2 and pole 3.

C pole 3 and pole 4.

D pole 4 and pole 5.

An electric current can produce a heating effect and a magnetic effect.

Which row shows the effect that a relay uses, together with one application of a relay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & effect used by a relay & one application of a relay \\
\hline A & heating effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
B & heating effect & changing the voltage of an alternating current \\
C & magnetic effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
D & magnetic effect & changing the voltage of an alternating current \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a mains transformer that has an output voltage of \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \).

![diagram](./assets/19ee9c48-c365-4d73-9fcc-aca2f9d8e59e.png)

How many turns of wire are in the secondary coil?

A 12

B 20

C 50

D 20000

One lamp fails and all the lamps go out.

Which lamp failed?

![diagram](./assets/2faad0a3-c201-40a9-87cc-cd695f487f60.png)

Which statement about magnetism is correct?

A Aluminium is a ferrous metal.

B A steel magnet can be demagnetised by heating it.

C The core of an electromagnet is usually made of steel.

D The magnetic field lines around a bar magnet are evenly spaced.

Which diagram correctly represents rays of light passing through a converging lens in a camera?

B

image

The same quantity of thermal energy (heat) is given to each block.

Which block shows the greatest rise in temperature?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/8e2665fe-8fd9-4783-a4bd-0b68523a5a1a.png)

![diagram](./assets/e21cb8d4-8458-4d87-91bb-ee65b1d517e1.png)

A thermometer bulb is covered by a piece of damp absorbent cloth.

![diagram](./assets/4ae80c18-4a78-4a0f-908a-c25b5716bb69.png)

Air at room temperature is blown across the damp cloth.

What happens to the thermometer reading?

A It remains constant.

B It rises.

C It rises then falls.

D It falls.

A man stands on the ground.

Which action will increase the pressure that the man exerts on the ground?

A The man slowly bends his knees.

B The man slowly lies down on the ground.

C The man slowly raises his arms.

D The man slowly raises one foot off the ground.

The diagram shows a force being applied to a lever to lift a heavy weight.

![diagram](./assets/43b825cd-f806-4971-a722-dc45541cec81.png)

Which change would enable the heavy weight to be lifted with a smaller force?

A Move the force to the right.

B Move the heavy weight to the right.

A car moves along a level road.

The diagram shows all of the horizontal forces acting on the car.

![diagram](./assets/97d608ad-7c5c-42db-a0bf-fb8ac68c150e.png)

\( 2000 \mathrm{~N} \) force
 from engine

Which statement is correct?

A The car is slowing down.

B The car is speeding up.

C The car is moving at a constant speed.

D The car is moving backwards.

Which person is experiencing an acceleration?

A a driver of a car that is braking to stop at traffic lights

B a passenger in a train that is stationary in a railway station

C a shopper in a large store ascending an escalator (moving stairs) at a uniform rate

D a skydiver falling at constant speed towards the Earth

A geologist compares the volumes of three rocks, \( X, Y \) and \( Z \). Three measuring cylinders contain
 different volumes of water. He places each rock into one of the measuring cylinders.

The diagrams show the measuring cylinders before and after the rocks are put in.

![diagram](./assets/f2d876e4-c037-49bd-898c-d9ca79fafd1a.png)

A its mass

B Heavy objects always have more mass than light ones.

C Large objects always have more mass than small ones.

D Mass is a force but weight is not.

The student hears two bangs each time the hammer hits the pole.

Why does the student hear two bangs?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & first bang caused by & second bang caused by \\
\hline A & sound of hammer hitting pole & sound of pole hitting hammer \\
B & sound reaching left ear & sound reaching right ear \\
C & sound reaching student directly & sound due to echo from school building \\
D & sound reflected back from school building & sound reaching student directly \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The image of a clock face as seen in a plane mirror is shown.

![diagram](./assets/a6bb9119-fb3a-4dcc-b976-9446be33fc06.png)

What is the time on the clock?

A \( 1.25 \)

B \( 1.35 \)

C \( 10.25 \)

D \( 10.35 \)

A block of ice is heated until it has all melted. The water that is produced is then heated until it
 boils.


Which line in the table states what happens to the temperature of the ice while it is melting, and
 to the temperature of the water while it is boiling?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { temperature of ice } \\
\text { while it is melting }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { temperature of water } \\
\text { while it is boiling }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & increases & increases \\
B & increases & stays the same \\
C & stays the same & increases \\
D & stays the same & stays the same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A gas cylinder is left outside on a sunny day.

The Sun heats the gas inside the cylinder.

What happens to the gas molecules?

A They collide less often.

B They expand.

C They move closer together.

D They move more rapidly.
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
A heavy beam is resting on two supports, so that there are three forces acting on it.

![diagram](./assets/a2c66d9d-6b42-4681-b577-372731d587be.png)

The beam is in equilibrium.

Which statement is correct?

A All the forces are equal in value.

B The forces are in one direction and their turning effects are in the opposite direction.

C The resultant force is zero and the resultant turning effect is zero.

D The total upward force is twice the total downward force.

A car travels along the route PQRST in 30 minutes.

![diagram](./assets/b4104af8-f8bc-4e62-8130-4ad012be20dd.png)

What is the average speed of the car?

A \( 10 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour

B \( 20 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour

C \( 30 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour

D \( 60 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour

A village has to be supplied with electricity from a power station that is a long way from the
 village.

Which type of current should be used, and at which voltage?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & type of current & voltage \\
\hline A & alternating current & high voltage \\
B & alternating current & low voltage \\
C & direct current & high voltage \\
D & direct current & low voltage \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A fuse is a safety device for use in an electrical appliance.

How does a fuse affect a circuit when the current in it becomes higher than the correct value for
 the appliance?

A It completely stops the current.

B It reduces the current to the correct value for the appliance.

C It sends the current to the outer case of the appliance.

D It sends the excess current to the earth wire.

Which component can store energy and can be used in time-delay circuits?

A a capacitor

B a potentiometer

C a resistor

D a thermistor

Water waves in a tank pass over a thin plastic block as shown.

![diagram](./assets/bf31c783-93d9-4401-aed5-448ae2165eb0.png)

What happens to the waves as they reach the plastic block?

A They are diffracted because they slow down.

B They are diffracted because they speed up.

C They are refracted because they slow down.

D They are refracted because they speed up.

A car travels along the route PQRST in 30 minutes.

![diagram](./assets/5b801e0a-93df-48e9-b22c-307dd427077c.png)

What is the average speed of the car?

A \( 10 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour B \( 20 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour C \( 30 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour D \( 60 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour

The diagrams show an experiment to determine the volume of a stone.

without stone

with stone

![diagram](./assets/29ce3268-59eb-415c-b59e-ff2560472b46.png)

![diagram](./assets/fa1bcaa5-0aa9-4297-a568-322362e349da.png)

What is the volume of the stone?

A \( 3 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

B \( 4 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

C \( 7 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

D \( 11 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

A student is trying to find the density of water and of a large, regularly shaped concrete block.

Which apparatus is needed to find the density of both the water and the concrete block?

A balance, clock, measuring cylinder

B balance, clock, ruler

C balance, measuring cylinder, ruler

D clock, measuring cylinder, ruler

The diagram shows an experiment to demonstrate electromagnetic induction.

![diagram](./assets/520fc2cf-247f-447e-8322-69d4ac01c8a2.png)

\( X \) and \( Y \) are joined, in turn, by four wires, each made of a different material.

Each wire is then moved quickly downwards between the magnets.

Which material will not give rise to an induced current in the wire?

A aluminium

B copper

C iron

D nylon

The circuit diagram shows a cell connected to three identical lamps \( X, Y \) and \( Z \). All the lamps are
 lit.

![diagram](./assets/d6cdd7a5-2736-44a6-9473-69294e68170c.png)

Lamp \( Y \) is removed by unscrewing it from its holder.

What happens to lamp Z?

A It goes out completely.

B It becomes dimmer but stays lit.

C It stays the same brightness.

D It becomes brighter.

Three charged balls, \( P, Q \) and \( R \) are suspended by insulating threads. Ball \( P \) is negatively
 charged.

Ball \( Q \) is brought close to ball \( P \).

![diagram](./assets/8f877250-cf53-411e-8258-72c3f2dbb5c3.png)

![diagram](./assets/ddd022c5-882c-4476-93fa-365046c061b1.png)

Ball \( Q \) is now brought close to ball \( R \).

![diagram](./assets/35be063d-55fd-4bd4-83a8-e8bffa1ea933.png)

What are the charges on ball \( Q \) and on ball \( R \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & ball \( Q \) & ball \( R \) \\
\hline A & positive & positive \\
B & positive & negative \\
C & negative & positive \\
D & negative & negative \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

An old and expensive steel watch becomes magnetised.

The owner wants to use the watch again. He must demagnetise the watch.

What is the best method to do this?

A Heat it until it glows red hot.

B Pass direct current though it.

C Place it in a plastic bag and put the bag in hot water for several hours.

D Place it in a solenoid that carries alternating current and then slowly remove it.

Some sound from a loudspeaker at \( P \) travels directly to \( Q \). Sound also reaches \( Q \) after being
 reflected from a wall at \( R \).

![diagram](./assets/0127f58a-435e-4112-a40c-373a18442971.png)

The speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What is the difference in time for a sound to travel from \( P \) to \( Q \) by the two routes?

\( \left(\frac{6}{330}\right) \mathrm{s} \)

B \( \left(\frac{16}{330}\right) s \)

C \( (6 \times 330) \mathrm{s} \)

D \( (16 \times 330) \mathrm{s} \)

A tuning fork is marked with the number 320 .

![diagram](./assets/d8bb20dc-094b-43ee-b459-cd6240a563d4.png)

This indicates the size of the frequency.

What does this mean?

A The length of the tuning fork is \( 320 \mathrm{~mm} \).

B The note from the tuning fork will last for up to \( 320 \mathrm{~s} \).

C The sound waves produced by the tuning fork travel at \( 320 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

D The tuning fork vibrates 320 times every second.

Which diagram correctly represents rays of light passing through a converging lens in a camera?

![diagram](./assets/28ba0236-3ee4-4241-8a94-b470114c1d7b.png)

B

![diagram](./assets/ebfe6974-e72d-4eb5-b1f1-93daacc9cb8d.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/e32aa847-e028-414d-bc91-014efc14b2bf.png)

image

![diagram](./assets/6109161f-c9e3-4056-9e26-43698b4ac053.png)
 image

The diagrams show the actual size of the heels of four different lady's shoes, as seen from
 underneath the shoe.

Which heel is most likely to cause damage to floors?

A

![diagram](./assets/6d555647-ae8b-4add-8a66-d0286d269ec4.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/7202458d-ff5d-4db7-9ef9-106fd46eb5ae.png)

The diagrams show different objects, each being acted upon by only the two forces shown.

Which object is in equilibrium?

![diagram](./assets/0a914c90-411e-45dc-9eae-a165fea7798c.png)

![diagram](./assets/ddb799bf-eb13-452f-a453-22dba73b52eb.png)

![diagram](./assets/d1a6e661-00a5-459a-9871-ac689b43b2c3.png)

![diagram](./assets/79815cd6-aea9-4732-95ce-f878b05b33af.png)

A car travels at various speeds during a short journey.

The table shows the distances travelled and the times taken during each of four stages
 \( P, Q, R \) and \( S \).

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline stage & \( \mathrm{P} \) & \( \mathrm{Q} \) & \( \mathrm{R} \) & \( \mathrm{S} \) \\
\hline distance travelled/km & \( 1.8 \) & \( 3.6 \) & \( 2.7 \) & \( 2.7 \) \\
time taken/minutes & 2 & 2 & 4 & 3 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

During which two stages is the car travelling at the same average speed?

A \( P \) and \( Q \)

B \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{S} \)

C \( Q \) and \( R \)

D \( \mathrm{R} \) and \( \mathrm{S} \)

A heavy metal ball falls vertically downwards through air past four equally spaced levels \( \mathrm{J}, \mathrm{K}, \mathrm{L} \)
 and \( M \).

metal ball

level \( \mathrm{J} \)

level K

level \( L \)

level \( M \)

The times taken to fall from one level to the next are measured.

Where is the speed of the ball greatest and which time is shortest?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { speed is } \\
\text { greatest between }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { time is } \\
\text { shortest between }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & \( \mathrm{J} \) and K & \( \mathrm{J} \) and K \\
B & \( \mathrm{J} \) and K & \( \mathrm{L} \) and M \\
C & \( \mathrm{L} \) and M & \( \mathrm{J} \) and K \\
D & \( \mathrm{L} \) and M & \( \mathrm{L} \) and M \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which type of radiation has the greatest ionising effect?

A \( \alpha \)-particles

B \( \beta \)-particles

C \( \gamma \)-rays

D all have the same ionising effect
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
The diagram shows a simple cathode-ray tube.

Which part emits the electrons?

![diagram](./assets/0b08ab13-1ea8-4c7a-b698-f37cbd76e087.png)

The diagram shows a circuit with three ammeters, \( X, Y \) and \( Z \).

![diagram](./assets/46869a77-87ff-4b26-977f-1c05d08b40cc.png)

Which set of readings is possible?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( X \) & \( Y \) & \( Z \) \\
\hline A & \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 5 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
B & \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 5 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
C & \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
D & \( 5 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A fire alarm is not loud enough. An engineer adjusts it so that it produces a note of the same pitch
 which is louder.

What effect does this have on the amplitude and on the frequency of the sound?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & amplitude & frequency \\
\hline A & larger & larger \\
B & larger & same \\
C & same & larger \\
D & same & same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Radio waves are received at a house at the bottom of a hill.

![diagram](./assets/6ba085f9-ef54-4e60-aee2-25d76617ef45.png)

The waves reach the house because the hill has caused them to be

A diffracted.

B radiated.

C reflected.

D refracted.

An experiment is set up as shown.

![diagram](./assets/99ba1635-a19d-4726-965f-6dc6bade73e8.png)

What does the pressure gauge show as the air in the flask becomes hotter?

A a steady pressure

B a decrease in pressure

C an increase in pressure

D an increase and then a decrease in pressure

A water manometer is used to measure the pressure of a gas supply to a house. It gives a
 reading of \( h \mathrm{~cm} \) of water.

![diagram](./assets/4d2f2e3c-39d8-4e7e-b3e9-8f54e3f5a507.png)

Why is it better to use water rather than mercury in this manometer?

A \( h \) would be too large if mercury were used.

B \( h \) would be too small if mercury were used.

C The tube would need to be narrower if mercury were used.

D The tube would need to be wider if mercury were used.

Objects with different masses are hung on a \( 10 \mathrm{~cm} \) spring. The diagram shows how much the
 spring stretches.

![diagram](./assets/243346d7-7477-4a56-8b98-956845b047b9.png)

The extension of the spring is directly proportional to the mass hung on it.

What is the mass of object \( M \) ?

A \( \quad 110 \mathrm{~g} \)

B \( \quad 150 \mathrm{~g} \)

C \( 200 \mathrm{~g} \)

D \( 300 \mathrm{~g} \)

Two blocks \( X \) and \( Y \) are placed on a beam as shown. The beam balances on a pivot at its centre.

![diagram](./assets/e9bd1157-8e38-4568-91ce-512d48f483c3.png)

What does this show about \( X \) and \( Y \) ?

A They have the same mass and the same density.

B They have the same mass and the same weight.

C They have the same volume and the same density.

D They have the same volume and the same weight.

Which statement is correct?

A The mass of a bottle of water at the North Pole is different from its mass at the Equator.

B The mass of a bottle of water is measured in newtons.

C The weight of a bottle of water and its mass are the same thing.

D The weight of a bottle of water is one of the forces acting on it.

A decorator wishes to calculate the area of a bathroom tile so that he can estimate the amount of
 adhesive that he needs to buy.

What must he use?

A a measuring cylinder only

B a ruler only

C a measuring cylinder and a clock only

D a measuring cylinder and a ruler only

A strong electromagnet is used to attract pins.

![diagram](./assets/f999f5de-22af-4145-80a9-df82b235bc5a.png)

What happens when the current in the coil is halved?

A No pins are attracted.

B Some pins are attracted, but not as many.

C The same number of pins is attracted.

D More pins are attracted.

A student wishes to make a permanent magnet. She has an iron rod and a steel rod.

Which rod should she use to make the permanent magnet, and is this rod a hard magnetic
 material or a soft magnetic material?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & rod & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { type of magnetic } \\
\text { material }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & iron & hard \\
B & iron & soft \\
C & steel & hard \\
D & steel & soft \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A candle flame is placed in front of a loudspeaker.

The loudspeaker produces a sound wave that causes air particles to vibrate. The vibrating air
 particles make the candle flame vibrate in the same direction as the air particles.

![diagram](./assets/6df8d9ce-e291-467c-af66-5933372618de.png)

![diagram](./assets/1b333c49-018e-4cba-bac7-011cb812152a.png)


Which row shows the direction of vibration of the candle flame, and the nature of sound waves?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { direction of } \\
\text { vibration }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { nature of } \\
\text { sound waves }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & 4 & longitudinal \\
B & \( \longrightarrow \) & transverse \\
C & \( \longrightarrow \) & longitudinal \\
D & \( \longrightarrow \) & transverse \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
Radio waves are received at a house at the bottom of a hill.

![diagram](./assets/6f2aff8d-d6e7-4dea-8903-4ab37c9e9695.png)

The waves reach the house because the hill has caused them to be

A diffracted.

B radiated.

C reflected.

D refracted.

Which quantity gives the thermal capacity of a beaker?

A the thermal energy required to change the state of the beaker at constant temperature

B the thermal energy required to raise the temperature of the beaker by \( 1^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

C the total mass of hot liquid that the beaker can hold

D the total volume of hot liquid that the beaker can hold

A jug of water is at room temperature.

Several ice cubes at a temperature of \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) are dropped into the water and they begin to melt
 immediately.


What happens to the temperature of the water and what happens to the temperature of the ice
 cubes while they are melting?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { temperature of } \\
\text { the water }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { temperature of } \\
\text { the ice cubes }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & increases \\
B & decreases & stays constant \\
C & stays constant & increases \\
D & stays constant & stays constant \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a simple mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/72608e8a-9062-4152-896c-514ed3aa6a96.png)

The atmospheric pressure increases.

Which distance increases?

A VW

B WY

C \( X Y \)

D \( X Z \)

Which energy source is renewable and reliably available at all times?

A coal

B geothermal

C nuclear

D wind

A feather falls through the air. Its downward speed is constant.

Which statement about the feather is correct?

A No energy is lost to the air as the feather falls.

B The air resistance acting on the feather is greater than its weight.

C The feather experiences no resultant vertical force.

D There is a resultant downward force on the feather.

A heavy object is released near the surface of the Earth and falls freely. Air resistance can be
 ignored.

Which statement about the acceleration of the object due to gravity is correct?

A The acceleration depends on the mass of the object.

B The acceleration depends on the volume of the object.

C The acceleration is constant.

D The acceleration is initially zero and increases as the object falls.

An electric oven is connected to the mains supply using insulated copper wires. The wires
 become very warm.

What can be done to prevent so much heat being produced in the connecting wires?

A Use thicker copper wires.

B Use thinner copper wires.

C Use thicker insulation.

D Use thinner insulation.

Two bars of soft iron are placed near a bar magnet.

![diagram](./assets/8f6c5f68-4f9f-4800-b42b-5206fd0765c1.png)

![diagram](./assets/3d53b259-da37-40a7-9ede-904d27c96589.png)

Which row states and explains the behaviour of poles \( P \) and \( Q \) of the soft iron bars?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) & reason \\
\hline A & attract & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are like poles \\
B & attract & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are unlike poles \\
C & repel & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are like poles \\
D & repel & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are unlike poles \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A swimmer is sitting on a rock at the sea shore looking at passing waves. He notices that five
 complete wavelengths pass him in \( 20 \mathrm{~s} \).

What is the frequency of this wave?

A \( 0.25 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

B \( 4.0 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

C \( 15 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

D \( 100 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

A boy sits near a campfire. He pokes the fire with an iron bar. His hand becomes hot.

![diagram](./assets/635c5191-dae5-4fab-880b-ad015ecbc360.png)

In which ways does thermal energy (heat) from the fire reach his hand?

A conduction and convection only

B conduction and radiation only

C convection and radiation only

D conduction, convection and radiation

After a sheep has its wool cut off, it is harder for it to stay warm when the air temperature falls.

How does the wool help the sheep to stay warm?

A Air can circulate between the wool fibres and heat up the skin by convection.

B Air trapped by the wool fibres reduces heat losses from the skin by convection.

C The wool fibres are curly so it takes longer for heat to be conducted away from the skin.

D The wool fibres conduct heat to the skin from the air outside.

Which physical property is used to measure temperature in a liquid-in-glass thermometer?

A the length of the thermometer

B the thickness of the glass bulb

C the volume of the glass bulb

D the volume of the liquid

Very small pollen grains are suspended in water. A bright light shines from the side.

Looking through a microscope, small specks of light are seen to be moving in a random, jerky
 manner.

\( \Leftrightarrow \) eye

![diagram](./assets/25849018-399b-42b8-b7bb-008d9ebbf9f9.png)

![diagram](./assets/83f744c4-2010-41b7-98bd-dd00cb2b4d10.png)

pollen grains

in water

What are the moving specks of light?

A pollen grains being hit by other pollen grains

B pollen grains being hit by water molecules

C water molecules being hit by other water molecules

D water molecules being hit by pollen grains

A heavy table has six legs. The area of cross-section of each leg is \( X \).

The legs of the table make marks in a carpet. These marks become deeper with increased
 pressure.

What would reduce the depth of the marks for a table of a fixed weight?

A using three legs, each of an area smaller than \( X \)

B using four legs, each of an area the same as \( X \)

C using six legs, each of an area smaller than \( X \)

D using eight legs, each of an area the same as \( X \)

The diagram shows a mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/ced87f3a-b3fd-4892-b94f-2ed42c341c27.png)

Which distance is used to calculate the pressure of the atmosphere?

A \( 25 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 75 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 80 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 100 \mathrm{~cm} \)

The diagram shows sections of four objects of equal mass. The position of the centre of mass of
 each object has been marked with a cross.

Which object is the most stable?

![diagram](./assets/f07fd574-1c3b-4fa4-9353-8b79cfd9644b.png)

A liquid has a density of \( 0.80 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \).

Which could be the volume and mass of this liquid?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & volume \( / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \) & mass \( / \mathrm{g} \) \\
\hline A & \( 2.0 \) & 16 \\
B & \( 8.0 \) & 10 \\
C & 10 & \( 8.0 \) \\
D & 16 & \( 2.0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A large bag of feathers and a steel block balance each other on some scales.

![diagram](./assets/e65b2476-f1c6-4384-9171-470b5d88f573.png)

What does this show about the masses and the weights of the bag of feathers and the steel
 block?

A It shows that the masses are equal and the weights are equal.

B It shows that the masses are equal, but the weights might be different.

C It shows that the masses might be different and the weights might be different.

D It shows that the weights are equal, but the masses might be different.

Two stones of different weight fall at the same time from a table. Air resistance may be ignored.

What will happen and why?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & what will happen & why \\
\hline A & both stones hit the floor at the same time & acceleration of free fall is constant \\
B & both stones hit the floor at the same time & they fall at constant speed \\
C & the heavier stone hits the floor first & acceleration increases with weight \\
D & the heavier stone hits the floor first & speed increases with weight \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Four lamps are each labelled '60W \( 230 \mathrm{~V} \) '.

In which circuit are the lamps connected so that they operate at normal brightness?

![diagram](./assets/2b3bf5a8-6cb3-4af6-8c47-3c6fc24d7d91.png)

![diagram](./assets/9ff58bf0-46e0-4b78-a331-2f0985ea2a84.png)

![diagram](./assets/10deaaa3-67c5-413d-b690-60662c0070d3.png)

D

![diagram](./assets/4c6fdba5-8cec-4dbd-9f98-62d4920aa33a.png)

The diagram shows a light-dependent resistor (LDR) connected in a potential divider circuit.

![diagram](./assets/c471ac05-e87b-4402-90e9-48da4d6ed738.png)

The brightness of the light falling on the LDR is increased.

Which row shows what happens to the resistance of the LDR, and what happens to the reading
 on the voltmeter?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & resistance of LDR & reading on voltmeter \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Sounds are produced by vibrating objects. A certain object vibrates but a person nearby cannot
 hear any sound.

Which statement could explain why nothing is heard?

A The amplitude of the sound waves is too large.

B The frequency of the vibration is too high.

C The sound waves are transverse.

D The speed of the sound waves is too high.

The diagram represents the electromagnetic spectrum.

Some regions have been labelled, and some labels are missing.

Which region should be labelled as infra-red waves?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline \( \begin{array}{c}\text { radio } \\
\text { waves }\end{array} \) & A & B & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { visible } \\
\text { light }\end{array} \) & C & D & \( \gamma \)-rays \\

\end{tabular}

 difference between the pressure of a gas and atmospheric pressure.

Electrical energy may be obtained from nuclear fission.

In which order is the energy transferred in this process?

A nuclear fuel \( \rightarrow \) generator \( \rightarrow \) reactor and boiler \( \rightarrow \) turbines

B nuclear fuel \( \rightarrow \) generator \( \rightarrow \) turbines \( \rightarrow \) reactor and boiler

C nuclear fuel \( \rightarrow \) reactor and boiler \( \rightarrow \) generator \( \rightarrow \) turbines

D nuclear fuel \( \rightarrow \) reactor and boiler \( \rightarrow \) turbines \( \rightarrow \) generator

What needs to be known to calculate the work done by a force acting on an object?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { the size of } \\
\text { the force }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { the distance } \\
\text { the force } \\
\text { moves the } \\
\text { object }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { the time for } \\
\text { which the force } \\
\text { acts }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & \( \checkmark \) & \( \checkmark \) & \( \checkmark \) \\
B & \( \checkmark \) & \( \checkmark \) & key \\
C & \( \checkmark \) & \( x \) & \( \checkmark= \) needed \\
D & \( \checkmark \) & \( x \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The mass of an object is measured on Earth. The mass is \( 5.0 \mathrm{~kg} \).

The object is taken to the Moon. The mass of the object is measured on the Moon.

What is the mass of the object on the Moon?

B more than \( 0 \mathrm{~kg} \), but less than \( 5.0 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( 5.0 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D more than \( 5.0 \mathrm{~kg} \)

A \( 10 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour B \( 20 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour C \( 30 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour D \( 60 \mathrm{~km} / \) hour

120 & 120 \\
180 & 95 \\
240 & 75 \\

D \( { }_{4}^{7} \mathrm{Li} \)

C

B

![diagram](./assets/f17ded72-a472-4651-becb-482ee1193550.png)

 other. The second bang is an echo.

From which surface has the sound reflected to cause this echo?

A \( X Y \)

B PV

C ZY

D WX

After the rod is heated at the join in the centre for about a minute, where would the lowest
 temperature be?

![diagram](./assets/695f2f66-460e-4cbc-b9b0-966e794f2539.png)

Which part of the graph shows when the substance is boiling?

 as shown in the diagrams.

In which container is the pressure on the base the greatest?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/c4f2a109-751c-4c28-894c-0a8918ae8bf9.png)

The diagrams show two mercury barometers standing side by side. The right-hand diagram
 shows a tube of bigger diameter, but the diagram is incomplete. There is a vacuum above the
 mercury in both tubes.

Which labelled position on the right-hand tube could show the mercury level in that tube?

![diagram](./assets/e36dbb4c-62ec-4cb0-9c26-8c36548ae8ab.png)

Electricity can be obtained from different energy resources.

Which energy resource is used to obtain electricity without producing heat to boil water?

A coal

B geothermal

C hydroelectric

D nuclear

A car travels \( 100 \mathrm{~km} \). The highest speed of the car is \( 90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \), and the lowest speed is
 \( 30 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \). The journey takes two hours.

What is the average speed for the journey?

A \( 30 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

B \( 50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

C \( 60 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

D \( 90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

In a cathode-ray tube, a hot tungsten cathode releases particles by thermionic emission.

What are these particles?

A \( \alpha \)-particles

B electrons

C protons

D tungsten atoms

A \( P \)

B \( Q \)

C \( P+Q \)

D \( P-Q \)

End Q: attracts end R,

attracts end \( \mathrm{S} \),

repels end \( U \).

A rod 1 only

B \( \operatorname{rod} 1 \) and rod 2

C \( \operatorname{rod} 1 \) and rod 3

D rod 3 only

In an experiment to measure the speed of sound, a student uses a stopwatch to find the time
 taken for a sound wave to travel from \( X \) to \( Y \). She does this six times.

![diagram](./assets/c54835f2-59e6-4575-b140-a319ec7ee80d.png)

The table shows her results.

second & \( 0.7 \) \\
third & \( 0.6 \) \\
fourth & \( 0.4 \) \\
fifth & \( 0.9 \) \\
sixth & \( 0.5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A \( 0.4 \mathrm{~s} \)

B \( \quad 0.5 \mathrm{~s} \)

C \( 0.6 \mathrm{~s} \)

D \( 0.9 \mathrm{~s} \)

Which type of electromagnetic wave is used in airport security scanners?

A infra-red

B microwaves

C radio waves

D X-rays

The diagram shows a simple transformer with an input of \( 240 \mathrm{~V} \) and an output of \( 40 \mathrm{~V} \).

There are 600 turns on the primary coil.

![diagram](./assets/de45756a-e066-45f9-bb0b-8d6749a80c4d.png)

A 100

B \( 3.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

D The wavelength of wave \( S \) is the same as the wavelength of wave \( Q \).

D the top and bottom points of the thermometer bulb

body:
The diagram shows a simple mercury barometer.

![diagram](./assets/71538b91-6c36-4546-a4fe-3b0dfce74d1e.png)

The atmospheric pressure increases.

Which distance increases?

A \( \mathrm{VW} \)

B WY

C \( X Y \)

D \( X Z \)

To prevent a cement mixer sinking into soft ground, the mixer is placed on a large flat board.

![diagram](./assets/7e66cf4a-52d7-41d4-8355-77694b4468be.png)

Why does this prevent the mixer sinking?

A The large area decreases the pressure on the ground.

B The large area increases the pressure on the ground.

C The large area decreases the weight on the ground.

D The large area increases the weight on the ground.

A cyclist travels down a hill from rest at point \( \mathrm{X} \) without pedalling.

The cyclist applies his brakes and the cycle stops at point \( Y \).

![diagram](./assets/c65ab366-aad4-487f-92e0-93c2f60f3800.png)

Which energy changes have taken place between \( X \) and \( Y \) ?

A \( \quad \) kinetic \( \rightarrow \) internal (heat) \( \rightarrow \) gravitational potential

B \( \quad \) kinetic \( \rightarrow \) gravitational potential \( \rightarrow \) internal (heat)

C gravitational potential \( \rightarrow \) internal (heat) \( \rightarrow \) kinetic

D gravitational potential \( \rightarrow \) kinetic \( \rightarrow \) internal (heat)

Which source of energy uses the production of steam to generate electricity?

A hydroelectric

B nuclear

C tides

D waves

The diagram shows sections of four objects of equal mass. The position of the centre of mass of
 each object has been marked with a cross.

Which object is the most stable?

![diagram](./assets/af61bf49-4d28-43bd-ab2d-e2a2d046efeb.png)

A newton is a unit of force.

Which quantity is measured in newtons?

A acceleration

B density

C mass

D weight

A cyclist is riding along a road when an animal runs in front of him. The graph shows the cyclist's
 motion. He sees the animal at \( P \), starts to brake at \( Q \) and stops at \( R \).

![diagram](./assets/0309005c-0577-4d3d-950e-5fa0af992db2.png)

What is used to find the distance travelled after he applies the brakes?

A the area under line \( P Q \)

B the area under line \( Q R \)

C the gradient of line \( P Q \)

D the gradient of line QR

A ruler is used to measure the length of a nail.

![diagram](./assets/2e367a0e-6d5c-4b61-a552-80a12c1feaaa.png)

What is the length of the nail?

A \( 1.3 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 2.9 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 5.2 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 8.1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

A coil is rotated steadily between the poles of a magnet. The coil is connected to an oscilloscope.

![diagram](./assets/425246d3-c13d-400a-8715-57c5a5fa3662.png)

Which graph shows the output voltage \( V \) against time \( t \) ?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/8e25d988-0acb-4c3b-808d-a0271a963a7a.png)

![diagram](./assets/6e3020e8-b63c-4fb7-86d0-5dae093ef22f.png)

![diagram](./assets/9f5ff311-8582-40b8-abde-dcc40de3b769.png)

![diagram](./assets/cb161c81-1ffe-4efb-9797-414c8d26d2f6.png)
