![diagram](./assets/b33bfb6d-c007-464c-b5fe-79b79be67e86.png)

The p.d. and the resistance of the resistor can both be changed.

Which row shows two changes that will both increase the current in the resistor?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & change & change \\
\hline A & decrease p.d. & decrease resistance \\
B & decrease p.d. & increase resistance \\
C & increase p.d. & decrease resistance \\
D & increase p.d. & increase resistance \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A scientist is trying to direct a ray of light through a glass block without any light leaving the top of
 the block. However, some light does leave the top.

![diagram](./assets/0a7a3f67-efdf-4af6-9738-b8166ca2a610.png)

The scientist changes angle \( X \) and stops the ray of light leaving the top.

Which row in the table describes the change to angle \( X \) and the name of the effect produced?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & change to angle \( X \) & name of effect produced \\
\hline A & decrease & total internal reflection \\
B & decrease & total internal refraction \\
C & increase & total internal reflection \\
D & increase & total internal refraction \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A ship sends a pulse of sound vertically downwards to the sea bed. An echo is heard
 \( 0.4 \) seconds later.

If the speed of sound in the water is \( 1200 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), how deep is the water below the ship?

A \( 240 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 480 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 1500 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 3000 \mathrm{~m} \)

The diagrams represent two different sound waves.

wave \( P \)

wave \( Q \)

![diagram](./assets/9853769b-3398-473e-b25c-dd8a54a16137.png)

How do the frequency and pitch of \( P \) compare with the frequency and pitch of \( Q \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & frequency of \( P \) & pitch of \( P \) \\
\hline A & greater than \( Q \) & higher than \( Q \) \\
B & greater than \( Q \) & same as \( Q \) \\
C & same as \( Q \) & higher than \( Q \) \\
D & same as \( Q \) & same as \( Q \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which group contains only transverse waves?

A infra-red waves, light waves, sound waves

B infra-red waves, light waves, ultra-violet waves

C infra-red waves, ultra-violet waves, sound waves

D light waves, sound waves, ultra-violet waves

A piece of wood has some iron nails pushed through it. One side of the wood is covered with heat
 sensitive paper which turns from pink to blue when heated. The wood is heated as shown for a
 few minutes and blue dots appear on the heat sensitive paper where it touches the nails.

![diagram](./assets/0e459e8b-f467-4f80-8dc6-47e642be0019.png)

This experiment shows that, compared to wood, iron is a good

A absorber of heat.

B conductor of heat.

C convector of heat.

D emitter of heat.

A block of ice cream is prevented from melting by wrapping it in newspaper soaked in water. The
 water evaporates from the newspaper.


Which molecules escape from the water and what happens to the average speed of the water
 molecules that remain in the newspaper?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & escaping molecules & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { average speed of the } \\
\text { remaining water molecules }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & the more energetic ones & decreases \\
B & the more energetic ones & increases \\
C & the less energetic ones & decreases \\
D & the less energetic ones & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which of these is designed to change electrical energy into kinetic energy?

A a capacitor

B a generator

C a motor

D a transformer

Four athletes run twice around a track. The table shows their times at the end of each lap.

Which athlete runs the second lap the fastest?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline athlete & time at end of first lap/s & time at end of second lap/s \\
\hline A & \( 22.99 \) & \( 47.04 \) \\
B & \( 23.04 \) & \( 47.00 \) \\
C & \( 23.16 \) & \( 47.18 \) \\
D & \( 23.39 \) & \( 47.24 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Liquid \( X \) has a density of \( 1010 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \). Liquid \( Y \) has a density of \( 950 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \).

The liquids are poured into tubes as shown.

Which tube has the greatest pressure on its base?

![diagram](./assets/36a0918b-8b70-44c7-96c8-de8a6e0f8a88.png)

A radiation detector is placed close to a source of \( \beta \)-particles.

Aluminium sheets of increasing thickness are placed between the source and the detector.

![diagram](./assets/43f61e35-8efa-45f3-81ec-8f5b0f86a0f7.png)

Eventually a sheet which is \( 2.0 \mathrm{~cm} \) thick is used. The reading on the detector decreases, but does
 not fall to zero.

Why does the reading not fall to zero?

A Some of the \( \beta \)-particles go round the edges of the sheet.

B The detector is too close to the source.

C There is always some background radiation.

D The sheet can never be thick enough to absorb all the \( \beta \)-particles.
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
Each branch of a domestic circuit often includes a circuit-breaker. This protects the wiring if too
 much current flows in the circuit.

In which wire is the circuit-breaker placed and what does it do when it operates?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & circuit-breaker in & when the circuit-breaker operates it \\
\hline A & live wire & disconnects the circuit \\
B & live wire & reduces the current to a safe value (not zero) \\
C & neutral wire & disconnects the circuit \\
D & neutral wire & reduces the current to a safe value (not zero) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A circuit contains the component shown by the following symbol.

![diagram](./assets/d22af86f-3700-485e-83b2-3440bad6e41d.png)

Which change would the component detect?

A change in

A light level.

B potential difference.

C radioactivity.

D temperature.

An electromagnet is used to separate magnetic metals from non-magnetic metals.

Why is steel not suitable as the core of the electromagnet?

A It forms a permanent magnet.

B It has a high density.

C It has a high thermal capacity.

D It is a good conductor of electricity.

The diagrams show four blocks of steel. The blocks are all drawn to the same scale.

The same quantity of thermal energy (heat) is given to each block.

Which block shows the greatest rise in temperature?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/6b0f1192-063a-435e-b528-f160b9ca38a0.png)

![diagram](./assets/b6cca904-6bc6-4e10-8e99-c050de31c20e.png)

![diagram](./assets/9dbe2686-2914-4134-8cb7-09c0cdcc788e.png)

![diagram](./assets/a90e8f42-8d62-47fd-95e6-bc9cbc1a265d.png)

A gas storage tank has a fixed volume. The graph shows how the temperature of the gas in the
 tank varies with time.

![diagram](./assets/a77e484f-73a8-4a94-8f2d-04df4beed52f.png)

At time \( Y \), the gas molecules are

A closer together than at time \( X \).

B hitting the sides of the tank harder than at time \( X \).

C larger in size than at time \( X \).

D moving more slowly than at time \( X \).

A car moves along a level road at constant speed. Work is done by the engine and power is
 developed by the engine.

Which pair of graphs shows how the work done and the power developed vary with time?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/ad25ed88-f15c-4549-baee-622f3e8e17f4.png)

![diagram](./assets/bb3d5be7-df6e-4f64-b565-0d2b3f96b51b.png)

![diagram](./assets/fd4d8429-b420-44b6-9069-7427590f24c7.png)

![diagram](./assets/7a77ffa2-571c-4dcf-86d4-7ca6481430db.png)

\( \mathrm{C} \)

D

![diagram](./assets/6e4dbabc-dd84-40d8-bf65-e9a50dd52c55.png)

![diagram](./assets/26e6b3f6-447a-4153-9446-3f2f6025e359.png)

![diagram](./assets/f6be693c-7a8f-4b48-8f19-31ab78eb58e4.png)

![diagram](./assets/ee132119-4718-4a2e-846e-ef65a8a01894.png)

The diagram shows a hydroelectric system.

![diagram](./assets/3deb4e43-0a35-48de-8bdb-3b95b4bca3b9.png)

What are the main energy changes taking place?

A chemical energy \( \rightarrow \) kinetic energy \( \rightarrow \) electrical energy

B electrical energy \( \rightarrow \) gravitational energy \( \rightarrow \) kinetic energy

C gravitational energy \( \rightarrow \) kinetic energy \( \rightarrow \) electrical energy

D kinetic energy \( \rightarrow \) electrical energy \( \rightarrow \) gravitational energy

A child sits on a rubber ball and bounces up and down on the ground.

![diagram](./assets/f2676cb4-1af5-4521-ad54-beea7772acc9.png)

What stays the same when the ball hits the ground?

A the acceleration of the ball

B the mass of the ball

C the shape of the ball

D the velocity of the ball

A student stands with both feet on some scales in order to measure his weight.

The reading on the scales is \( 500 \mathrm{~N} \). He lifts one foot off the scales and keeps it lifted.

What is the new reading on the scales?

A 0

B \( 250 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 500 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 1000 \mathrm{~N} \)

Two blocks of metal \( X \) and \( Y \) hang from spring balances, as shown in the diagrams.

![diagram](./assets/4abc6dee-db16-4ee8-a13d-bc3134d4960e.png)

![diagram](./assets/97ee45a2-9f51-42dd-85d8-4543674d6cf0.png)

What does the diagram show about \( \mathrm{X} \) and \( \mathrm{Y} \) ?

A They have the same mass and the same volume but different weights.

B They have the same mass and the same weight but different volumes.

C They have the same mass, the same volume and the same weight.

D They have the same weight and the same volume but different masses.

A student makes the circuit shown.

![diagram](./assets/17a91616-fb55-4365-b17f-e9b5fba2ad5c.png)

The fuse has blown and stopped the current.

What could have caused this?

A The current rating of the fuse was too high.

B The current was too large.

C The lamp was loose.

D The voltage was too small.

A lamp is to be connected in a circuit so that the p.d. across it can be varied from 0 to \( 6 \mathrm{~V} \).

Which circuit would be most suitable?

![diagram](./assets/46de6cd2-d524-45cf-bd12-4d4efade81e7.png)

![diagram](./assets/1d099744-0e86-47e7-ac69-0b1a669b898e.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/dcc8f6ec-23eb-4361-8dea-be0d0be36907.png)

![diagram](./assets/a6304d91-20e1-4945-b7a1-81302b0b1322.png)

In the circuit below, \( X \) and \( Y \) are identical \( 6 \mathrm{~V} \) lamps.

![diagram](./assets/980d62b4-9721-4444-a7b1-89ace17f142c.png)

What happens when the switch is closed?

A \( \mathrm{X} \) lights more brightly than \( \mathrm{Y} \).

B \( Y \) lights more brightly than \( X \).

C \( X \) and \( Y \) light with equal brightness.

D Neither \( X \) nor \( Y \) light.

A brass rod is positioned in an east-west direction and a plotting compass is placed at each end.

brass rod

plotting

compass

![diagram](./assets/5b8bb0a3-6df0-4bc4-89a2-8fcc51f21949.png)

![diagram](./assets/7b229abf-bcf8-4862-9c56-6b35685418d3.png)

Which diagram shows the positions of the needles of the plotting compasses?

A (4)

(4)

(4)

(1)

C

![diagram](./assets/aa86ffe7-7206-4921-a596-21577397804e.png)

![diagram](./assets/16065072-1b2a-4cbf-929f-26ca35b5747e.png)

D

A measured mass of gas is placed in a cylinder at atmospheric pressure and is then slowly
 compressed.

![diagram](./assets/6d0f9f60-7fbb-4a29-b71d-f4010ff1a795.png)

The temperature of the gas does not change.

What happens to the pressure of the gas?

A It drops to zero.

B It decreases, but not to zero.

C It stays the same.

D It increases.

A ball is released from rest and rolls down a track from the position shown.

What is the furthest position the ball could reach?

![diagram](./assets/332ab3b1-3fea-4711-9c5b-6464189071ef.png)

A power station uses nuclear fission to obtain energy.

In this process, nuclear energy is first changed into

A chemical energy.

B electrical energy.

C gravitational energy.

D internal energy.

A sample of a radioactive isotope has an initial rate of emission of 128 counts per minute and a
 half-life of 4 days.

How long will it take for the rate of emission to fall to 32 counts per minute?

A 2 days

B 4 days

C 8 days

D 12 days

Below are four statements about isotopes of a certain element.

Which statement about the isotopes must be correct?

A They are radioactive.

B They are unstable.

C They have the same number of neutrons.

D They have the same number of protons.

The diagram shows a cell connected to two \( 6.0 \Omega \) resistors. Three currents, \( I_{1}, I_{2} \) and \( I_{3} \), are
 labelled.

![diagram](./assets/765f1845-dc59-495a-9fb4-8802e4aedbb2.png)

Which row correctly compares \( I_{2} \) and \( I_{3} \) with \( I_{1} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( I_{2} \) & \( I_{3} \) \\
\hline A & same as \( I_{1} \) & same as \( I_{1} \) \\
B & same as \( I_{1} \) & smaller than \( I_{1} \) \\
C & smaller than \( I_{1} \) & same as \( I_{1} \) \\
D & smaller than \( I_{1} \) & smaller than \( I_{1} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a battery connected to two resistors.

![diagram](./assets/69f217ef-f204-41f7-b293-08efe220e8e9.png)

Four students separately measure the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery, the current in
 the resistors, and the potential difference (p.d.) across resistor R.

Their results are shown in the table below.

Which row shows values with their correct units?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & e.m.f. & current & p.d. \\
\hline A & \( 3.0 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 0.30 \mathrm{~V} \) & \( 1.5 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
B & \( 3.0 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 0.30 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 1.5 \mathrm{~V} \) \\
C & \( 3.0 \mathrm{~V} \) & \( 0.30 \mathrm{~V} \) & \( 1.5 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
D & \( 3.0 \mathrm{~V} \) & \( 0.30 \mathrm{~A} \) & \( 1.5 \mathrm{~V} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A flexible electrical cable consists of a central conductor and outer insulation.

![diagram](./assets/4f252ea2-1a55-4ae8-8816-f9edf4064442.png)

Which pair of materials is suitable for the cable?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & central conductor & outer insulation \\
\hline A & copper & plastic \\
B & lead & wood \\
C & plastic & copper \\
D & wood & lead \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which statement about magnetism is correct?

A An unmagnetised iron bar becomes magnetised when it is placed near a magnet.

B An unmagnetised steel bar can be magnetised by passing a current through it.

C The direction of magnetic field lines is from an S-pole to an N-pole.

D The N-poles of two magnets attract each other.

A rod is made half of glass and half of copper. Four pins \( \mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C} \) and \( \mathbf{D} \) are attached to the rod by
 wax. The rod is heated in the centre as shown.

The pins fall off when the wax melts.

Which pin falls off first?

![diagram](./assets/fd26fcfe-e74a-426a-a8e2-7666bd7c9ea9.png)

A sealed bottle of constant volume contains air.

The air in the bottle is heated by the Sun.

What is the effect on the average speed of the air molecules in the bottle, and the average
 distance between them?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { average speed } \\
\text { of air molecules }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { average distance } \\
\text { between air } \\
\text { molecules }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & stays the same \\
C & increases & increases \\
D & increases & stays the same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What causes the random, zig-zag movement (Brownian motion) of smoke particles suspended in
 air?

A air molecules colliding with smoke particles

B convection currents as the hot smoke rises

C smoke particles colliding with each other

D smoke particles reacting with oxygen molecules in the air
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
The diagram shows an enlarged drawing of the end of a metre rule. It is being used to measure
 the length of a small feather.

![diagram](./assets/f170d9c4-bbd6-48b5-9484-19b4b5acf553.png)

![diagram](./assets/12b13e44-2bbf-4744-a04e-edeff43a5140.png)

What is the length of the feather?

A \( 19 \mathrm{~mm} \)

B \( 29 \mathrm{~mm} \)

C \( 19 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 29 \mathrm{~cm} \)

A beam of cathode rays passes between two parallel, charged metal plates in a vacuum.

![diagram](./assets/66408153-d112-4efa-b95d-95220d3f1b57.png)

In which direction is the beam deflected?

A into the page

B out of the page

C to the left of the page

D to the right of the page

Which graph shows how the voltage of a simple a.c. generator varies with time?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/f1f34c2e-16ee-42a5-ae36-c1ebc5f7d214.png)

![diagram](./assets/2c56d4fe-4a65-4b9d-9129-9a8a4c5b6347.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/fe868b3f-944d-47d7-96ea-fa76996e9068.png)

![diagram](./assets/5d11ad3d-b2aa-4065-b28d-cc3c6c3ecb13.png)

Which row shows a use of a capacitor and a use of a relay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & use of a capacitor & use of a relay \\
\hline A & switching circuit & voltage transformation \\
B & time-delay circuit & switching circuit \\
C & voltage transformation & switching circuit \\
D & voltage transformation & time-delay circuit \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A student connects the circuit shown.

![diagram](./assets/8559240d-251b-40fd-a0de-294029b1c464.png)

Which switches must be closed for the bell to ring without lighting the lamp?

A 1 and 2 only

B 1 and 3 only

C 1,3 and 4 only

D 2, 3 and 4 only

Which of these is an electric current?

A a beam of atoms

B a beam of electrons

C a beam of molecules

D a beam of neutrons

Some electrical devices require a magnet which may be switched on and off many times in a
 second.

Which type of magnet may be used?

A an electromagnet only

B a permanent magnet only

C either a permanent magnet or an electromagnet

D neither a permanent magnet nor an electromagnet

A girl notices that when she shouts into a cave she hears an echo.

Which wave property causes the echo?

A diffraction

B dispersion

C reflection

D refraction

A thin converging lens forms an image.

![diagram](./assets/0d991d19-a2b6-49da-99c3-444733937655.png)

What is the nature of this image and can it be formed on a screen?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & nature of image & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { can be formed } \\
\text { on a screen? }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & not real & no \\
B & not real & yes \\
C & real & no \\
D & real & yes \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A night storage heater contains a large block of material that is heated electrically during the
 night. During the day the block cools down, releasing thermal energy into the room.

![diagram](./assets/15341c42-a038-49a0-8709-cadc031356c7.png)


Which thermal capacity and which night-time temperature increase will cause the most energy to
 be stored by the block?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { thermal capacity } \\
\text { of block }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { night-time } \\
\text { temperature increase }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & large & large \\
B & large & small \\
C & small & large \\
D & small & small \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The graph shows the temperature of a substance as it is heated steadily.

In which part of the graph is the substance boiling?

![diagram](./assets/544c46c8-30c9-4dd9-bfd7-1af5306e0f4b.png)

A skier walks from the bottom of a ski slope to the top and gains \( 10000 \mathrm{~J} \) of gravitational potential
 energy.

She skis down the slope. At the bottom of the slope, her kinetic energy is \( 2000 \mathrm{~J} \).

![diagram](./assets/0f87819c-005a-4b28-93da-c02061ed9c4e.png)

How much energy was converted into thermal energy and sound energy as the skier moved
 down the slope?

A \( 2000 \mathrm{~J} \)

B \( 8000 \mathrm{~J} \)

C \( 10000 \mathrm{~J} \)

D \( 12000 \mathrm{~J} \)

A power station uses nuclear fission to obtain energy.

In this process, nuclear energy is first changed into

A chemical energy.

B electrical energy.

C gravitational energy.

D thermal (heat) energy.

The speed-time graph shown is for a bus travelling between stops.

Where on the graph is the acceleration of the bus greatest?

![diagram](./assets/ef7aeba8-946b-44c1-8b2d-88260a420768.png)

A pendulum is set in motion and timed. The time measured for 20 complete swings is \( 30 \mathrm{~s} \).

What is the time for one complete swing of the pendulum?

A \( 0.67 \mathrm{~s} \)

B \( 0.75 \mathrm{~s} \)

C \( 1.5 \mathrm{~s} \)

D \( 3.0 \mathrm{~s} \)

The nuclide symbol for radioactive polonium is \( { }_{84}^{210} \mathrm{Po} \).

A nucleus of this type of polonium emits an \( \alpha \)-particle.

What is the proton number (atomic number) of the nucleus after it has emitted the \( \alpha \)-particle?

A 82

B 83

C 84

D 85
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
A step-up transformer is used before electricity is transmitted by overhead cables.

Which statement explains why the step-up transformer is used?

A It increases the current to increase the speed at which the electricity travels.

B It increases the current to reduce energy loss in the cables.

C It increases the voltage to increase the speed at which the electricity travels.

D It increases the voltage to reduce energy loss in the cables.

What is the circuit symbol for a variable resistor?

A

B

C

D

\( \square \)

![diagram](./assets/43290274-8263-4ac8-a812-8d01d268f57b.png)

![diagram](./assets/271f5dcd-48d1-48fe-a7db-5f5e7d1c6392.png)

![diagram](./assets/f5206b07-d9e4-4506-ab22-a61aa960f138.png)

A student draws a diagram representing three rays of light from point \( P \) passing through a
 converging lens. Each point labelled \( F \) is a principal focus of the lens.

![diagram](./assets/0bb4c8db-dca3-47e6-94f2-78a5734268a6.png)

Which of the rays has the student drawn correctly?

A ray \( X \) and ray \( Y \)

\( B \) ray \( X \) and ray \( Z \)

C ray \( Y \) only

D ray \( Z \) only

The air in a room is heated by a heater. The diagram shows the circulation of the air in the room.

![diagram](./assets/7ebe7d9b-559d-4c3d-8640-3150bde4712d.png)

Which statement about the air that is heated is correct?

A The air contracts and becomes less dense.

B The air contracts and becomes more dense.

C The air expands and becomes less dense.

D The air expands and becomes more dense.

The same quantity of thermal (heat) energy is given to two objects \( X \) and \( Y \). The temperature rise
 of object \( X \) is less than the temperature rise of object \( Y \).

What accounts for this difference?

A \( \mathrm{X} \) has a larger thermal capacity than \( \mathrm{Y} \).

B \( \mathrm{X} \) is a better thermal conductor than \( \mathrm{Y} \).

C Y has a larger thermal capacity than \( \mathrm{X} \).

D \( \mathrm{Y} \) is a better thermal conductor than \( \mathrm{X} \).

A circular metal disc is heated.

Which quantity decreases?

A its density

B its diameter

C its thickness

D its volume

A cylinder of constant volume contains a fixed mass of gas. The gas is cooled.

What happens to the pressure of the gas and what happens to the kinetic energy of the gas
 molecules?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & pressure of gas & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { kinetic energy } \\
\text { of molecules }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A heavy beam rests on two supports. The diagram shows the only three forces \( F_{1}, F_{2} \) and \( F_{3} \)
 acting on the beam.

![diagram](./assets/d8c91cbf-30c4-4b94-b654-583b39a25545.png)

The beam is in equilibrium.

Which statement is correct?

A All the forces are equal in size.

B The resultant force on the beam is in the opposite direction to the resultant turning effect.

C The resultant force on the beam is zero and the resultant turning effect on the beam is zero.

D The total upward force is twice the total downward force.

The graph represents the motion of a car.

![diagram](./assets/8d6fadde-ba66-4ca3-b903-863ec72a6561.png)

What is the distance travelled by the car while it is moving at a constant speed?

A \( 100 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 150 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 250 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 300 \mathrm{~m} \)

The diagram shows a box used for storing radioactive sources.

![diagram](./assets/68db50a9-2e0f-48ba-b0b1-c596811bf54f.png)

Which material is best for lining the box to prevent the escape of most radioactive emissions?

A aluminium

B copper

C lead

D steel

The current in a lamp at full brightness is \( 0.25 \mathrm{~A} \). The flexible cable to the lamp is designed for
 currents up to \( 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \), so it can safely carry the \( 0.25 \mathrm{~A} \) taken by the lamp.

Which fuse should be inserted in the plug at the other end of the flexible cable?

A \( 0.2 \mathrm{~A} \)

B \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

C \( 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

D \( 10.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

Either a fuse or a circuit-breaker can be used to protect electrical cables from large currents that
 could cause overheating.

![diagram](./assets/c865a2a7-29d0-4227-8208-151b2cc2c47f.png)
 appliance

If a fuse is used, in which position in the circuit should it be connected, and if a circuit-breaker is
 used, in which position should it be connected?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { position } \\
\text { of fuse }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { position of } \\
\text { circuit-breaker }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & X & X \\
B & X & Y \\
C & Y & X \\
D & Y & Y \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Using the circuit shown, the current \( I \) is found for various voltages \( V \). The temperature of the
 resistor does not change.

variable direct

![diagram](./assets/4d24e452-718b-4c0e-8893-560183bce4b3.png)

Which graph shows the results obtained?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/f4e70902-38ed-4a54-8411-916c50aa9ede.png)

![diagram](./assets/1f580e76-8670-439b-b38f-9f9e24b70422.png)

![diagram](./assets/2a54b5fe-2986-4582-9008-2b78a69f2c3d.png)

![diagram](./assets/5c01f5ff-8298-4983-9be1-ae7e2bf1b232.png)

Which particle does not experience a force due to an electric field?

A \( \alpha \)-particle

B electron

C neutron

D proton

An electromagnet is used to separate magnetic metals from non-magnetic metals.

Why is steel unsuitable as the core of the electromagnet?

A It forms a permanent magnet.

B It has a high density.

C It has a high thermal capacity.

D It is a good conductor of electricity.

The diagram shows a fire.

Why does the smoke rise above the fire?

A Smoke evaporates more quickly at higher temperatures.

B Smoke molecules diffuse more quickly at higher temperatures.

C The density of the air is lower at higher temperatures.

D The pressure of the air is greater at higher temperatures.

A piston traps a certain mass of gas inside a cylinder. Initially the piston is halfway along the
 length of the cylinder.


The piston is now moved towards the open end of the cylinder. The temperature of the gas
 remains constant.

initial position

![diagram](./assets/6352ab62-c369-44fd-bf0a-28e31b2dd7ae.png)

final position

How are the density and the pressure of the gas affected by moving the piston?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & density & pressure \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & unchanged \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & unchanged \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which items of apparatus are required to determine the density of a liquid?

A balance and measuring cylinder

B balance and thermometer

C metre rule and measuring cylinder

D metre rule and thermometer

The table shows the weight in newtons of a \( 10 \mathrm{~kg} \) mass on each of four planets.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline planet & weight of a \( 10 \mathrm{~kg} \) mass \( / \mathrm{N} \) \\
\hline Earth & 100 \\
Jupiter & 250 \\
Mercury & 40 \\
Venus & 90 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a force meter (spring balance) being used.

![diagram](./assets/8ba0c5a3-de3d-4724-b787-7ce8cddb4fa4.png)

On which planet is the force meter (spring balance) being used?

A Earth

B Jupiter

C Mercury

D Venus

The diagram shows a radioactive source, a thick aluminium sheet and a radiation detector.

![diagram](./assets/22e5c1ee-10d8-4fb4-bf57-2eaa54bbc56d.png)

The radiation detector shows a reading greater than the background reading.

Which type of radiation is being emitted by the source and detected by the detector?

A \( \alpha \)-radiation

B \( \beta \)-radiation

C \( \gamma \)-radiation

D infra-red radiation

A permanent magnet is made from metal and an electromagnet uses a metal core.

Which metal is suitable for each of these purposes?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { permanent } \\
\text { magnet }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { core of } \\
\text { electromagnet }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & iron & iron \\
B & iron & steel \\
C & steel & iron \\
D & steel & steel \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Light waves pass from air into glass and are refracted.

What always remains constant when this happens?

A direction

B frequency

C speed

D wavelength

An electric field is set up between two parallel plates.

Cathode rays are directed into this field, parallel to the plates.

![diagram](./assets/a413715f-da88-4cd9-a0d0-0d73bcceb20c.png)

In which direction are the cathode rays deflected by the electric field?

A downwards

B upwards

C into the page

D out of the page

Some electrical equipment is connected to a \( 230 \mathrm{~V} \) supply. It is kept inside a metal case which is
 not earthed. The case is fixed to a plastic support. A strand of wire has become loose and
 touches the metal case as shown.

![diagram](./assets/72cf039a-aa15-4d57-a30d-a1b33ca8154d.png)

metal case on plastic support

strand of wire

Which statement about this situation is correct?

A An electric current is passing through the metal case.

B A fuse in the live wire will blow.

C Someone touching the case would receive an electric shock.

D The metal case is at \( 0 \mathrm{~V} \).

The potential divider shown is connected across a constant \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) supply.

![diagram](./assets/e131ae8e-b656-4898-bbaa-7dda799c3041.png)

When \( R \) has a value of \( 20 \Omega \), the voltmeter readings are equal.

How do these readings change when the value of \( R \) is reduced to \( 10 \Omega \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & reading on \( V_{1} \) & reading on \( V_{2} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A circuit contains two resistors connected in parallel with a battery.

![diagram](./assets/59b11e7c-db3c-4cf5-9926-744cbac776c5.png)

Which of the following statements about the currents at \( P, Q \) and \( R \) is true?

A The current at \( P \) is the greatest.

B The current at \( Q \) is the greatest.

C The current at \( R \) is the greatest.

D The current is the same at points \( P, Q \) and \( R \).

A beaker containing ice and a thermometer is left in a warm room for 15 minutes.

No water is visible in the beaker until 5 minutes has passed. After 15 minutes some ice is still
 visible.

![diagram](./assets/7e4e55c0-6c7b-49ca-85f7-b42e06f79d13.png)

Which graph shows how the thermometer reading changes?

![diagram](./assets/8bedb154-6c62-4859-817d-c98047ef93a1.png)

![diagram](./assets/a6c4c1ce-8eea-48b7-930e-bfb3f15779f5.png)

![diagram](./assets/7dae1713-269a-40df-b6b1-625c14fc161d.png)

![diagram](./assets/fb30c8f4-5e1e-4399-9122-c36b3e688ca4.png)

Some gas in a sealed plastic bag is cooled.

How do the gas molecules behave when this happens?

A They move more quickly and become closer together.

B They move more quickly and become further apart.

C They move more slowly and become closer together.

D They move more slowly and become further apart.

body:
An electric heater is placed inside a metal box which has one side open. The diagram shows four
 possible positions for the box.

The heater is switched on for several minutes.

In which position does the box become the hottest?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/5ea720c8-137a-4ecb-9f08-0708601efa35.png)

![diagram](./assets/c7937c84-2fdc-4f3b-8cb4-7b2aae9048b5.png)

A car is driven on a long journey along a flat, horizontal road. The car stops several times on the
 journey and its engine becomes hot.

Which type of energy does not change during the journey?

A the chemical energy in the fuel tank

B the gravitational energy of the car

C the internal (thermal) energy of the engine

D the kinetic energy of the car

A force acts on a moving rubber ball.

Which of these changes could not happen to the ball because of the force?

A a change in direction

B a change in mass

C a change in shape

D a change in speed

Which list contains the name of a force?

A acceleration, charge, temperature

B density, resistance, speed

C distance, frequency, mass

D energy, power, weight

The diagram shows the speed/time graph for an object moving at constant speed.

![diagram](./assets/fe26536c-a3ea-48b5-b871-9f96852524b4.png)

What is the distance travelled by the object in the first 3 s?

A \( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 2.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 3.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 6.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

What is a simple mercury barometer designed to measure?

A the pressure beneath a liquid

B the pressure of a gas supply

C the pressure of car tyres

D the pressure of the atmosphere

A beam of cathode rays passes between two charged metal plates.

![diagram](./assets/24d50a03-ecd3-4678-9c13-6262689dba92.png)

What happens to the beam as it passes between the plates?

A It is deflected into the paper.

B It is deflected out of the paper.

C It is deflected towards the negative plate.

D It is deflected towards the positive plate.

A toy railway engine is driven around a track by a d.c. electric motor.

How can the speed of the motor be increased?

A Use a motor made with fewer turns of wire.

B Use a smaller d.c. voltage.

C Use a stronger magnet in the motor.

D Use the supply with its connections reversed.

A student wants to make a transformer to step \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) down to \( 6.0 \mathrm{~V} \).

She winds 60 turns of wire around an iron core as shown in the diagram.

![diagram](./assets/b38bcdf4-762f-4fd8-bbc8-f1908e67e533.png)

How many turns of wire should she wind on the secondary coil of her transformer?

A 5

B 30

C 60

D 120

Which group contains only good electrical conductors?

A air, carbon (graphite), plastic

B air, gold, mercury

C carbon (graphite), copper, mercury

D copper, gold, plastic

An electronic engineer makes devices which can receive television pictures from satellites.

Which type of electromagnetic radiation must these devices be able to receive?

A infra-red waves

B microwaves

C radio waves

D ultra-violet waves

Which group of electromagnetic radiations is arranged in order of increasing frequency?

A infra-red, visible light, ultraviolet

B \( \gamma \)-rays, X-rays, infra-red

C ultra-violet, visible light, radio waves

D X-rays, radio waves, \( \gamma \)-rays

The diagram represents a wave.

![diagram](./assets/8e5b738e-77e5-4331-b482-5f8d80861c7e.png)

How many wavelengths are there between \( X \) and \( Y \) ?

A \( \quad \frac{2}{3} \)

B 1

C \( 1 \frac{1}{2} \)

D 3

The diagram shows the surface of water in a ripple tank. A wave is travelling in the direction of
 the arrow towards a gap in a barrier.

![diagram](./assets/93d349c1-a1d5-40ea-9ee9-c0f2898b0d8c.png)


What happens to the wave as it passes through the gap, and what happens to the shape of the
 wavefronts after passing through the gap?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { what happens } \\
\text { at the gap }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { shape after passing } \\
\text { through the gap }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & diffraction & curved \\
B & diffraction & straight \\
C & refraction & curved \\
D & refraction & straight \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a refrigerator.

The cooling unit is placed at the top. The cooling unit cools the air near it.

![diagram](./assets/40ca267c-15a2-4dfa-a6bb-3b6118f124c5.png)

What happens to the density of the air as it cools, and how does it move?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & density of the air & movement of the air \\
\hline A & decreases & moves down \\
B & decreases & stays at the top \\
C & increases & moves down \\
D & increases & stays at the top \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which statement about the transfer of thermal energy is correct?

A Convection can occur in air, but only when the air is trapped.

B Convection can only occur in a gas.

C Radiation cannot occur in air.

D Radiation can occur in a vacuum, but convection cannot.

![diagram](./assets/33e868c5-bb47-4539-9f98-20d6a9fee9fe.png)

D \( 95 \mathrm{~mm} \) of mercury

A an electron

B a neutron

A \( 0 \mathrm{mg} \)

B \( 40 \mathrm{mg} \)

D \( 200 \mathrm{mg} \)

aluminium

silver

iron

plastic

A aluminium

B copper

Viewed through a microscope, very small particles can be seen moving with Brownian motion.

\text { of particles }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { particles are } \\

\hline

A farmer has two carts. The carts have the same weight, but one has four narrow wheels and the
 other has four wide wheels.

narrow wheel

wide wheel

B & narrow & less pressure on the ground \\
C & wide & greater pressure on the ground \\

\hline
\end{tabular}

A capacitor

A keeping the material a long distance from people

proton 0

(+)

positive

nucleus

mercury & \( -39 \) \\

Two workers are stacking cans on to a shelf in a shop. The workers lift the same number of
 identical cans on to the same shelf from the same level.

Worker P takes \( 3.0 \) minutes to lift the cans. Worker Q takes \( 4.0 \) minutes to lift the cans.

Which statement about the workers is correct?

A Worker \( P \) develops less useful power than worker \( Q \).

B Worker P develops more useful power than worker \( Q \).

C Worker \( P \) does less useful work than worker \( Q \).

D Worker P does more useful work than worker Q.

The diagram shows a wire in the magnetic field between two poles of a magnet.

![diagram](./assets/edda25f7-81b9-4a54-9d73-49a10a1ca476.png)

The current in the wire repeatedly changes between a constant value in one direction and a
 constant value in the opposite direction. This is shown on the graph.

![diagram](./assets/f35f3fbf-78a2-43b2-95f7-a32a1dd1075e.png)

What is the effect on the wire?

A The force on the wire alternates between one direction and the opposite direction.

B The force on the wire is constant in size and direction.

C There is no force acting on the wire at any time.

D There is only a force on the wire when the current reverses.

 voltmeter \( P \)

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & reading on \( \mathrm{P} \) & reading on \( \mathrm{Q} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What information does this give about the amplitude and the frequency of the sound wave

\hline A & too large & too large \\
B & too large & too small \\
C & too small & too large \\
D & too small & too small \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

back of
 mirror

D

The diagram shows cathode rays entering an electric field between two charged plates.

How does the path of the cathode rays change and why?

A They move towards the negative plate because cathode rays have a negative charge.

B They move towards the negative plate because cathode rays have a positive charge.

C They move towards the positive plate because cathode rays have a negative charge.

D They move towards the positive plate because cathode rays have a positive charge.

A current-carrying coil in a magnetic field experiences a turning effect.

![diagram](./assets/c9f359fc-8807-4ab2-bfb6-95a4b4411620.png)

How can the turning effect be increased?

A Increase the number of turns on the coil.

B Reduce the size of the current.

![diagram](./assets/bc15a544-6048-4da1-b1d2-bb54b1d796cd.png)

- The current in the wire \( X Y \) is reversed.

- The magnetic field is reversed.

 time.

A 0

B 1

C 2

D 3

C The reading on \( Q \) is greater than the reading on \( P \).

D The reading on \( Q \) is greater than the reading on \( R \).

Four students are each given an identical resistor and asked to find its resistance. They each

One student makes a mistake.

\hline

B & no & yes \\
C & yes & no \\
D & yes & yes \\
\hline

![diagram](./assets/1b92da09-5ef0-4413-822a-aa31dea70214.png)

\text { refracted? }\end{array} \) \\

 diameters. The rods are heated at one end, in the same way.

\( \mathrm{Q} \) & 30 \\
\( \mathrm{R} \) & 45 \\

A metal P

![diagram](./assets/7445c835-b5dd-449b-8b9f-1b6a6f285591.png)

A the area of the shaded face and the volume of the block

B the area of the shaded face and the weight of the block

D the mass of the block and the volume of the block

An input voltage of \( 10 \mathrm{~V} \) is supplied to the primary coil of a transformer. An output voltage of \( 40 \mathrm{~V} \)
 is produced across the secondary coil.

The \( 10 \mathrm{~V} \) supply at the primary coil is now replaced with a \( 40 \mathrm{~V} \) supply.

What is the new output voltage across the secondary coil?

A \( 10 \mathrm{~V} \)

B \( 40 \mathrm{~V} \)

C \( 70 \mathrm{~V} \)

D \( 160 \mathrm{~V} \)

When a wire is moved upwards between the poles of a magnet, an electromotive force (e.m.f.) is
 induced across the ends of the wire.

![diagram](./assets/fc52c130-d5e8-4f10-b74b-efaa9cca4ce7.png)

Which device uses a moving wire to induce an e.m.f.?

A a cathode-ray tube

B a generator

C a transformer

D an electromagnet

The list contains three energy resources \( P, Q \) and \( R \).

P geothermal energy from hot rocks

Q nuclear fission in reactors

R sunlight on solar panels

Which of these resources are renewable?

A \( P \) and \( Q \) only

B \( P \) and \( R \) only

C \( Q \) and \( R \) only

D \( P, Q \) and \( R \)

![diagram](./assets/4c258f9f-1d61-412a-841f-552475b5e1a2.png)

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & water level at \( P \) & water level at \( Q \) \\
\hline A & falls & falls \\
B & falls & rises \\
C & rises & falls \\
D & rises & rises \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The mass of an astronaut is \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \) on the Moon.

What is the mass of the astronaut on the Earth?

A \( 7 \mathrm{~kg} \)

B \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( 80 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D \( 700 \mathrm{~kg} \)

 left-hand pan and various weights are put in the right-hand pan.

![diagram](./assets/f274afcf-e0c8-43ad-93ae-8315eb7248b9.png)

These are the results.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline weights in the right-hand pan & effect \\
\hline \( 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.05 \mathrm{~N}, 0.02 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the left-hand side \\
\hline \( 0.2 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.01 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the right-hand side \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What is the best estimate of the weight of the object?

A \( 0.27 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( 0.29 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 0.31 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 0.58 \mathrm{~N} \)

Diagram 1 shows a measuring cylinder containing water.

Five identical steel balls are now lowered into the measuring cylinder. Diagram 2 shows the new
 water level in the cylinder.

![diagram](./assets/17f18957-9f7d-4b74-912e-0181bbf76789.png)

diagram 1

diagram 2

A \( 6 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

B \( 14 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

C \( 30 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

D \( 70 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

Which statement is true of all neutral atoms?

A The number of electrons equals the number of nucleons.

B The number of neutrons equals the number of protons.

C The number of nucleons equals the number of neutrons.

D The number of protons equals the number of electrons.

Which line in the table describes the nature of an \( \alpha \)-particle and of a \( \gamma \)-ray?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \alpha \)-particle & \( \gamma \)-ray \\
\hline A & helium nucleus & electromagnetic radiation \\
B & helium nucleus & electron \\
C & proton & electromagnetic radiation \\
D & proton & electron \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

B \( N / 2 \)

\( S \) is a radioactive source emitting \( \alpha \)-particles, \( \beta \)-particles and \( \gamma \)-rays. A detector is placed \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \)

diagram 1

& a low temperature & quickly from a hot liquid \\

C \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D greater than \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

A student investigates how the radiation from a radioactive source changes with time.

The table shows the results from the detector used by the student.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

How does the wool help the sheep to stay warm?

A Air can circulate between the wool fibres and heat up the skin by convection.

B Air trapped by the wool fibres reduces heat losses from the skin by convection.

C The wool fibres are curly so it takes longer for heat to be conducted away from the skin.

D The wool fibres conduct heat to the skin from the air outside.

A the height of the platform above the ground

B the number of boxes lifted

C the time taken to lift the boxes

D the weight of the boxes

A pendulum is set in motion and timed. The time measured for 20 complete swings is \( 30 \mathrm{~s} \).

What is the time for one complete swing of the pendulum?

A \( 0.67 \mathrm{~s} \)

B \( 0.75 \mathrm{~s} \)

C \( 1.5 \mathrm{~s} \)

D \( 3.0 \mathrm{~s} \)

A beam of cathode rays passes between two parallel metal plates connected to a high-voltage
 d.c. power supply.

Which path does the beam follow?

C & \( \alpha \) less than \( \beta \) & \( \alpha \) greater than \( \beta \) \\
D & \( \alpha \) less than \( \beta \) & \( \alpha \) less than \( \beta \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

An ammeter and an \( 18 \Omega \) resistor are connected in series with a battery. The reading on the
 ammeter is \( 0.50 \mathrm{~A} \). The resistance of the battery and the ammeter can be ignored.

![diagram](./assets/5965d75e-1d93-4fae-aff9-ed63ef33ee26.png)

A \( 9.0 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( 9.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

D \( 36 \mathrm{~V} \)

A student listens to a machine that makes sounds of different frequencies. He can only hear one
 of the sounds.

Which frequency of sound is the student able to hear?

A \( 2 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

B \( 10 \mathrm{~Hz} \)

C \( 2 \mathrm{kHz} \)

D \( 30 \mathrm{kHz} \)

Which energy resource is used to generate electricity by first boiling water?

A hydroelectric

B nuclear fission

D waves

barometer 1 , day 1

barometer 2 , day 2

B The atmospheric pressure on day 1 is the same as the atmospheric pressure on day 2.

C The pressure at point \( X \) is less than the pressure at point \( Y \).

D The pressure at point \( \mathrm{X} \) is the same as the pressure at point \( Y \).

A sealed gas cylinder is left outside on a hot, sunny day.

What happens to the average speed of the molecules and to the pressure of the gas in the

\text { the gas molecules }\end{array} \) & gas pressure \\
\hline A & falls & falls \\
B & falls & rises \\
C & rises & falls \\
D & rises & rises \\

\end{tabular}

power supply

A The image is real.

B The image is left to right (laterally inverted).

C The image is smaller than the object.

D The image is upside down.

cylinder 1

cylinder 2

The blocks are now allowed to cool back to room temperature.

Block \( Y \) has a greater thermal capacity than block \( X \).

 container

body:
A student carries out an experiment to find the melting point of wax. The graph shows how the
 temperature of the wax changes as it cools.

![diagram](./assets/188fd1d0-be8f-45fa-9c5d-dcb44cb72364.png)

Which statement is correct?

A At \( X \) the temperature drops more slowly than at \( Z \).

B At \( Y \) all the wax is solid.

C At \( Y \) thermal energy is being given out by the wax.

D At \( Z \) the wax molecules are not moving.

A liquid is left in an open dish. After several days there is less liquid in the dish.

Which statement explains this?

A The least energetic molecules leave the surface and escape into the air.

B The least energetic molecules leave the surface and return.

C The most energetic molecules leave the surface and escape into the air.

D The most energetic molecules leave the surface and return.

A They expand.

B They hit the walls less often.

C They move further apart.

Which type of energy is stored in each of them?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\end{tabular}

D They have the same weight and the same volume but different masses.

\( 4.0 \) & 40 \\
\( 8.0 \) & \\
\hline

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { half-life } \\
\text { /hours }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { rate of emission at } 8.0 \text { hours } \\

A mains electrical circuit uses insulated copper cable and the cable overheats.

To prevent the cable overheating, how should the cable be changed, and why?

A Use thicker copper cable which has less resistance.

B Use thicker insulation which stops the heat escaping.

C Use thinner copper cable which has more resistance.

D Use thinner insulation which allows less heat to escape.

A householder asks an electrician to install a mains electrical socket in her bathroom so that she
 may use a hairdryer there. The electrician refuses to do this because it would be dangerous.

Why would installing the socket be dangerous?

A The current drawn by the hairdryer would cause overheating in the cables.

B The handling of electrical equipment in damp conditions could cause an electric shock.

C The hot air produced by the hairdryer would cause the fuse to melt.

D The temperature in the bathroom would damage the insulation.

A The molecules expand.

B The molecules increase in mass.

C The molecules move further apart.

B nuclear fuel \( \rightarrow \) generator \( \rightarrow \) turbines \( \rightarrow \) reactor and boiler

D nuclear fuel \( \rightarrow \) reactor and boiler \( \rightarrow \) turbines \( \rightarrow \) generator

D strain energy and heat energy

The diagram shows a coil connected to a battery and a switch. Two unmagnetised iron bars hang
 freely near opposite ends of the coil.

![diagram](./assets/c50ec02a-0343-4dd7-a575-1564560550cc.png)

![diagram](./assets/422693c8-98be-43b0-ac24-0460e9c9ba40.png)

What happens to the iron bars when the switch is closed?

A Both \( X \) and \( Y \) move away from the coil.

B Both \( X \) and \( Y \) move towards the coil.

C \( X \) moves towards the coil, \( Y \) moves away from the coil.

D \( Y \) moves towards the coil, \( X \) moves away from the coil.

Which row correctly describes light waves and radio waves?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & light waves & radio waves \\
\hline A & longitudinal & longitudinal \\
B & longitudinal & transverse \\
C & transverse & longitudinal \\
D & transverse & transverse \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The molecules of a substance become more closely packed and move more quickly.

What is happening to the substance?

A A gas is being heated and compressed.

B A gas is being heated and is expanding.

C A liquid is boiling.

D A liquid is evaporating at room temperature.
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
In a race, a car travels 60 times around a \( 3.6 \mathrm{~km} \) track. This takes \( 2.4 \) hours.

What is the average speed of the car?

A \( 1.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

B \( 90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

C \( 144 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

D \( 216 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)

The diagram shows a torch containing two \( 2 \mathrm{~V} \) cells, a switch and a lamp.

![diagram](./assets/47c3b5f4-1907-423d-b2c3-8623681ad6b5.png)

What is the circuit diagram for the torch?

![diagram](./assets/90db95f6-8553-4dc9-9843-89843cd9cd9c.png)

![diagram](./assets/f7260e5c-43e0-4206-8b89-12d2f89b9493.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/41692580-0f7f-4a4d-8d0f-26c54d901c55.png)

![diagram](./assets/8b3ee5b2-2989-4939-9f54-68343ed1a9eb.png)

![diagram](./assets/af02d9a9-40f3-4f90-8a1e-b1d3b2bb8062.png)

Which switches must be closed to light only lamps 1 and 3 ?

A switch 1 only

B switch 1 and switch 2 only

C switch 1 and switch 3 only

D switch 2 and switch 3 only

An electrical component is to be placed in the circuit at \( Z \), to allow the brightness of the lamp to
 be varied from bright to dim.

![diagram](./assets/a7c720de-622c-4986-aca6-7ea824b09561.png)

What should be connected at \( Z \) ?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/a57f937c-4362-4590-8998-1ae1de82786c.png)

![diagram](./assets/2927af13-587d-4353-b8cd-d0ec526b824e.png)

A vertical stick is dipped up and down in water at \( P \). In two seconds, three wave crests are
 produced on the surface of the water.

![diagram](./assets/293017a1-51f6-4cc2-818a-fcb305d80db3.png)

Which statement is true?

A Distance \( X \) is the amplitude of the waves.

B Distance \( Y \) is the wavelength of the waves.

C Each circle represents a wavefront.

D The frequency of the waves is \( 3 \mathrm{~Hz} \).

Water waves change direction when they move from shallow water to deep water.

![diagram](./assets/56b44d06-feaa-441a-aeb8-9c26286c22a1.png)

What is the name of this effect?

A diffraction

B dispersion

C reflection

D refraction

Thermometer \( \mathrm{X} \) is held above an ice cube and thermometer \( \mathrm{Y} \) is held the same distance below
 the ice cube. After several minutes, the reading on one thermometer changes. The ice cube does
 not melt.

thermometer \( \mathrm{X} \)

ice cube-

thermometer \( Y \)

Which thermometer reading changes and why?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & thermometer & reason \\
\hline A & X & cool air rises from the ice cube \\
B & X & warm air rises from the ice cube \\
C & Y & cool air falls from the ice cube \\
D & Y & warm air falls from the ice cube \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A student places his thumb firmly on the outlet of a bicycle pump, to stop the air coming out.

![diagram](./assets/39e469b3-8377-4f44-9041-6fc5aec37fd9.png)

What happens to the pressure and to the volume of the trapped air as the pump handle is pushed
 in?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & pressure & volume \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & remains the same \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & remains the same \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a man diving into water.

![diagram](./assets/cc7e6b98-f42d-42ec-bbdc-ae5e94eccd9b.png)

Which form of energy is increasing as he falls?

A chemical

B gravitational

C kinetic

D strain

A small steel ball is dropped from a low balcony.

Ignoring air resistance, which statement describes its motion?

A It falls with constant acceleration.

B It falls with constant speed.

C It falls with decreasing acceleration.

D It falls with decreasing speed.

The diagram shows the speed-time graph for an object moving at constant speed.

![diagram](./assets/56f81d4c-0183-480d-a72f-a252d19b4e68.png)

What is the distance travelled by the object in the first \( 3 \mathrm{~s} \) ?

A \( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 2.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

C \( 3.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 6.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

Light from the Sun passes through a prism and a spectrum is produced on a screen.

![diagram](./assets/085eb72a-4212-4853-a2a5-4deae6b14095.png)

A thermometer placed at \( \mathrm{P} \) shows a large temperature rise.

Which type of radiation causes this?

A infra-red

B microwave

C ultra-violet

D visible light

Two sets of water waves overlap as shown in the diagram.

![diagram](./assets/c66314ca-8efa-4671-b5fe-77d42acf8480.png)

From which two points are the sets of waves coming?

A \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{S} \)

B \( T \) and \( R \)

C \( Q \) and \( T \)

D \( U \) and \( Q \)

The diagram represents water waves about to move into shallow water from deep water.

![diagram](./assets/f86e39ae-d09c-4105-a0ea-da795b2653be.png)

shallow water

Which property of the waves remains the same after the waves move into shallow water?

A frequency

B speed

C wavefront direction

D wavelength

A heater is placed in a room.

Which diagram shows the movement of air as the room is heated?

![diagram](./assets/193487a6-5bc6-457c-bd4c-940431fbde07.png)

![diagram](./assets/d82b658c-9a39-44bd-8ce8-37a7cb4c81b2.png)

\( \mathrm{C} \)

D

![diagram](./assets/859905cd-040e-4a72-bed9-df9b5d8daa84.png)

![diagram](./assets/a3b25cb7-c8f9-42f0-a1fe-21c5b6a91b78.png)

Four glass tanks contain water.

In which tank is the pressure of the water on the base greatest?

![diagram](./assets/487e6875-b06e-44aa-8a98-7eb46f177ff3.png)

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/be225f32-002d-4ad4-83d8-2c683e71fdd3.png)

![diagram](./assets/7d056318-b278-4842-8df5-ff75c23feef1.png)

![diagram](./assets/02ea9eb9-46ee-42f0-8c53-3ffd4a40bf14.png)

A manometer is used to indicate the pressure in a steel vessel, as shown in the diagram.

![diagram](./assets/67c36146-0715-4f75-8a5d-842a8f17d91d.png)

What value does the liquid manometer give for the pressure in the vessel?

A It is zero.

B It is between zero and atmospheric pressure.

C It is equal to atmospheric pressure.

D It is greater than atmospheric pressure.

The diagram shows an experiment to find the density of a liquid.

![diagram](./assets/c22c5758-d1b1-4dee-ba15-97cd20e0ac93.png)

What is the density of the liquid?

A \( \quad 0.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

B \( 2.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

C \( 8.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

D \( 10.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

The graph shows the decay curve for one particular radioactive nuclide.

![diagram](./assets/013dbd91-6aad-4673-b149-a942d3653a15.png)

What is the half-life of this nuclide?

A \( 1.0 \) day

B \( 1.5 \) days

C \( 2.0 \) days

D \( 2.5 \) days

A transformer has 50 turns on its primary coil and 100 turns on its secondary coil. An alternating
 voltage of \( 25.0 \mathrm{~V} \) is connected across the primary coil.

![diagram](./assets/42843f46-744b-4916-af79-d43f5d3d7024.png)

What is the voltage across the secondary coil?

A \( 12.5 \mathrm{~V} \)

B \( 50.0 \mathrm{~V} \)

C \( 175 \mathrm{~V} \)

D \( 200 \mathrm{~V} \)

An engineer standing at \( \mathrm{P} \) sees an explosion at \( \mathrm{X} \).

![diagram](./assets/fc89268c-03c2-4ed5-8870-7ea2054f18f0.png)

After the explosion, she hears two bangs. One bang is heard a fraction of a second after the
 other. The second bang is an echo.

From which surface has the sound reflected to cause this echo?

A \( X Y \)

B PV

C ZY

D WX

The diagrams show water waves which move more slowly after passing into shallow water at the
 broken line.

Which diagram shows what happens to the waves?

![diagram](./assets/bdafc323-40f3-4bb9-a8c0-9857cff9ab66.png)

In an experiment, some of a substance changes from a liquid to a gas. The temperature of the
 remaining liquid changes because of this.

What is the name for this change of state and how does the temperature change?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & change of state & how temperature changes \\
\hline A & condensation & decreases \\
B & condensation & increases \\
C & evaporation & decreases \\
D & evaporation & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

body:
A student fills two containers with water (density \( 1.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \) ) and two with oil(density \( 0.8 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \) ),
 as shown in the diagrams.

In which container is the pressure on the base the greatest?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/d363113c-4690-4354-a38c-84cc32e93fe3.png)

Four people of equal weight on a beach use different routes to get to the top of a sea wall.

![diagram](./assets/800ebb28-2838-48ef-a348-4cdd0ba97c14.png)

Which person produces the greatest average power?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline person & route & time taken \\
\hline A & runs across the beach, then climbs the ladder & \( 8 \mathrm{~s} \) \\
B & walks across the beach, then climbs the ladder & \( 16 \mathrm{~s} \) \\
C & runs up the slipway & \( 5 \mathrm{~s} \) \\
D & walks up the slipway & \( 10 \mathrm{~s} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which items of apparatus are required to determine the density of a liquid?

A balance and measuring cylinder

B balance and thermometer

C metre rule and measuring cylinder

D metre rule and thermometer

Cathode rays are emitted in a vacuum tube. They consist of particles that are found in atoms.

What is the name of the particles and how are the cathode rays produced?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & name of particles & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { how the cathode rays } \\
\text { are produced }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & electrons & electromagnetic induction \\
B & electrons & thermionic emission \\
C & protons & electromagnetic induction \\
D & protons & thermionic emission \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
The diagram shows an a.c. generator.

![diagram](./assets/23d64f65-fe97-4e59-b01e-9f191cd9d482.png)

With the coil in the position shown, the output voltage is \( +10 \mathrm{~V} \).

When does the output voltage become \( -10 \mathrm{~V} ? \)

A when the coil has turned \( 90^{\circ} \)

B when the coil has turned \( 180^{\circ} \)

C when the coil has turned \( 270^{\circ} \)

D when the coil has turned \( 360^{\circ} \)

A fuse and a relay each use an effect of an electric current.

Which effect of an electric current is used by a fuse and which effect is used by a relay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { effect used by } \\
\text { a fuse }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { effect used by } \\
\text { a relay }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & heating effect & heating effect \\
B & heating effect & magnetic effect \\
C & magnetic effect & heating effect \\
D & magnetic effect & magnetic effect \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a potential divider circuit with two identical lamps \( L_{1} \) and \( L_{2} \).

![diagram](./assets/5237a8d7-b004-4447-9ea7-db8960946a61.png)

The contact \( \mathrm{K} \) is halfway between \( \mathrm{X} \) and \( \mathrm{Y} \) and the lamps are equally bright.

What will happen to the brightness of the lamps when contact \( \mathrm{K} \) is moved a short distance
 towards \( \mathrm{X} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline & lamp \( L_{1} \) & lamp \( L_{2} \) \\
\hline A & brighter & brighter \\
B & brighter & dimmer \\
C & dimmer & brighter \\
D & dimmer & dimmer \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows an electric heater being used to heat a beaker of water and an identical
 beaker of oil for several minutes.

![diagram](./assets/68659862-c3e3-4b97-bf0c-53b80f9a9975.png)


The temperature of the water and the temperature of the oil increase constantly. The rise in
 temperature of the oil is much greater than that of the water.

Why is this?

A The oil has a higher boiling point than water.

B The oil has a higher thermal capacity than water.

C The oil has a lower boiling point than water.

D The oil has a lower thermal capacity than water.

Evaporation occurs when molecules escape from a liquid surface into the air above it. During this
 process the temperature of the liquid falls.

Why does the temperature of the liquid fall?

A The molecules in the vapour expand because the pressure is less.

B The molecules left in the liquid have more space to move around.

C The molecules move more slowly when they escape into the air.

D The molecules with the highest energies escape into the air.

To mark the lower fixed point of a Celsius scale on a thermometer, the thermometer should be
 placed in

A pure alcohol.

B pure distilled water.

C pure melting ice.

D pure mercury.

A chair is placed on protective cups to prevent damage to the carpet underneath it.

![diagram](./assets/56db9ce9-0a16-4f1d-826a-d59dfc78ceb4.png)

protective cups

How do the cups change the area of contact with the carpet and the pressure on it?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & area of contact & pressure \\
\hline A & decreased & decreased \\
B & decreased & increased \\
C & increased & decreased \\
D & increased & increased \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The pressure of a fixed mass of gas in a cylinder is measured. The volume of the gas in the
 cylinder is then slowly decreased. The temperature of the gas does not change.

Which graph could show the change of pressure of the gas during this process?

![diagram](./assets/e90b3c95-1859-46d2-b477-3e0459d47cad.png)

![diagram](./assets/0f719376-95e1-401c-b533-c10ddb8ce436.png)

![diagram](./assets/6c99937f-414a-4ac1-a27e-2b25c9a56894.png)

\( \mathrm{D} \)

![diagram](./assets/63317a37-3d89-4b57-b78d-93e4225aa45b.png)

A force \( F \) moves a load from the bottom of a slope to the top.

![diagram](./assets/e23a0289-c1a2-4817-8944-a37e6cdad6e7.png)

The work done by the force depends on the size of the force, and on a distance.

What is this distance?

A \( p \)

B \( q \)

C \( r \)

D \( p+q \)

A student adds weights to an elastic cord. He measures the length of the cord for each weight.

He then plots a graph from the results, as shown.

![diagram](./assets/bfdd8b3d-5abf-49fa-bbef-1abff8eb1bc5.png)

Which length has he plotted on the vertical axis?

A measured length

B original length

C (measured length - original length)

D (measured length + original length)

The diagram shows a radioactive source, a thick aluminium sheet and a radiation detector.

![diagram](./assets/b2828c1e-94ad-4248-8643-88b46a81ab94.png)

The radiation detector shows a reading greater than the background reading.

Which type of radiation is being emitted by the source and detected by the detector?

A \( \alpha \)-radiation

B \( \beta \)-radiation

C \( \gamma \)-radiation

D infra-red radiation

The diagram shows a simple transformer with an input of \( 240 \mathrm{~V} \) and an output of \( 40 \mathrm{~V} \).

There are 600 turns on the primary coil.

![diagram](./assets/79038c48-a840-401a-a1d1-ad9bc906ecc3.png)

How many turns are there on the secondary coil?

A 100

B \( \quad 320 \)

C 400

D 3600

The diagram shows a torch containing two cells, a switch and a lamp.

![diagram](./assets/a101f39a-8779-4d1f-83ad-57b320580a4e.png)

Which is the circuit diagram for the torch?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/eed609fb-6a79-4d01-a7c2-36ac8ecc1c47.png)

![diagram](./assets/650b0d38-ef64-4476-b051-fe1249d44250.png)

![diagram](./assets/79dc9f05-6c3b-4c76-9f20-c2b1061fd2f7.png)

![diagram](./assets/9d0ed1c8-a3bc-4ce0-b6e9-bff79452ae06.png)

A student carries out an experiment to investigate the resistance of a resistor \( \mathrm{R} \). She takes a
 series of readings of potential difference (p.d.) and current, and plots a graph of her results.

Which circuit should she use?

![diagram](./assets/095b7be9-0ec4-4b93-96f3-992b8f1fcc85.png)

![diagram](./assets/3b9d23f0-20b5-4ef7-bc0c-60889be973e3.png)

\( \mathrm{C} \)

\( \mathrm{D} \)

![diagram](./assets/c7ee4c43-4484-4322-ba6e-662c24cd8a22.png)

![diagram](./assets/b6547549-c6fc-4da0-a1a1-6e7e6fc8dfec.png)

Which row gives the unit for energy and the unit for electromotive force (e.m.f.)?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & energy & e.m.f. \\
\hline A & \( \mathrm{J} \) & \( \mathrm{N} \) \\
B & \( \mathrm{J} \) & \( \mathrm{V} \) \\
C & \( \mathrm{W} \) & \( \mathrm{N} \) \\
D & \( \mathrm{W} \) & \( \mathrm{V} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A permanent magnet is made from metal and an electromagnet uses a metal core.

Which metal is suitable for each of these purposes?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { permanent } \\
\text { magnet }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { core of } \\
\text { electromagnet }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & iron & iron \\
B & iron & steel \\
C & steel & iron \\
D & steel & steel \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The metal surface of a kettle is hot.

What happens to the cool air outside the kettle when it comes into contact with the hot kettle?

A The density of the air decreases and the air falls.

B The density of the air decreases and the air rises.

C The density of the air increases and the air falls.

D The density of the air increases and the air rises.

Which points are the fixed points of the liquid-in-glass thermometer shown?

![diagram](./assets/7f615c19-8c99-4a52-8f93-2313d2e9c374.png)

A the beginning and end points of the column of liquid

B the beginning and end points of the thermometer scale

C the points marked \( 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

D the top and bottom points of the thermometer bulb
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
A water manometer is connected to a gas supply.

![diagram](./assets/3bf0fa8f-5b96-4fc4-b5db-7a7ea02143d2.png)

There is a gas leak and the pressure of the gas supply falls.

What happens to the water level at \( \mathrm{P} \) and what happens to the water level at \( \mathrm{Q} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & water level at \( P \) & water level at \( Q \) \\
\hline A & falls & falls \\
B & falls & rises \\
C & rises & falls \\
D & rises & rises \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which movement will require the greatest amount of work to be done?

A a force of \( 10 \mathrm{~N} \) moving an object a distance of \( 3.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

B a force of \( 10 \mathrm{~N} \) moving an object a distance of \( 5.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

C a force of \( 15 \mathrm{~N} \) moving an object a distance of \( 3.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

D a force of \( 15 \mathrm{~N} \) moving an object a distance of \( 5.0 \mathrm{~m} \)

A student connects a variable potential divider (potentiometer) circuit.

![diagram](./assets/47425c2c-664d-4c77-999c-6a621feea41a.png)

What happens to the reading on the voltmeter as the sliding terminal \( T \) is moved from \( R \) to \( S \) ?

A It decreases from \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \) to \( 0 \mathrm{~V} \).

B It increases from \( 0 \mathrm{~V} \) to \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \).

C It remains at \( 0 \mathrm{~V} \).

D It remains at \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \).

A circuit-breaker is designed to protect a circuit which usually carries a current of \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \).

The time taken to break the circuit depends on the current, as shown in the graph.

![diagram](./assets/c961a5d9-c7da-4fa7-93b4-90f0c5fd86e3.png)

current/A

What happens when the current in the circuit is \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \) and what happens when the current \( 18 \mathrm{~A} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & when the current is \( 2 \mathrm{~A} \) & when the current is \( 18 \mathrm{~A} \) \\
\hline A & the circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds & the circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds \\
B & the circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds & the circuit does not break \\
C & the circuit does not break & the circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds \\
D & the circuit does not break & the circuit does not break \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

In which unit is potential difference measured?

A ampere

B ohm

C volt

D watt

Which circuit contains a fuse?

![diagram](./assets/f228fb87-6ef6-4acb-822a-8de75e42bd9f.png)

![diagram](./assets/cd4f66e7-a0c1-45bc-8cdf-38c0af99e4c4.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/7f10a3a4-12ce-4385-a30e-e8ea2d60800c.png)

![diagram](./assets/c76c4f20-2877-41d3-838d-6299798331d2.png)

What is the unit of wavelength?

A hertz

B metre

C metre per second

D second

A student draws three rays of light from point \( P \) through a converging lens.

Each point labelled \( F \) is a principal focus of the lens.

![diagram](./assets/517da840-53d1-400d-9e49-b517f3a725f9.png)

Which of the rays are drawn correctly?

A ray \( Y \) only

B ray \( Z \) only

C ray \( X \) and ray \( Y \)

D ray \( X \) and ray \( Z \)

The diagrams represent the waves produced by four sources of sound. The scales are the same
 for all the diagrams.

Which sound has the highest frequency?

![diagram](./assets/e00e7823-c418-422b-9db9-495828547312.png)

![diagram](./assets/168529f2-433e-4d78-aadc-f2da2e7262d6.png)

![diagram](./assets/8602f8ec-669f-4d9a-a282-9b209da92e66.png)

![diagram](./assets/89a3aff1-f7e4-461e-b524-064b3c2e4ee7.png)

In which pair of energy sources are both sources renewable?

A oil and coal

B oil and tidal

C tidal and geothermal

D tidal and nuclear fission

Which pair contains only physical quantities that vary with temperature and so could be used in
 making a thermometer?

A activity of a radioactive source, volume of a gas

B mass of a liquid, volume of a liquid

C activity of a radioactive source, mass of a solid

D volume of a gas, volume of a liquid

Passengers are not allowed to stand on the upper deck of double-decker buses.

![diagram](./assets/75a8a93b-f479-4489-9f80-27d9a4dd1020.png)

Why is this?

A They would cause the bus to become less stable.

B They would cause the bus to slow down.

C They would increase the kinetic energy of the bus.

D They would lower the centre of mass of the bus.

A stone has a volume of \( 0.50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \) and a mass of \( 2.0 \mathrm{~g} \).

What is the density of the stone?

A \( \quad 0.25 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

body:
Which statement is correct about the speed of electromagnetic waves in a vacuum?

A Ultra-violet waves have the greatest speed.

B Visible light waves have the greatest speed.

C Infra-red waves have the greatest speed.

D All electromagnetic waves have the same speed.

What causes refraction when light travels from air into glass?

A The amplitude of the light waves changes.

B The colour of the light changes.

C The frequency of the light waves changes.

D The speed of the light changes.

A person holds a glass beaker in one hand and fills it quickly with hot water. It takes several
 seconds before his hand starts to feel the heat.

Why is there this delay?

A Glass is a poor conductor of heat.

B Glass is a good conductor of heat.

C Water is a poor conductor of heat.

D Water is a good conductor of heat.

A labourer on a building site lifts heavy concrete blocks onto a lorry. Lighter blocks are now lifted
 the same distance in the same time.

What happens to the work done in lifting each block and the power exerted by the labourer?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { work done in } \\
\text { lifting each block }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { power exerted by } \\
\text { labourer }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & remains the same \\
C & increases & increases \\
D & remains the same & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

 race.

Which row shows the effect that a relay uses, together with one application of a relay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & effect used by a relay & one application of a relay \\
\hline A & heating effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
B & heating effect & changing the voltage of an alternating current \\
C & magnetic effect & allowing a small current to switch on a large current \\
D & magnetic effect & changing the voltage of an alternating current \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which copper wire would have the smallest resistance?

A a long, thick wire

B a long, thin wire

C a short, thick wire

D a short, thin wire

soft-iron rod soft-iron rod

\text { as shown }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { battery connections } \\
\text { reversed }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & rods attract & rods attract \\
B & rods attract & rods repel \\
C & rods repel & rods attract \\
D & rods repel & rods repel \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A Aluminium is a ferrous metal.

B A steel magnet can be demagnetised by heating it.

D The magnetic field lines around a bar magnet are evenly spaced.

sound wave 2

The diagram shows an experiment to demonstrate electromagnetic induction.

![diagram](./assets/775e80d1-a03d-4e68-8fb1-6c8ff7486fe7.png)

\( X \) and \( Y \) are joined, in turn, by four wires, each made of a different material.

Each wire is then moved quickly downwards between the magnets.

Which material will not give rise to an induced current in the wire?

A aluminium

B copper

C iron

D nylon

The diagram shows a mains transformer that has an output voltage of \( 12 \mathrm{~V} \).

![diagram](./assets/0acecc13-e21e-4c50-bad6-85e7ca276b4d.png)

How many turns of wire are in the secondary coil?

A 12

B 20

C 50

D 20000

A desk lamp should have a \( 3 \mathrm{~A} \) fuse fitted, but a \( 13 \mathrm{~A} \) fuse has been fitted by mistake.

The lamp is not faulty.

The lamp is switched on. What happens?

A The fuse blows.

B The fuse does not blow but the lamp does not light.

C The lamp draws too much current and the supply cables could melt.

D The lamp works normally.

The reading on the ammeter in the circuit is \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \).

A second ammeter is connected in the circuit. It also reads \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \).

At which labelled point is it connected?

![diagram](./assets/a05a634d-2917-4e97-85ba-901db90194f3.png)

Three charged balls, \( P, Q \) and \( R \) are suspended by insulating threads. Ball \( P \) is negatively
 charged.

Ball \( Q \) is brought close to ball \( P \).

![diagram](./assets/e6df90d2-13b2-4199-9645-4aba8c87116e.png)

![diagram](./assets/3645ee3b-17c0-42b7-ad35-9e4e0fe6aa3a.png)

Ball \( Q \) is now brought close to ball \( R \).

![diagram](./assets/49d67485-c2b4-4d15-91ec-a956000aeaa3.png)

What are the charges on ball \( Q \) and on ball \( R \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & ball \( Q \) & ball \( R \) \\
\hline A & positive & positive \\
B & positive & negative \\
C & negative & positive \\
D & negative & negative \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which diagram shows how a ray of light could pass through a glass block in air?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/529642ff-50cb-4039-a55b-cfb184a874ee.png)

![diagram](./assets/60deb5aa-5a59-4d03-b692-a58cab349dc7.png)

C

D

The diagram shows the cross-section of a vacuum flask containing a hot liquid in a cold room.
 \( X \) and \( Y \) are points on the inside surfaces of the walls of the flask.

![diagram](./assets/5dbd398d-1b3c-42ff-875f-0e79f97924c1.png)

How is thermal energy transferred between \( X \) and \( Y \) ?

A by conduction and convection

B by conduction only

C by radiation and convection

D by radiation only
