body:
A mercury thermometer with no scale is taped to a ruler as shown.

When the thermometer is placed in steam, the mercury level rises to \( 22.0 \mathrm{~cm} \).

When the thermometer is placed in pure melting ice, the mercury level falls to \( 2.0 \mathrm{~cm} \).

![diagram](./assets/65c6655e-2c09-4b85-8241-68a41a6950ae.png)

Which temperature is shown by the mercury level in the diagram?

A \( 6^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

B \( 8^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

C \( 30^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

D \( 40^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

The diagram shows a hydroelectric system.

![diagram](./assets/a410299b-e40a-4637-99d1-1419c2ab7250.png)

What are the main energy changes taking place?

A chemical energy \( \rightarrow \) kinetic energy \( \rightarrow \) electrical energy

B electrical energy \( \rightarrow \) gravitational energy \( \rightarrow \) kinetic energy

C gravitational energy \( \rightarrow \) kinetic energy \( \rightarrow \) electrical energy

D kinetic energy \( \rightarrow \) electrical energy \( \rightarrow \) gravitational energy

The diagram shows a force being applied to a lever to lift a heavy weight.

![diagram](./assets/096e275a-5494-449f-9f2e-ec2da5686c51.png)

Which change would enable the heavy weight to be lifted with a smaller force?

A Move the force to the right.

B Move the heavy weight to the right.

C Move the force to the left.

D Move the pivot to the left.

A car moves along a level road.

The diagram shows all of the horizontal forces acting on the car.

![diagram](./assets/4938fc48-1020-42be-8e84-f6681444d2e2.png)

\( 2000 \mathrm{~N} \) force
 from engine

Which statement is correct?

A The car is slowing down.

B The car is speeding up.

C The car is moving at a constant speed.

D The car is moving backwards.

An electric oven is connected to the mains supply using insulated copper wires. The wires
 become very warm.

What can be done to prevent so much heat being produced in the connecting wires?

A Use thicker copper wires.

B Use thinner copper wires.

C Use thicker insulation.

D Use thinner insulation.

Two bars of soft iron are placed near a bar magnet.

![diagram](./assets/aa9fe34d-08f6-432c-a8c9-192aa153a394.png)

![diagram](./assets/1cc0e1df-2760-486c-8815-31ad292581c9.png)

Which row states and explains the behaviour of poles \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) of the soft iron bars?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) & reason \\
\hline A & attract & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are like poles \\
B & attract & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are unlike poles \\
C & repel & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are like poles \\
D & repel & \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \) are unlike poles \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which graph shows how the voltage of a simple a.c. generator varies with time?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/deee67c4-cba8-4487-a5b4-4dd458abec67.png)

![diagram](./assets/f30bda34-c38c-462c-a209-9288c8157d9c.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/6f986a45-f8fe-4c5d-8e5c-d8df0edec1e4.png)

![diagram](./assets/d0c39d4b-9a44-4701-aca6-3255edcf9d64.png)

The diagram shows a circuit used to find the resistance of lamp \( L \).

Blocks \( P, Q \) and \( R \) represent the different components used.

![diagram](./assets/f67a9332-c393-4def-9d25-b606d9a35f6d.png)

Which is a correct possible choice of components to use for \( P, Q \) and \( R \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & P & \( Q \) & \( R \) \\
\hline A & ammeter & variable resistor & voltmeter \\
B & variable resistor & voltmeter & ammeter \\
C & voltmeter & ammeter & variable resistor \\
D & voltmeter & variable resistor & ammeter \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows two voltmeters, \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \), connected to a potential divider.

![diagram](./assets/9dceab8f-9c04-4302-9e66-8c8f52d94f56.png)

The sliding connection at point \( \mathrm{X} \) is moved towards the top of the diagram.

What happens to the reading on \( \mathrm{P} \) and to the reading on \( \mathrm{Q} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & reading on \( \mathrm{P} \) & reading on \( \mathrm{Q} \) \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows plane waves reflected by a plane surface.

Which line represents a wavefront?

![diagram](./assets/4e694df4-a8cf-4544-922a-a8c60e46d8b2.png)

![diagram](./assets/5cbaa68c-618d-432e-82b1-75bde40d98b6.png)

Which row shows a use of a capacitor and a use of a relay?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & use of a capacitor & use of a relay \\
\hline A & switching circuit & voltage transformation \\
B & time-delay circuit & switching circuit \\
C & voltage transformation & switching circuit \\
D & voltage transformation & time-delay circuit \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A boy sits near a campfire. He pokes the fire with an iron bar. His hand becomes hot.

![diagram](./assets/c293ee89-4e86-4047-80f1-75c05974b319.png)

In which ways does thermal energy (heat) from the fire reach his hand?

A conduction and convection only

B conduction and radiation only

C convection and radiation only

D conduction, convection and radiation

Which physical property is used to measure temperature in a liquid-in-glass thermometer?

A the length of the thermometer

B the thickness of the glass bulb

C the volume of the glass bulb

D the volume of the liquid

A see-saw is made by resting a long plank of wood with its centre of mass on a barrel.

A boy sits on one side of the barrel and a girl sits on the other side so that the see-saw is
 balanced.

![diagram](./assets/39591f6b-c244-45ab-980e-9c17ed9751cb.png)

Which statement must be true?

A boy's weight \( = \) girl's weight

B distance \( x= \) distance \( y \)

C total downward force \( = \) total moment about the barrel

D resultant force and resultant moment are both zero

The diagram shows sections of four objects of equal mass. The position of the centre of mass of
 each object has been marked with a cross.

Which object is the most stable?

![diagram](./assets/fe592e4a-6613-428d-8876-a96ca8a8d7c8.png)

A large bag of feathers and a steel block balance each other on some scales.

![diagram](./assets/c2072f57-8e5b-434f-a448-3b1a47dd41e0.png)

What does this show about the masses and the weights of the bag of feathers and the steel
 block?

A It shows that the masses are equal and the weights are equal.

B It shows that the masses are equal, but the weights might be different.

C It shows that the masses might be different and the weights might be different.

D It shows that the weights are equal, but the masses might be different.

A parachutist inside an aeroplane has a mass of \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \).

![diagram](./assets/98b1437c-4484-471e-989a-6637e2c14c7a.png)

What is his mass after he has jumped from the aeroplane?

A \( 0 \mathrm{~kg} \)

B between \( 0 \mathrm{~kg} \) and \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D greater than \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

The diagram shows a simple step-down transformer used to decrease a voltage.

Which part is the primary coil?

![diagram](./assets/926ded2e-8918-4cf8-a5db-e6b62dd8ad53.png)

A magnet is suspended from a spring so that it can move freely inside a coil. The coil is
 connected to a sensitive centre-zero ammeter.

![diagram](./assets/8995b037-d31a-45ab-aa88-0b94625f8c59.png)

What does the ammeter show when the magnet repeatedly moves slowly up and down?

A a reading constantly changing from left to right and right to left

B a steady reading to the left

C a steady reading to the right

D a steady reading of zero

A polythene rod repels an inflated balloon hanging from a nylon thread.

What charges must the rod and the balloon carry?

A The rod and the balloon carry opposite charges.

B The rod and the balloon carry like charges.

C The rod is charged but the balloon is not.

D The balloon is charged but the rod is not.

The diagram shows a thermistor in a potential divider. A voltmeter is connected across the
 thermistor.

![diagram](./assets/58a6fa43-398c-4e41-946f-a21faad5ff70.png)

The graph shows how the resistance of the thermistor changes with temperature.

![diagram](./assets/c458d7b6-0ca4-4464-aa81-e73967c31c46.png)

As the thermistor becomes warmer, what happens to its resistance and what happens to the
 reading on the voltmeter?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & resistance & voltmeter reading \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & increases \\
C & increases & decreases \\
D & increases & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

In two separate experiments, a magnet is brought near to an unmagnetised iron bar. This causes
 the bar to become magnetised.

experiment 1

![diagram](./assets/4cf41dab-4a74-4a15-bd5b-85d7044828a4.png)

\( \mathrm{X} \quad \) iron bar

experiment 2

![diagram](./assets/0f9a8d53-ed0b-459e-beb8-ec1ac1f724b4.png)

\begin{tabular}{|ll|}
\hline iron bar \( \quad Y \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which magnetic poles are induced at \( \mathrm{X} \) and at \( \mathrm{Y} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & pole induced at \( X \) & pole induced at \( Y \) \\
\hline A & \( \mathrm{N} \) & \( \mathrm{N} \) \\
B & \( \mathrm{N} \) & \( \mathrm{S} \) \\
C & \( \mathrm{S} \) & \( \mathrm{N} \) \\
D & \( \mathrm{S} \) & \( \mathrm{S} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows the dispersion of white light by a glass prism.

![diagram](./assets/3e07e53e-8423-4078-9ea0-d19fb13210d7.png)

Why does dispersion occur when white light enters the glass?

A The frequency of red light decreases more than that of violet light.

B The frequency of violet light decreases more than that of red light.

C The speed of red light decreases more than that of violet light.

D The speed of violet light decreases more than that of red light.

A thin converging lens is used to produce, on a screen, a focused image of a candle.

![diagram](./assets/37901465-2276-45f2-9811-8f9192ea6b30.png)

Various focused images are produced on the screen by moving the lens and the screen
 backwards and forwards.

Which statement is always correct?

A The image is at the principal focus (focal point) of the lens.

B The image is bigger than the object.

C The image is closer to the lens than the object is.

D The image is inverted.

Two farmers use an electrically powered elevator to lift bales of hay. All the bales of hay have the
 same mass.

![diagram](./assets/b18ca5f0-035f-42b2-a37d-df058e7a7732.png)


As sunset approaches, they increase the speed of the motor so that more bales are lifted up in a
 given time.


How does this affect the work done in lifting each bale and the useful output power of the motor?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { work done in } \\
\text { lifting each bale }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { useful output power } \\
\text { of the motor }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & increases & decreases \\
B & increases & increases \\
C & no change & decreases \\
D & no change & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A brick with flat, rectangular sides rests on a table.

![diagram](./assets/2e24a85f-481c-4d88-8436-70872bfd8137.png)

The brick is now turned so that it rests on the table on its smallest face.

![diagram](./assets/a3d7b671-0693-413e-9d42-c13c36582584.png)

How has this affected the force and the pressure exerted by the brick on the table?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & force & pressure \\
\hline A & increased & increased \\
B & increased & unchanged \\
C & unchanged & increased \\
D & unchanged & unchanged \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

When a liquid evaporates, some molecules escape from it and its temperature changes.

From where do the molecules escape and what is the effect on the temperature of the liquid?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & molecules escape from & temperature of liquid \\
\hline A & all parts of the liquid & decreases \\
B & all parts of the liquid & increases \\
C & only the liquid surface & decreases \\
D & only the liquid surface & increases \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Balls are stuck with wax to rods made from different metals, as shown in diagram 1.

The rods are heated at one end. Some of the balls fall off, leaving some as shown in diagram 2.

Which labelled metal is the best conductor of heat?

diagram 1

diagram 2

![diagram](./assets/4e8b3827-28b2-402a-b9b2-f1d2a317bec2.png)

![diagram](./assets/66c3c7e0-e422-4a09-9ea2-dd37fe618083.png)

![diagram](./assets/19161e92-98bf-4b3f-9670-48f182183bd6.png)

heated end

heated end

before heating

after heating

The diagram shows an enlarged drawing of the end of a metre rule. It is being used to measure
 the length of a small feather.

![diagram](./assets/4493ecbc-6e41-4566-88c9-caeeac2a4e7f.png)
undefined

What is the length of the feather?

A \( 19 \mathrm{~mm} \)

B \( 29 \mathrm{~mm} \)

C \( 19 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 29 \mathrm{~cm} \)

A student investigates how the radiation from a radioactive source changes with time.

The table shows the results from the detector used by the student.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \( \begin{array}{c}\text { time/ } \\
\text { minutes }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { count rate/ } \\
\text { counts per minute }\end{array} \) \\
\hline 0 & 340 \\
\( 2.0 \) & 180 \\
\( 4.0 \) & 100 \\
\( 6.0 \) & 60 \\
\( 8.0 \) & 40 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The experiment is repeated by many other students, who also measure the count rate every two
 minutes.

The half-life of the source is known to be exactly \( 2.0 \) minutes.

Why is the measured count rate always greater than half the previous value?

A Radioactive emissions occur randomly with time.

B The detector used is very close to the source.

C There is background radiation present.

D The radioactive source is decaying.

A beam of cathode rays enters an electric field between two charged plates.

Which diagram shows a path that the rays could take?
undefined

![diagram](./assets/3df9cec9-6c1e-4df7-9f44-c8f14b97dfe5.png)

D

![diagram](./assets/f16580ea-0fdf-4fb6-9f35-c53780dc6e41.png)

Two resistors are connected in parallel.

![diagram](./assets/1377c531-1ab9-44aa-b215-b7079861fe75.png)

Which value could be the resistance of the combination?

A \( 12 \Omega \)

B \( 20 \Omega \)

C \( 25 \Omega \)

D \( 50 \Omega \)

Which circuit shows a voltmeter measuring the p.d. across a resistor?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/cead2647-58ec-432f-9bf3-5b5292f850d3.png)

![diagram](./assets/86dd224d-014b-4e8c-9de1-bb44f3c8b1ed.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/6d67a62a-57f7-4799-9226-0de6c987eee2.png)

![diagram](./assets/bb60ed21-7be5-4995-9d8a-00de954b1027.png)

Which procedure may be used to demagnetise a steel bar?

A cooling it in a freezer for several hours

B earthing it with a copper wire for several seconds

C removing it slowly from a coil carrying an alternating current (a.c.)

D rubbing it in one direction with a woollen cloth

Sounds are produced by vibrating objects. A certain object vibrates but a person nearby cannot
 hear any sound.

Which statement could explain why nothing is heard?

A The amplitude of the sound waves is too large.

B The frequency of the vibration is too high.

C The sound waves are transverse.

D The speed of the sound waves is too high.

Two sounds \( X \) and \( Y \) are produced by loudspeakers.

The amplitude and frequency of each sound wave is given in the table.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & amplitude \( / \mathrm{mm} \) & frequency \( / \mathrm{Hz} \) \\
\hline\( X \) & \( 1.3 \) & 475 \\
\( \mathrm{Y} \) & \( 2.0 \) & 235 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

How does sound \( Y \) compare with sound \( X \) ?

A \( Y \) is louder and has a higher pitch.

B \( Y \) is louder and has a lower pitch.

C \( Y \) is quieter and has a higher pitch.

D \( Y \) is quieter and has a lower pitch.

The diagram represents a water wave.

![diagram](./assets/e1c98ff6-84a6-49e5-96e4-db43f1c279b9.png)

Which row shows the amplitude and the wavelength of the wave?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & amplitude/m & wavelength/m \\
\hline A & 1 & 2 \\
B & 1 & 4 \\
C & 2 & 2 \\
D & 2 & 4 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A swimmer feels cold after leaving warm water on a warm, windy day.

Why does she feel cold even though the air is warm?

A The less energetic water molecules on her skin escape quickly.

B The more energetic water molecules on her skin do not escape quickly.

C The water on her skin does not evaporate quickly enough to keep her warm.

D The water on her skin evaporates quickly and cools her skin.

The diagrams represent the molecules in two different states of matter. The arrows show the
 motion of the molecules.

![diagram](./assets/d4151ede-c2b2-417b-86a4-4ee08cf5ac40.png)

state 1

state 2

What is state 1 , and what is state \( 2 ? \)

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & state 1 & state 2 \\
\hline A & gas & liquid \\
B & gas & solid \\
C & liquid & gas \\
D & liquid & solid \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

body:
A heavy beam rests on two supports. The diagram shows the only three forces \( F_{1}, F_{2} \) and \( F_{3} \)
 acting on the beam.

![diagram](./assets/8e0867a6-5572-454b-9b8a-b95a7fdae070.png)

The beam is in equilibrium.

Which statement is correct?

A All the forces are equal in size.

B The resultant force on the beam is in the opposite direction to the resultant turning effect.

C The resultant force on the beam is zero and the resultant turning effect on the beam is zero.

D The total upward force is twice the total downward force.

body:

![diagram](./assets/ecf47c3d-bebe-42fc-8c28-3b7d28f4fcce.png)

A student wants the cathode rays to make a spot at \( P \) on the screen.

Which parts of the cathode-ray tube should be positive?

A anode and top \( Y \) plate

B anode and bottom Y plate

C cathode and top \( Y \) plate

D cathode and bottom Y plate

In the circuits shown, all the resistors are identical.

Which circuit has the least resistance?

![diagram](./assets/85ff1d5a-9c9d-4d28-b694-fbe718bb60d6.png)

![diagram](./assets/a279d8b1-39a9-41b1-824c-323c675a03d4.png)

![diagram](./assets/60018847-0054-49a3-93d8-c00cfc7f2c54.png)

![diagram](./assets/90b5e384-e1bd-4e56-bc33-a2cda2a19632.png)

The diagram shows the path of a ray of light passing through the principal focus \( F \) of a lens.

Which broken line shows the direction of the ray after it leaves the lens?

![diagram](./assets/543a0c00-b65f-47be-ad7f-326788105c39.png)

Which diagram shows what happens when a ray of white light passes through a prism?

![diagram](./assets/3c4040c7-dc3d-4fa7-8751-0e0de7a61f44.png)

![diagram](./assets/24c1cb2e-0608-4536-bdfb-98fd4cd5eed9.png)

![diagram](./assets/60e6a633-2fc3-45e9-bc1f-1d87b64c9644.png)

D

![diagram](./assets/8e697218-1198-4707-859e-d7b0730dd71c.png)

Which property of an object cannot be changed by a force?

A its mass

B its motion

C its shape

D its size

A wooden plank rests in equilibrium on two boulders on opposite sides of a narrow stream. Three
 forces of size \( P, Q \) and \( R \) act on the plank.

![diagram](./assets/bdddf1bb-c53b-44f5-ab88-48fad761a587.png)

How are the sizes of the forces related?

A \( P+Q=R \)

B \( P+R=Q \)

C \( P=Q=R \)

D \( P=Q+R \)

Which statement about the masses and weights of objects on the Earth is correct?

A A balance can only be used to compare weights, not masses.

B Heavy objects always have more mass than light ones.

C Large objects always have more mass than small ones.

D Mass is a force but weight is not.

Two parallel metal plates in a vacuum are connected to the terminals of a high-voltage power
 supply. A beam of cathode rays is passed into the space between the two plates, as shown.

In which direction does the beam of cathode rays deflect?

high-voltage

power supply

![diagram](./assets/f49aea95-fb51-4da5-b1c3-b8756d58d177.png)

![diagram](./assets/d3f6583a-4f8a-4a72-82db-51c1aaab0419.png)

metal plate

A nuclide of substance \( X \) has the symbol \( { }_{12}^{26} X \).

How many electrons are there in a neutral atom of substance X?

A 12

B 14

C 26

D 38

The diagram shows a simple transformer.

![diagram](./assets/dbfd88bf-2f14-48b4-8e24-ba084359fda5.png)

From which material should the core be made?

A aluminium

B copper

C iron

D steel

A horseshoe magnet is brought near to an unmagnetised iron bar.

![diagram](./assets/70d1eecf-7124-4a57-b24f-c820a2e8adda.png)

iron bar

Which row in the table shows the magnetic poles induced in the iron bar and the direction of the
 forces between the bar and the magnet?
undefined

The diagrams show the wave shapes of two different sounds. The scales are the same in each
 diagram.

![diagram](./assets/7fc567da-febc-4a9f-aa0c-85351617270e.png)

![diagram](./assets/0e5d3a3c-c148-418d-9b50-2ccc3d7ea84f.png)

sound 1

sound 2

How does sound 2 compare with sound \( 1 ? \)

A Sound 2 is louder than sound 1.

B Sound 2 is quieter than sound 1.

C Sound 2 has a higher pitch than sound 1 .

D Sound 2 has a lower pitch than sound 1.

Radio waves are received at a house at the bottom of a hill.

![diagram](./assets/fd88cd0c-211a-4ddc-afe1-fcf6b8a6dfda.png)

The waves reach the house because the hill has caused them to be

A diffracted.

B radiated.

C reflected.

D refracted.

The diagram shows the image of a clock in a plane mirror.

![diagram](./assets/dfcdfb8d-dc63-408d-8484-8f1119ff8eaa.png)

What time is shown?

A \( 02: 25 \)

B \( 02: 35 \)

C 09:25

D 09:35

Two identical copper cans are filled with boiling water.

![diagram](./assets/e0df1e99-3398-4aeb-8589-bf82bc594c3b.png)

uninsulated can

insulated can

One can is insulated with wool. The temperature of the water in each can is taken every minute
 for several minutes. Graphs of the results are plotted.

Which graph shows the results obtained?

![diagram](./assets/89b711b7-c147-40d0-8cbb-9a67c1001505.png)

A water manometer is used to measure the pressure of a gas supply.

![diagram](./assets/ffb62995-3e5d-4e79-9af6-0dcbdbd46d59.png)

When it is attached to the gas supply, the water falls on the left side and rises on the right side.
 The difference in the levels of water on the two sides is now \( 20 \mathrm{~cm} \).

What is the pressure of the gas supply?

A the pressure due to \( 10 \mathrm{~cm} \) depth of water

B the pressure due to \( 20 \mathrm{~cm} \) depth of water

C the pressure due to \( 10 \mathrm{~cm} \) depth of water plus atmospheric pressure

D the pressure due to \( 20 \mathrm{~cm} \) depth of water plus atmospheric pressure

A uniform rod rests on a pivot at its centre. The rod is not attached to the pivot. Forces are then
 applied to the rod in four different ways, as shown. The weight of the rod can be ignored.

Which diagram shows the rod in equilibrium?

A

B

![diagram](./assets/fe497258-72e5-4bb0-b0c7-511f94eac8bc.png)

![diagram](./assets/ac951397-cf18-457d-b868-87fa85dfef7a.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/b8d41fe5-4418-4c5a-853e-90d373168216.png)

The weight of an object is to be found using the balance shown in the diagram.

![diagram](./assets/2f3a76b0-affe-498b-97a7-ad89061a220e.png)

The object is put in the left-hand pan and various standard weights are put in the right-hand pan.
 These are the results.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline weights in the right-hand pan & effect \\
\hline \( 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.05 \mathrm{~N}, 0.02 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the left-hand side \\
\hline \( 0.2 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.01 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the right-hand side \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What is the best estimate of the weight of the object?

A \( 0.27 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( \quad 0.29 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 0.31 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 0.58 \mathrm{~N} \)

The graph shows how the speed of a car changes with time.

![diagram](./assets/79875087-2a39-4c44-8706-b64d9802b987.png)

Between which two times is the car stationary?

A U and V

B \( V \) and \( W \)

C W and \( X \)

D \( X \) and \( Y \)

Which diagram shows the magnetic field pattern around a wire that is carrying a current
 perpendicular to the page?

![diagram](./assets/462c720a-e0cb-494a-bf75-d941dc35423e.png)

![diagram](./assets/e6f6c2da-9e56-47b5-be7d-40a1068f9f46.png)

The diagram shows a circuit with a \( 3.0 \Omega \) resistor and a \( 2.0 \Omega \) resistor connected in parallel.

![diagram](./assets/d6903673-d941-4e58-a483-accfd0b9b055.png)

The switch is open, and the ammeter reads \( 2.0 \mathrm{~A} \).

The switch is now closed and the ammeter reads the total current in both resistors.

What is the ammeter reading with the switch closed?

A \( 1.2 \mathrm{~A} \)

B \( \quad 3.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

C \( 4.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

D \( \quad 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

One type of double glazing consists of two panes of glass separated by a vacuum.

![diagram](./assets/035f4872-8c36-47ee-93df-7c968c156318.png)

Which method or methods of energy transfer are prevented by the vacuum?

A conduction and convection

B conduction and radiation

C convection and radiation

D radiation only

Some gas is trapped in a container of fixed volume.

The temperature of the gas increases.

Which graph shows how the pressure of the gas changes with temperature?

![diagram](./assets/116dca3e-42ee-4320-ac90-f1ae1531a597.png)

![diagram](./assets/eaac4619-a4c6-431f-a461-568350021f67.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/bf8a07de-5876-4618-ae60-ec41446e001a.png)

![diagram](./assets/2c0f9d4a-1d8d-4a65-973e-9f3817296d7f.png)

The list contains three energy resources \( P, Q \) and \( R \).

P geothermal energy from hot rocks

Q nuclear fission in reactors

\( \mathrm{R} \) sunlight on solar panels

Which of these resources are renewable?

A \( P \) and \( Q \) only

B \( P \) and \( R \) only

C \( Q \) and \( R \) only

D \( P, Q \) and \( R \)

Which properties of a body can be changed by applying a force to the body?

A mass, motion and shape

B mass and motion, but not shape

C mass and shape, but not motion

D motion and shape, but not mass

In which situation is no resultant force needed?

A a car changing direction at a steady speed

B a car moving in a straight line at a steady speed

C a car slowing down

D a car speeding up

The weight of an object is found using the balance shown in the diagram. The object is put in the
 left-hand pan and various weights are put in the right-hand pan.

![diagram](./assets/917641ef-e36b-4667-8d6c-574595a7fd2a.png)

These are the results.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline weights in the right-hand pan & effect \\
\hline \( 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.05 \mathrm{~N}, 0.02 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the left-hand side \\
\hline \( 0.2 \mathrm{~N}, 0.1 \mathrm{~N}, 0.01 \mathrm{~N} \) & balance tips down slightly on the right-hand side \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What is the best estimate of the weight of the object?

A \( 0.27 \mathrm{~N} \)

B \( 0.29 \mathrm{~N} \)

C \( 0.31 \mathrm{~N} \)

D \( 0.58 \mathrm{~N} \)

The mass of an astronaut is \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \) on the Moon.

What is the mass of the astronaut on the Earth?

A \( 7 \mathrm{~kg} \)

B \( 70 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( 80 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D \( 700 \mathrm{~kg} \)

A radioactive nucleus emits a \( \beta \)-particle.

\( \beta \)-particle

![diagram](./assets/63ae5f8c-32f7-4316-93f7-dafaae01e5b2.png)

What happens to the proton number (atomic number) of the nucleus?

A It stays the same.

B It increases by 1 .

C It decreases by 2 .

D It decreases by 4 .
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
The diagram shows a device to produce cathode rays.

![diagram](./assets/f083296c-b6d6-4d4b-b399-f0c95d3a9241.png)

Which part of the device is heated and why?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & part heated & reason \\
\hline A & anode & to emit electrons \\
B & anode & to emit protons \\
C & cathode & to emit electrons \\
D & cathode & to emit protons \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which diagram could represent the structure of a neutral atom?

![diagram](./assets/12f53785-de1e-4bd1-873c-69ed9fa08a6b.png)

![diagram](./assets/4c4a6db5-9a5e-42dc-a32b-df43b9b59619.png)

C

D

key

neutron

\( (+ \) proton

electron

Which procedure may be used to demagnetise a steel bar?

A cooling it in a freezer

B earthing it with a copper wire

C placing it in a solenoid carrying a large direct current (d.c.)

D striking it repeatedly with a hammer

A wire passes between the poles of a horseshoe magnet. There is a current in the wire in the
 direction shown, and this causes a force to act on the wire.

![diagram](./assets/8e5c0d18-8103-4bfe-b24f-c819de80dcaa.png)

Three other arrangements, \( P, Q \) and \( R \), of the wire and magnet are set up as shown.

![diagram](./assets/e96d1e4e-2693-4888-89cb-81e32354a0d9.png)

![diagram](./assets/8d8a8c58-577d-42d0-9c0e-61e0e2765064.png)

![diagram](./assets/12fdb6b2-b24a-4058-9b78-9cf7137d317d.png)

magnet turned around current direction reversed current direction reversed
 and magnet turned around

Which arrangement or arrangements will cause a force in the same direction as the original
 arrangement?

A \( P, Q \) and \( R \)

B \( P \) and \( Q \) only

C P only

D R only

The circuit shown in the diagram contains an unknown component \( X \), hidden in a box.

The voltage-current graph for \( \mathrm{X} \) is as shown.

variable voltage supply

![diagram](./assets/61677941-ba1d-4073-aa5c-6cb4c77a5a8b.png)

![diagram](./assets/982d178d-d17f-4746-9a3b-cf8d39198732.png)

What is the component \( X \) ?

A a capacitor

B a closed switch

C an open switch

D a resistor of constant resistance

The image formed by a plane mirror is upright.

![diagram](./assets/c94666c1-2dbd-4dac-90a2-580328697d7a.png)

What are the other characteristics of the image?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { laterally inverted } \\
\text { (left to right) }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { magnified } \\
\text { (larger than the object) }\end{array} \) & virtual \\
\hline A & no & yes & yes \\
B & yes & no & no \\
C & yes & no & yes \\
D & yes & yes & no \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A heater supplies \( 80 \mathrm{~J} \) of energy to a block of metal. The temperature of the block rises by \( 20^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \).

What happens to the block of metal when its temperature falls by \( 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) ?

A Its internal energy decreases by \( 40 \mathrm{~J} \).

B Its internal energy decreases by \( 160 \mathrm{~J} \).

C Its internal energy increases by \( 40 \mathrm{~J} \).

D Its internal energy increases by \( 160 \mathrm{~J} \).

An object on a thread is swinging between \( X \) and \( Z \), as shown in the diagram. It is momentarily at
 rest at \( X \) and at \( Z \).

![diagram](./assets/bf04514c-4449-49c1-aeb3-7dd204d9832d.png)

An incomplete word equation about the energy of the object is shown below.

gravitational potential energy \( = \) kinetic energy \( +\ldots \ldots \ldots \) energy \( + \) energy losses
 at \( X \quad \) at \( Y \quad \) at \( Y \)

Which form of energy is needed to complete the word equation?

A chemical

B gravitational potential

C internal

D strain

A car is moving downhill along a road at a constant speed.

Which graph is the speed/time graph for the car?

![diagram](./assets/ab4acc8e-307c-42dc-8a97-e67a670258ab.png)

![diagram](./assets/dd4d2fab-5bf7-40bb-9db2-d34b141b83ef.png)

C

D

![diagram](./assets/5781e823-6f5d-4c04-9a74-814f62a84753.png)

![diagram](./assets/427aaa9f-a76a-4059-b9c5-d0f52e6e97ee.png)

Which quantity is measured in newtons?

A density

B energy

C pressure

D weight

Which statement is correct?

A A fuse is included in a circuit to prevent the current becoming too high.

B A fuse should be connected to the neutral wire in a plug.

C An electric circuit will only work if it includes a fuse.

D An earth wire is needed to prevent the fuse blowing.

A plane mirror is on a wall.

Which is a correct description of the image formed by the mirror?

A the right way up and smaller than the object

B the right way up and the same size as the object

C upside down and smaller than the object

D upside down and the same size as the object

An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole
 of the washer.

![diagram](./assets/cf8e4685-45a6-4f8a-a178-0e6aeb335fc3.png)

![diagram](./assets/36c1e8b8-3398-441b-8eed-133aea88e722.png)

How can the engineer fit the washer onto the rod?

A cool the washer and put it over the rod

B cool the washer and rod to the same temperature and push them together

C heat the rod and then place it in the hole

D heat the washer and place it over the rod

Two boys \( X \) and \( Y \) each have the same total weight and are standing on soft ground.

![diagram](./assets/07ea4616-7207-4da8-8a21-9d3d5655a14e.png)

![diagram](./assets/b14b24a2-bd7e-4fd2-bc79-4987d269d0d7.png)

Which boy is more likely to sink into the soft ground and why?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { boy more } \\
\text { likely to sink }\end{array} \) & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { pressure on soft } \\
\text { ground }\end{array} \) \\
\hline A & \( X \) & larger than \( Y \) \\
B & \( X \) & smaller than \( Y \) \\
C & \( Y \) & larger than \( X \) \\
D & \( Y \) & smaller than \( X \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A piece of card has its centre of mass at \( \mathrm{M} \).

Which diagram shows how it hangs when suspended by a thread?

![diagram](./assets/9f188ac7-5e87-497d-a387-b392b8207f17.png)

![diagram](./assets/0d6ff010-8826-4afd-8514-2e74bd45314a.png)

![diagram](./assets/fc3237ad-3003-4cae-9d67-746c10327d57.png)

![diagram](./assets/145bedaf-4ca4-41de-a299-b47f452cb41b.png)

A student shines a narrow beam of white light into a prism as shown in the diagram. He sees a
 spectrum of colours emerging from the prism.

![diagram](./assets/2c01d296-0495-4d49-9701-281d796d729b.png)

spectrum

of colours

Which three colours does he see at \( \mathbf{X} \), at \( \mathbf{Y} \) and at \( \mathbf{Z} \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \mathbf{X} \) & \( \mathbf{Y} \) & \( \mathbf{Z} \) \\
\hline A & blue & yellow & red \\
B & red & blue & yellow \\
C & red & yellow & blue \\
D & yellow & red & blue \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a section through a series of waves on water.

Which dotted line shows the position of the still water surface after the waves have passed?

![diagram](./assets/fb31b8e7-9965-4cc6-b714-2fb35f054bad.png)

Spoons made of different materials were placed in four cups of coffee poured from the same jug.

Which spoon will be hottest to touch at end \( \mathbf{X} \) ?

![diagram](./assets/a32edca4-78cd-4df7-aef3-13ca2d645327.png)

![diagram](./assets/1987104a-c2bc-4763-b586-b7d5a9a1eaee.png)

experiment \( \mathrm{C} \)

experiment \( D \)

![diagram](./assets/54f6e9ed-2263-420c-819e-19dc894ae24b.png)

![diagram](./assets/a388f9df-3a66-4ca3-9797-280e82286062.png)

Which statement refers to convection?

A It does not involve energy transfer.

B It is the transfer of heat energy without the movement of particles.

C It only occurs in liquids or gases.

D It only occurs in solids.
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
An empty glass is placed on a join between two tables as shown. The glass remains stable.

Which point is the centre of mass of the glass?

![diagram](./assets/faa864c9-9e0d-4313-8365-6dad17a08361.png)

A sample of radioactive uranium has mass \( 1 \mathrm{~g} \). Another sample of the same material has
 mass \( 2 \mathrm{~g} \).

Which property is the same for both samples?

A the amount of radiation emitted per second

B the half-life

C the number of uranium atoms

D the volume

The diagram shows a transformer connected to a \( 240 \mathrm{~V} \) a.c. supply.

![diagram](./assets/77437c22-100d-4686-93ce-d735a029e2a5.png)

What is the potential difference across the secondary coil of the transformer?

A \( 30 \mathrm{~V} \)

B \( 120 \mathrm{~V} \)

C \( 240 \mathrm{~V} \)

D \( 480 \mathrm{~V} \)

The device \( X \) in this circuit is designed to cut off the electricity supply automatically if too much
 current flows.

![diagram](./assets/ae3b8681-99a4-4a83-9c06-988850078686.png)

What is device \( X \) ?

A a fuse

B a switch

C a resistor

D an ammeter

A solenoid carrying a current is used to demagnetise a bar magnet.

bar magnet

![diagram](./assets/6a77fca9-644e-4951-9bc6-12dcbb3bc8c7.png)

Which conditions achieve demagnetisation?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( \begin{array}{c}\text { current through } \\
\text { solenoid }\end{array} \) & movement of bar magnet \\
\hline A & a.c. & around the solenoid quickly \\
B & a.c. & through the solenoid slowly \\
C & d.c. & around the solenoid quickly \\
D & d.c. & through the solenoid slowly \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which diagram shows total internal reflection of light?

![diagram](./assets/d7c5588e-1b0f-4510-8966-c0647f94bc50.png)

![diagram](./assets/918c006f-d59f-4fc4-8798-013946e2a210.png)

The force of gravity acting on an astronaut in an orbiting spacecraft is less than when she is on
 the Earth's surface.


Compared with being on the Earth's surface, how do her mass and weight change when she
 goes into orbit?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & mass in orbit & weight in orbit \\
\hline A & decreases & decreases \\
B & decreases & unchanged \\
C & unchanged & decreases \\
D & unchanged & unchanged \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Some liquid is heated in a flask.

The diagrams show the height of the liquid in the tube when the liquid is cold and when it is hot.

![diagram](./assets/e24a2221-607a-4485-b6a0-2aa25cc36957.png)

![diagram](./assets/2b7b9386-491e-47a3-9563-bebb3640151f.png)

What is the difference in the heights?

A \( 1.7 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 2.8 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( 3.2 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 4.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
In a cathode-ray tube, a hot tungsten cathode releases particles by thermionic emission.

What are these particles?

A \( \alpha \)-particles

B electrons

C protons

D tungsten atoms
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
Which particle does not experience a force due to an electric field?

A \( \alpha \)-particle

B electron

C neutron

D proton

The current in a lamp at full brightness is \( 0.25 \mathrm{~A} \). The flexible cable to the lamp is designed for
 currents up to \( 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \), so it can safely carry the \( 0.25 \mathrm{~A} \) taken by the lamp.

Which fuse should be inserted in the plug at the other end of the flexible cable?

A \( 0.2 \mathrm{~A} \)

B \( 1.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

C \( 5.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

D \( 10.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

In the circuit shown, ammeter \( X \) reads \( 0.5 \mathrm{~A} \).

![diagram](./assets/e6c87079-060b-4e0b-8504-07bc1cf1361b.png)

What does ammeter \( Y \) read?

A 0

B \( \quad 0.5 \mathrm{~A} \)

C \( \quad 3.5 \mathrm{~A} \)

D \( 4.0 \mathrm{~A} \)

Using the circuit shown, the current \( I \) is found for various voltages \( V \). The temperature of the
 resistor does not change.

variable direct

![diagram](./assets/024d8dc2-746d-4a68-86d0-4c3aabdaf58d.png)

Which graph shows the results obtained?

![diagram](./assets/560b80fc-9e8a-4ea9-8848-2d38fb76afee.png)

The north pole of a bar magnet is placed next to end \( P \) of an iron bar \( P Q \), as shown. As a result,
 magnetic poles are induced in the iron bar.

![diagram](./assets/d7613827-ac99-418c-88fd-d759d5c10fd2.png)

![diagram](./assets/7d247c3f-f168-4276-aa43-5023fe448ce3.png)

iron bar

What are the magnetic poles induced at \( P \) and at \( Q \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & magnetic pole at \( P \) & magnetic pole at \( Q \) \\
\hline A & north & north \\
B & north & south \\
C & south & north \\
D & south & south \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Four blocks, made of different materials, are each given the same quantity of internal energy
 (heat).

Which block has the greatest thermal capacity?

![diagram](./assets/77ad8f7e-abfb-417f-a761-eee0ec8db67b.png)

![diagram](./assets/d44e8ebc-f7db-45eb-ba81-6f1f05c9bebf.png)

![diagram](./assets/86412a36-e3c4-47f6-8a82-97052f8115f3.png)

\( \mathrm{D} \)

![diagram](./assets/f86765ab-be1c-48fa-b1b6-98a8f131fa5c.png)

temperature temperature temperature temperature
 rise \( =2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \quad \) rise \( =4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \quad \) rise \( =6^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \quad \) rise \( =8^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

The diagram shows a fire.

Why does the smoke rise above the fire?

A Smoke evaporates more quickly at higher temperatures.

B Smoke molecules diffuse more quickly at higher temperatures.

C The density of the air is lower at higher temperatures.

D The pressure of the air is greater at higher temperatures.

The graph shows the change in temperature of a substance as it is heated steadily.

Which part of the graph shows when the substance is boiling?

![diagram](./assets/dd776f40-e1cb-464e-93b2-966f2f6d6a0d.png)

The table shows the weight in newtons of a \( 10 \mathrm{~kg} \) mass on each of four planets.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline planet & weight of a \( 10 \mathrm{~kg} \) mass \( / \mathrm{N} \) \\
\hline Earth & 100 \\
Jupiter & 250 \\
Mercury & 40 \\
Venus & 90 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a force meter (spring balance) being used.

![diagram](./assets/30bd406f-921c-4726-bb43-099983e2f88f.png)

On which planet is the force meter (spring balance) being used?

A Earth

B Jupiter

C Mercury

D Venus

The graph shows the activity of a radioactive source over a period of time.

activity
 / counts per
 second

![diagram](./assets/6087107a-046d-465c-b4b6-c8f95909edb4.png)

time/hour

What is the half-life of the source?

A \( \frac{1}{2} \) hour

B 1 hour

C \( \quad 1 \frac{1}{2} \) hours

D 3 hours

Four nails, A, B, C and \( \mathbf{D} \), are tested to find which makes the strongest permanent magnet.

![diagram](./assets/bbada5c7-5c47-4a7e-a78f-d1ca91edf2d8.png)

One of the nails is placed against a bar magnet and the number of paper clips which the nail can
 support is recorded. The bar magnet is then removed and the number of paper clips remaining
 attached to the nail is recorded. Each nail is tested in turn.

Which nail becomes the strongest permanent magnet?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline \multirow{2}{*}{ nail } & \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ number of paper clips attached to the nail } \\
\cline { 2 - 3 } & bar magnet present & bar magnet removed \\
\hline A & 2 & 0 \\
B & 2 & 1 \\
C & 4 & 3 \\
D & 5 & 2 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The diagram shows a lamp in a circuit.

![diagram](./assets/3b680887-e307-4deb-b01c-fb75b28ee8a2.png)

Which change to the circuit would increase the current in the lamp?

A adding another resistor in parallel with the one in the circuit

B adding another resistor in series with the one in the circuit

C decreasing the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery in the circuit

D moving the lamp to point \( P \) in the circuit

The diagrams show four arrangements of resistors.

Which arrangement has the smallest total resistance?

![diagram](./assets/b5f5c1b2-76d0-4e00-9713-e260de738408.png)

![diagram](./assets/a6328b30-a3b6-4b11-bd3e-85e0f5704c92.png)

C

![diagram](./assets/9ad897ca-f5ed-4fc6-8bc2-aecb719b83f2.png)

![diagram](./assets/ba3ed1e3-5916-4681-8fa4-af7e8310638d.png)

Which symbols are used for the units of current and of resistance?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & unit of current & unit of resistance \\
\hline A & A & W \\
B & A & \( \Omega \) \\
C & C & W \\
D & C & \( \Omega \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Which of these waves is longitudinal?

A infra-red

B radio

C sound

D water

The diagram shows a ray of light travelling from \( X \). Angle \( P \) is less than the critical angle.

In which direction does the ray continue?

![diagram](./assets/79ec3ede-e26c-4196-862b-07bf87cc3301.png)

Which combination of forces produces a resultant force acting towards the right?

![diagram](./assets/ad4fefbe-d813-4707-ad8a-9f8fac77551e.png)

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/1e7d9e41-e3fa-4a39-90da-b7deeb582504.png)

![diagram](./assets/de70057a-4c2e-4d25-9f71-39a237801acb.png)

![diagram](./assets/23430148-8448-49bd-b9be-444c2b6fb3ed.png)

A student is told to measure the density of a liquid and also of a large cube of metal.

Which pieces of equipment are sufficient to be able to take the measurements needed?

A balance, measuring cylinder and ruler

B balance and thermometer

C measuring cylinder and ruler

D measuring cylinder, ruler and thermometer

The count rate from a radioactive isotope is recorded every hour. The count rate is corrected for
 background radiation.

The table shows the readings.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline time/hours & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 \\
\hline\( \frac{\text { corrected count rate }}{\text { counts/s }} \) & 800 & 620 & 480 & 370 & 290 & 220 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

What estimate of the half-life of the isotope can be obtained from the readings in the table?

A between 1 and 2 hours

B between 2 and 3 hours

C between 3 and 4 hours

D between 4 and 5 hours

In a cathode-ray tube, a hot tungsten cathode releases particles by thermionic emission.

What are these particles?

A \( \alpha \)-particles

B electrons

C protons

D tungsten atoms
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
The diagram shows cables used in the transmission of electrical energy. High voltages are used
 for the transmission.

![diagram](./assets/92b1c400-1d6f-4a93-ab67-95b9ebd0ffac.png)

Why are high voltages used for the transmission of electrical energy?

A Fear of high voltages stops people from interfering with the cables.

B Heat loss in the cables is smaller than if low voltages are used.

C High voltages increase the current in the cables.

D High voltages produce large magnetic fields, so less insulation is needed.

An engineer uses the potential divider shown in the diagram. He needs the output voltage to be
 one tenth \( \left(\frac{1}{10}\right) \) of the input voltage.

![diagram](./assets/d76bf252-9352-47c8-a7db-763c268c2e60.png)

Which pair of values could he use for the two resistors \( X \) and \( Y \) ?

\begin{tabular}{|r|r|r|}
\hline & \( \mathrm{X} / \mathrm{k} \Omega \) & \( \mathrm{Y} / \mathrm{k} \Omega \) \\
\hline A & \( 1.0 \) & \( 9.0 \) \\
B & \( 1.0 \) & \( 10.0 \) \\
C & \( 9.0 \) & \( 1.0 \) \\
D & \( 10.0 \) & \( 1.0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

The ends of three metal rods are tested by holding end \( Q \) of rod 1 close to the others in turn.

![diagram](./assets/0556cc82-d82c-46f2-be7e-1ff678a021b3.png)

The results are as follows.

End Q: attracts end R,

attracts end \( \mathrm{S} \),

attracts end \( \mathrm{T} \),

repels end \( U \).

Which of the metal rods is a magnet?

A rod 1 only

B \( \operatorname{rod} 1 \) and rod 2

C \( \operatorname{rod} 1 \) and rod 3

D rod 3 only

A fire alarm is not loud enough and the pitch is too low. An engineer adjusts the alarm so that it
 produces a louder note of a higher pitch.


What effect does this have on the amplitude and on the frequency of the sound waves that the
 alarm produces?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & amplitude & frequency \\
\hline A & larger & larger \\
B & larger & smaller \\
C & smaller & larger \\
D & smaller & smaller \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

An object is placed in front of a converging lens. The lens has a focal length \( f \).

The lens produces a real, enlarged image of the object.

In which labelled position is the object placed?

![diagram](./assets/d8507b6f-79aa-4c73-8d23-1b94804a8ee6.png)

Which waves are longitudinal?

A

B

C

D

![diagram](./assets/bc7e26eb-e56c-4729-a590-5ad9429ad85c.png)

![diagram](./assets/c4413583-a88d-4f8b-be8f-4ebc97bc75b8.png)

![diagram](./assets/30d1358c-8c41-4fc1-b7c5-541932aa56e5.png)

![diagram](./assets/fbce4139-83d6-425f-b28b-8c903d79596f.png)

light waves

microwaves in an oven

water waves

sound waves

from a lamp

on a pond

from a trumpet

Which type of electromagnetic wave is used in airport security scanners?

A infra-red

B microwaves

C radio waves

D X-rays

Equal masses of two different liquids are put into identical beakers.

Liquid 1 is heated for \( 100 \mathrm{~s} \) and liquid 2 is heated for \( 200 \mathrm{~s} \) by heaters of the same power.

The temperature of both liquids increases by the same amount.

![diagram](./assets/9902525e-a43d-4db6-bb10-cb310374d1a0.png)

Which statement is correct?

A Both liquids receive the same amount of energy.

B Liquid 1 receives more energy than liquid 2.

C Both liquids have equal thermal capacity.

D The thermal capacity of liquid 1 is less than the thermal capacity of liquid 2.

The diagram shows a beaker of water. Four molecules are labelled. The relative amount of
 energy of each molecule is shown.

Which molecule is most likely to escape from the liquid?

![diagram](./assets/3aa696c4-bbf3-4adb-a638-c2f8ed53ace2.png)
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
The diagram shows three different containers \( \mathrm{J}, \mathrm{K} \) and \( \mathrm{L} \). Each container contains water of the
 same depth.

![diagram](./assets/6ca664ac-516d-4b44-a360-a50df60f2aab.png)

Which statement about the pressure of the water on the base of each container is correct?

A The water pressure is greatest in container \( \mathrm{J} \).

B The water pressure is greatest in container K.

C The water pressure is greatest in container \( L \).

D The water pressure is the same for all three containers.

The diagram shows the dimensions of a rectangular block of metal of mass \( m \).

![diagram](./assets/8f38d8d5-1e25-4b50-90fe-56c79ce05a6e.png)

Which expression is used to calculate the density of the metal?

A \( m \times p \times q \)

B \( m \times p \times q \times r \)

C \( \frac{m}{(p \times q)} \)

D \( \frac{m}{(p \times q \times r)} \)

A man stands by a railway track.

![diagram](./assets/b8beb056-58ad-4bbd-bac8-fec87c84ee20.png)

A train travelling at \( 40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) takes \( 2.0 \mathrm{~s} \) to pass the man.

What is the length of the train?

A \( 20 \mathrm{~m} \)

B \( 38 m \)

C \( 40 \mathrm{~m} \)

D \( 80 \mathrm{~m} \)

Diagram 1 shows a measuring cylinder containing water.

Five identical steel balls are now lowered into the measuring cylinder. Diagram 2 shows the new
 water level in the cylinder.

![diagram](./assets/42a33fe9-b151-44c5-9cbc-90a4adb7d0bc.png)

![diagram](./assets/4b1ebd89-75fe-4f1b-8f1c-334ec8a8b291.png)

diagram 1

diagram 2

What is the volume of each steel ball?

A \( 6 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

B \( 14 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

C \( 30 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

D \( 70 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

Which statement describes a property of a magnet?

A It attracts ferrous materials.

B It could have only one pole (north or south).

C It points in a random direction when suspended.

D It repels non-ferrous materials.

A thermistor is used in a circuit to control a piece of equipment automatically.

What might this circuit be used for?

A lighting an electric lamp as it becomes darker

B ringing an alarm bell if a locked door is opened

C switching on a water heater at a pre-determined time

D turning on an air conditioner when the temperature rises

The diagram shows water waves passing through a gap in a harbour wall. The waves curve
 round the wall and reach a small boat in the harbour.

![diagram](./assets/17c3bb79-20a5-4159-b97d-b80db518e9c7.png)


What is the name of this curving effect, and how can the gap be changed so that the waves are
 less likely to reach the boat?

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & name of effect & change to the gap \\
\hline A & diffraction & make the gap slightly bigger \\
B & diffraction & make the gap slightly smaller \\
C & refraction & make the gap slightly bigger \\
D & refraction & make the gap slightly smaller \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

A girl stands at a distance from a large building. She claps her hands and a short time later hears
 an echo.

Why is an echo produced when the sound waves hit the building?

A The sound waves are absorbed.

B The sound waves are diffracted.

C The sound waves are reflected.

D The sound waves are refracted.

Two plastic cups are placed one inside the other. Hot water is poured into the inner cup and a lid
 is put on top, as shown.

![diagram](./assets/7a075a7b-e0ec-4ba4-a2dc-6c8d206ca015.png)

Which statement is correct?

A Heat loss by radiation is prevented by the small air gap.

B No heat passes through the sides of either cup.

C The bench is heated by convection from the bottom of the outer cup.

D The lid is used to reduce heat loss by convection.

An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole
 of the washer.

![diagram](./assets/d25d449d-a6d3-4fcd-9e74-8556477a8b62.png)

![diagram](./assets/bb369786-b0d9-4e95-896f-a2d7d9381a1c.png)

How can the engineer fit the washer on to the rod?

A Cool the washer and put it over the rod.

B Cool the washer and rod to the same temperature and push them together.

C Heat the rod and then place it in the hole.

D Heat the washer and then place it over the rod.

Brownian motion is observed when looking at smoke particles in air using a microscope.

What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

A Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

B Smoke particles are moved by convection currents in the air.

C Smoke particles have different weights and fall at different speeds.

D Smoke particles hit the walls of the container.

Which statement is explained by reference to pressure?

A Objects with greater mass have greater weight.

B One kilogram of water occupies more volume than one kilogram of lead.

C Spikes on running-shoes sink into the ground.

D Water cooled to a low enough temperature turns to ice.

The diagram shows a mercury manometer used to measure the pressure of gas in a container.
 Atmospheric pressure is \( 76 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury.

![diagram](./assets/8914c503-86fb-4d23-9e63-297926f04912.png)

What is the pressure of the gas?

A \( 56 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

B \( 68 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

C \( 84 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

D \( 96 \mathrm{~cm} \) of mercury

Why does convection take place in a liquid when it is heated?

A Liquids expand when they are heated.

B Liquids start to bubble when they get close to boiling point.

C Molecules in the liquid expand when they are heated.

D Molecules near to the surface of the liquid escape into the air.
tags: Simple kinetic molecular model of matter

body:
A geologist places a small rock on the left-hand pan of a balance. The two pans are level as
 shown when masses with a total weight of \( 23 \mathrm{~N} \) are placed on the right-hand pan.
 Take the weight of \( 1.0 \mathrm{~kg} \) to be \( 10 \mathrm{~N} \).

![diagram](./assets/dfa2790c-2d61-49d0-b6c0-fc8c85110e92.png)

![diagram](./assets/d72f6bc6-2362-4729-8cbd-5edb3f3025f7.png)

What is the mass of the small rock?

A \( \quad 0.023 \mathrm{~kg} \)

B \( \quad 2.3 \mathrm{~kg} \)

C \( 23 \mathrm{~kg} \)

D \( 230 \mathrm{~kg} \)

The diagram shows a handle with three forces, each \( 100 \mathrm{~N} \), applied to it. The handle is free to
 move.

![diagram](./assets/f3779c90-4304-4584-9693-4e03a24fca4d.png)

What is the effect of the forces on the handle?

A The handle will move downwards.

B The handle will not move.

C The handle will turn anticlockwise (to the left).

D The handle will turn clockwise (to the right).

How many nucleons are in a nucleus of \( { }_{19}^{39} \mathrm{~K} \) ?

A 19

B 20

C 39

D 58

An electromagnet is used to separate magnetic metals from non-magnetic metals.

Why is steel unsuitable as the core of the electromagnet?

A It is a good conductor of electricity.

B It forms a permanent magnet.

C It has a high density.

D It has a high thermal capacity.

How can a permanent magnet be demagnetised?

A cool the magnet for a long time

B hit the magnet repeatedly with a hammer

C leave the magnet in a coil which carries direct current

D pass a small current through the magnet

Which type of wave cannot travel through a vacuum?

A infra-red radiation

B microwaves

C sound waves

D X-rays

A boy and a girl run up a hill in the same time.

![diagram](./assets/906ddc39-76d2-4ffa-b230-e9a14edd06d1.png)

![diagram](./assets/aa7b2a82-3b65-4797-bbcf-433d4e82a889.png)

boy weighs \( 600 \mathrm{~N} \)
 girl weighs \( 500 \mathrm{~N} \)

The boy weighs more than the girl.

Which statement is true about the power produced?

A The boy produces more power.

B The girl produces more power.

C They both produce the same power.

D It is impossible to tell who produces more power.

Which of the following is a unit of density?

A \( \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{g} \)

B \( \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \)

C \( \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

D \( \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \)

Which statement about the mass of a falling object is correct?

A It decreases as the object falls.

B It is equal to the weight of the object.

C It is measured in newtons.

D It stays the same as the object falls.

A piece of cotton is measured between two points on a ruler.

![diagram](./assets/c900b6d9-0f2b-47b9-a48c-96e8240c050e.png)

When the length of cotton is wound closely around a pen, it goes round six times.

![diagram](./assets/1e8ca7db-7c88-4a63-b665-421751c3728d.png)

What is the distance once round the pen?

A \( 2.2 \mathrm{~cm} \)

B \( 2.6 \mathrm{~cm} \)

C \( \quad 13.2 \mathrm{~cm} \)

D \( 15.6 \mathrm{~cm} \)
